review_body: Stayed here for 2 nights, even though the room size is small, it’s common in Tokyo which I am not complaining about. Value for money and great location. Convenience store right opposite the hotel. If you are a guy looking for prostitutes and hookers, don’t miss out on this hotel as there are usually a few standing near the hotel entrance for you to choose from. Highly recommend it!

Nice hotel. Easy to find and near to shinjuku station. Only thing that let it down was the prostitutes which hung around near the door every night. If the hotel moved them on then it would have made it a lot nicer to stay there

Room is small usually in Japan.But the design of the desk is too big.We booked the double bed room.With 2 full size luggage, no space to walk.But location is good. At the head of Godzilla Street. Will not book here again.

We have previously stayed in other hotels from the APA group so we knew what to expect. This particular branch is in the heart of Shinjuku nightlife and you are right next to shops, restaurants, bars etc. It is however about 10-15 walk from main Shinjuku station so be warned if you have got heavy bags with you and wanna walk it.The rooms are small like other japanese hotels. But they are clean with all that you need.There is Japanese public bath located on site if you are interested in the experience. Its less intimidating for the first timer.

There are many APA in Tokyo saw 6-8 just walking around our area in Shinjuku,This hotel appears to be new, rooms small like most business hotel in Japan, bed and pillow were soft and flat but suprisingly comfortable, staff speak good English, located in the middle of red light district but no problem, easy 15 mins walk from JR Shinjuku station, we bought round trip NEX ticket for 4200 Yen, one way is over 3000, no need to transfer - direct to Shinjuku and walk North to hotel.

Try to contact the hotel after the booking ..but the phone number is not working and the email do not get any reply. It is hard to contact without email. And call everytime , the phone say the phone number is not correct

This place is very good and it's location can't be beat for the nightlife in Shinjuku. Rooms are tiny but reasonably comfortable. Decent shower and bed. Breakfast is excellent and has a decent variety of items on offer. If you have tattoos you can't use the spa facilities, so I didn't as I have quite a few. It is close to everything including the Shinjuku station. Pillows are kind of lame but you can request a real pillow. I would do that as you check in as they have a limited amount of them.

Great location, 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station, a key station if you need multiple travel such as Shinkansen beside Tokyo wide movement. Plenty of eats around, from ramen to Sushi to Yakitori and Sukiyaki. It has great izakayas or Japanese pub for the salarymen and great to chill after a long day of business. It is otherwise also a seedy location after 11 pm where the area is also is a known red light district. Around APA you can prostitutes standing around from midnight.About this hotel, I have stayed here multiple times as I am in Tokyo every 2 months or so for business. My work takes me to Nakano, Shibuya and sometimes Ueno. Usually I would also make a trip to Osaka by Shinkansen. Hence Shinjuku is at the heart of all my travels, extremely convenient. Though there are other choices such as Prince etc another reason I love this hotel, is because I smoke, and they offer smoking rooms. As I understand, many travellers hated this hotel for the same reason, as even if they request for non smoking room, they can smell the tobacco. Another of my love of this hotel is they have a rooftop onsen free to guests. Nothing like a hot dip after a long day of business to sooth the nerves. Only complain is the onsen is very small, and usually full of rowdy tourists. Also be warned, the rooms here are very very small, you dont even have space for a large luggage. As I am here for work and not shopping, I didnt mind the size. Some other travellers complained the staff are rude. I would say probably some of the lobby counter staffs. Most room cleaning staffs are very nice. Some counter experience aren't so great. But since I am familiar with the hotel and their amenities, I didn't care much what the staffs say as I am aware the check in process is automated. Passport and form filling is a necessary procedure for hotels, even though I am here every 2 months staying at the same hotel, I fill in my name and particulars every time, even though I was pre-booked. That's procedure for you, no exceptions.Lastly, this may sound weird, but that's how unflexible the counter staff can be. Came in on a red eye flight, arrive 9 am, the room is not ready, ok I understand, deposit luggage and goes out to work and come back to the room in the afternoon is fine. Though if you ask for a toilet use so you can freshen up, they will direct you back to the public toilets back where you came from near Shinjuku station. Though level 2 they have a restaurant, Common Room, with multiple toilet facilities. BUT their point is, you are not a guest YET. So no. You can't use the toilet. So yea, be prepared. Freshen up at Odakyu or Lumine at Shinjuku station ahead. At APA, when you haven't get your room, you arent their guest.

The booking for the hotel was a complex process as staff and client need to enter allDocuments in a e-desk and neither of us could manage that easily...I must say , the exit process is much easier.Anyway, once you get into the rooms , it looks small but very sparkling clean ,Modern and comfortable.A usual room is the size of 2 double beds, hahah, but it s fine for a few days.There is a cleaner laundromat 8 mn from the hotel , asMy son mentioned !!!The best part of Apa hotel is that it is in the heart of shinjuku night life , and still not noisy!!!

review_body: The tower and its location are quite funky, in the middle of all the action and close to the station. How the lobby looks 70s chic despite the whole building being much younger is a mistery to me but that might be down to taste.However the rooms are very, very small, even for Japan. The hallway is super cold as if the tower was open at the top, so the cold immediately creeps in if you don't crank up the AC, temperature control can be tricky. The pillows and the bed were uncomfortable AF. I'd say it's a good place to stay if you're a solo traveller, otherwise it's not great.I didn't mind the knocking sounds at night, the area is known for lots of people having 'late night visitors' but I didnt have a great sleep either.

Stayed for 4 nights at APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower. It must have been my 7th stay at this hotel. It is affordable yet the standard is good! I choose this hotel whenever I visit Tokyo as it is conveniently located near Shinjuku Station (East Exit) and there are a lot of shops and eateries nearby. Although Kabukicho is supposed to be the ‘red light district’, it didn’t bother me much. Most of the touts didn’t really disturb me when I passed by at night. The hotel is basic yet clean and comfortable. The room is small (as expected of Japanese hotels) but the bed is comfortable (although the pillow is too thin!). The sento (indoor bath) at the top floor is a great place to relax after a long day out. The staff are courteous and provide great service (as with most service staff in Japan). No problems communicating as the staff are able to speak English well. Will definitely choose to stay here again when I’m back in Tokyo!

We stayed here one night just to be near the airport for our flight the next day. When I wasLooking at check-in info the night before I noticed our booking was down as a smoking room, which neither me nor my partner smoke so would never have selected this. We booked through booking.com and I would have noticed this if it was explicitly listed during booking, so unfortunate, but not the hotels fault. I asked at check-in whether they had any non-smoking rooms but they said they were all full, again, not their fault, just be weary during booking! The room did smell of smoke but we opened the window as far as it would go (which wasn’t far unfortunately as it was one of those high-rise windows that only open a crack). The room did have a air purifier though which we put on. Once you got used to it it wasn’t too bad, and when we left I was smelling our clothes and bags and no smell seemed to stick. The room was however very very hot, and I tried the air conditioning but to no avail.I am sure if I went to reception they would have helped but I was only there such a short time I just let it slide. Very nice hotel though, very pleasant staff, would return, just make sure it’s a non-smoking room!

review_body: First of all the room is fine if you’re one person, using it to only sleep and you don’t mind listening to other people have sex or not being able to control the air conditioning. If you are more than one person, if you can’t sleep while listening to constant banging on the walls from local prostitutes, if you like to have enough room to actually open your suitcase and unpack it, and if you like to be able to controlThe temperature of the room DO NOT BOOK. I am very ill and have a fever and I could not get the aircon to work. I was toldto open the door as the hotel aircon would only be blowing hot today. Absolutely awful stay would not recommend to my worst enemy.

Stayed here in January and this seems to be my "go to" place to stay in the city. Clean, modern, convenient and excellent staff. Prices can vary depending on demand, so bets to book as far in advance as you can. Rooftop onsen is fantastic.

Yes, the rooms are small. But we never felt too cramped during our six night stay. You'll find a place for everything and when you come back to your room exhausted after a full day of exploring Tokyo, you'll crash into the comfy bed and sleep great. We didn't have any noise issues up on the 24th floor and we enjoyed the incredible view of the sprawling city. Overall you can't beat this location and price. If this is your first time in Tokyo, I would recommend this hotel.

This hotel is stunningly appointed, only. minutes from train stations and all the shopping and dining one could wish for. Best feature is a spa/onsen on the top (28th) floor with spectacular views of the Tokyo skyline. Nearby Samurai Museum is highly recommended.

review_body: Caters for mass market. Standard double room was very small. Location is great but please make sure you have plug adaptors as no USB port in rooms.Also low floors can be bery noisy and a long wait for lifts. Breakfast very average

I would never stay in this hotel. The hotel is always right. The customer is always wrong. The staff were surly and unhelpful. The rooms are sooooo small you cannot move.The staff in the bar are very nice

If you are looking for the perfect location, this is it. In the heart of Shinjuku & walking to everything. amzingly convenient and actually quite quiet. Reception was helpful with maps and info. The room was clean. We woudl stay here agian in a second. (Yes, the rooms are tiny & the bathrooms are tiny & the spa will not allow you to enter if you have tattoos.)

The hotel is located in the heart of the city with walking distance to the train station and nearby everything. The room is very small compared with the price we've paid. Overall is okay in terms of location but don't expect too much with the room and facility at this place.

Hotel's aminities is so good, complete, and clean.It's really good for a budget hotel.But, the room (and bathroom) is so small even for 1 person. And, me and my wife gonna travelling to Kyoto-Osaka for days but the Hotel won't allowed to keep our luggage there, even I notify that I'll stay there AGAIN (already booked) when I come back to Tokyo at the exact date. Really disappointed with the regulation so I make sure I'm not coming back. Thank you for making us walked looking for storage in the morning so we missed our morning train✌(The most unpleasant thing that ever happen to me in Japan).

After reading some of the reviews I was pretty hesitant as to what the hotel would be like. However I was pleasantly surprised! The room is tiny but the bed is comfortable and the washroom has everything you need. The hotel is centrally located and has plenty of restaurants, convenience stores open 24/7. Overall, what a great stay and we’ll definitely be back!

I do business in Tokyo frequently and really like this hotel. It is very close to the various train and subway stations in Shinjuku (an easy walk) so it's easy to get to my customers from this area. In addition, a bus from Haneda stops at Shinjuku station as well as the Narita Express to Narita. It's an APA hotel so caters to business people and those on a budget. That said, it does have a public bath (hotel guests only) on the top floor which is nice to relax after a stressful day. There are so many restaurants and bars in the area that you can find anything you can possibly want to eat or drink. There is also a big Movie complex a block from the hotel (the one with Godzilla on the roof). Only caution is that Shinjuku is one of the most crowded area of Tokyo and the Shinjuku station is very complex and confusing at times.

Had an amazing three weeks travelling Japan and our last stay was here at APA Shinjuku tower. Was let down by the rude staff behind the the desk, they are not interested in helping customers at all, when ask for help they tut and huff and shake there heads!!!Will be speaking to APA head office as I think someone from corporate needs to spend time with the staff here as it’s shocking!! Look at others bad reviews for this hotel all mention rude staff.

We have never stayed in Tokyo before and expected small rooms, these were very very small. Windows don’t open and the air con was intrusively noisy. The hotel is in front of a square where drunks loiter all day and night and litter everywhere which is unusual for Japan. The room was not very clean either. Also we had accidentally booked a smoking room not actually knowing they existed. This was disgusting, we kept all our clothes in the suitcase and the few that were out absolutely stank afterwards. We had to wash them at our next stay in Kyoto. When we asked if we could move rooms the staff were very helpful and we only had one night in the smoke, after that at least the room did not smell. However I would not recommend this hotel.

The rooms are compact - to say the least. There was barely enough room to put our suitcases. However, we expected small rooms when travelling in Japan. The room had everything we needed and was within close proximity to the train station and a lot of good restaurants. The only turn off from this hotel is the square which is adjacent to the hotel. There is a lot of people who congregate there and drink and leave their rubbish everywhere! I can’t stand people who litter. It is a turn off considering Japan is overall very clean. If you are looking for somewhere conveniently located with all the basic amenities then I would recommend this hotel.

So disappointed in myself for not paying more attention to the negative reviews here; I pride myself on my travel research but failed here. I wanted a high view of the city and good breakfast at a reasonable price...which I got. But just barely. BathRoom smelled like mold. Could move us to the 3 Rd floor...etc etc. In the end, they were able to get rid of the mold smell by the 2nd day. Others complained about the pillows...I thought a bit petty. But NO...they are the worst. Flat little pancakes. Actually tried to buy 2 but couldn't find a target-like store close by. LOCATION: thought all the homeless, bottles & trash in front would be fine...but it was THE gathering spot in all Shinjuku for this. Smell of vomit in the morning. Being near Shinjuku Sta. was not the advantage I thought bc it is SO vast... Realized it would be better to be near a metro and just transfer rather than wandering forever in hot underground.Breakfast was pretty good and w variety. I love eggs in the a.m. but these eggs are a thick soup. I actually tried to microwave some after breakfast and they would NOT cook even though boiling...so don't know what they really were??In the end, the bed was comfortable and the room very clean. Appreciated the pajamas. Staff needs training. A welcome smile and "hello" in ANY language goes a long way. Felt they were there to make sure you follow the rules,never to help. I do not recommend.Would not recommend.

Where do I begin with this stay. I would say to date this is the worst hotel we have ever stayed in with abysmal service. We arrived at the hotel at 3am, following 12 hours of travelling, to find they had cancelled our booking following an email they sent to us not even 24 hours before requesting we mail to confirm the booking, even though we already had and had provided card details for them to take the payment. We sent a further email just one hour after their email to advise we would still be arriving and after 12am due to our flight. The receptionists could speak limited English and even with a translator our point and frustration did not seem to be getting across. As a resolution, they offered to put us in a smoking room which was something we did not want to do and advised of this but with no choice at all we felt stranded and had no where else to go at that hour so had to stay. This audial brought me to tears and once we seen the room, things were even worse. The room stank, it was unclean, there were holes in the sheet and we could not breathe. To top things off, the AC did not work in over 30c heat so as you can imagine we would not sleep. We reported this to the hotel but again, nothing was done about it. No apology. No refund. Nothing. They then offered to move us to a non-smoking room which was obviously what we had booked, they told us to leave our cases downstairs and once we arrived back at the hotel, the cases would be in our new room. Upon return, needless to say the cases where still in the lobby and our room not sorted. This had become our worst nightmare and ruined what was otherwise a great holiday. Awful service and awful welcome, would not recommend and would never stay in an APA again. The rooms are also the size of a coffin. Worst hotel I have ever visited.

Room was SO tiny. Could hardly 'swing a cat' - one person had to sit & wait while the other moved about getting dressed or making a cup of tea. Right in the middle of Shinjuku entertainment district but the square downstairs had many street dwellers in it lying around all day with their beer cans & rubbish littering the street. There was vomit in a few places in the street outside in the mornings. It stunk. Absolutely disgusting. Not family friendly. Extremely noisy in the room if you are fronting the square.The staff were reasonably proficient but lacking in English skills. They only change your linen on the bed every 4 days! Towels changed daily with a quick clean up. A/c was good (extremely hot while we were there) although there is none in the lifts or central corridor area. Wifi was good.Lots of convenience stores, restaurants & shops close by. Shinjuku station 5 minute walk. Bus station a good 20 minute walk. Would recommend to stay further away from this 'square' downstairs.

Cute, small hotel in a perfect location near many restaurants. It's also near a movie theatre and you can see the Godzilla statue as well. Really easy to get to and close to train station so you can visit the other areas as well

This is my third time staying in two years. I simply love the location. It’s near Shinjuku station and it’s surrounded by so many entertainment and food choices (including 24 hours outlets). It’s also great that Toho Cinemas is right beside it so you can watch a movie there if you want to. There is also an onsen for guests in the hotel, so that’s a plus.As a solo traveler, I’m not too bothered that my room is small. It’s functional, comfortable and cozy. I’m paying more for the location and continence more than anything. Very recommended.

Excellent location. located in Shinjuku where a lot of restaurants, shops, entertainment nearby!!! Close to train and subway! Hot public bath on the roof is a plus as well... Great relax for a day long travelling. Room is small... But given this price level? Totally understandable. Recommended.

Stayed at this hotel for a week while in Tokyo. The room was very small but the service was very good. The bathroom had all the supplies you could ever need in the case you forgot something. The air conditioner worked very well and excellent water pressure in the bathroom.

The front desk service staff are rude, impatient to listen to the customers. In room air-condition vents are stuffed with dust, the room feels dusty. Definitely not what I expected to experience in Japan.Location for shopping is good, however the hotel area is messy, I saw drunk people lying on the floor sleeping almost every morning, fights at local bars, police patrols.

We booked a non-smoking room (and it was re-iterated by the reception that it is non-smoking room) yet upon entering the room it is nothing but full of cigarette smell that almost triggered an asthma attack! I hope they can be more careful on that point because an attack is no joke.Otherwise public bath is public bath which opens daily from 3pm to 11am (well not sure those far away but not too far residential and hotel can see through or not though), the rest are up to the usual Japanese standard. It is very convenient area filled with eateries and near the subway. Some find the area too many people, while some may find it a little messier as there is a disco/club right opposite the main door of the hotel, you often find people getting drunk in the squad right at the door of the hotel. One additional thing to note about staying in Shinjuku is that one has to get used to getting lost in the station unless you have been around umpteen times... room size is okay, consider not bad as it is in Shinjuku...

Extremely small rooms by western standards. No closets to hang anything up. You suitcases will be in the way and you will have to move them constantly so you can exit the room, get in your bed etc. Otherwise it is clean, modern.

Compact and efficient. Great place to drop your stuff and enjoy the surroundings. Amazing location to experience the unique attractions that is Shinjuku. Ask at the desk for laundry accommodations and there is a spa on the 28th floor.

An interesting experience on check-in (I work in the accommodation industry) to be told at 11am our room would be ready at 2pm, and we have been allocated a room on the 19th floor. We had a booking for 4 nights.When returning to the Hotel at almost 3pm we were advised our room had been allocated to someone else because "we are a business hotel" and that we could have a room on the 6th floor, otherwise we would have to wait until 6pm to check in. Very confused! Housekeeping apparently works 2 shifts to allow for short term stays in this "business hotel". Rooms are allocated to check-in as soon as they are cleaned.A few questions later and we were on the 22nd floor and able to check in straight away. Room was clean & nicely presented. Central location and only a few minutes walk to the main station for access to anything via a train!

Prime Location, Safe And Clean. Rooms Are Small But Ok. Lot Of Place To Shop Near By. Lot Of Please To Eat IF You Like To Experiment With Food. There Are Few Indian Restaurant But Food Will Not Taste As In India Due To Different In Spice.

Stayed here for 4 days. From Haneda International Airport, you need to take the limousine bus to Shinjuku and then take a taxi. The room is okay as expected (smaller compared to other countries). The breakfast is okay. The location is superb. After a long day, you could roam around or go shopping. Near the train station.

We had a pleasant stay in the apa kabukicho Tower hotel. The check-in was smooth and the hotel room was neat and clean. We didn't find the room smelly or dusty as some other reviews stated. We felt safe and really enjoyed our stay here. We would stay again without drama.

We chose this hotel mainly because of its location - it is a stone throw away from all the shopping areas in Shinjuku. The room was small but this was expected in Tokyo. Room was clean with standard amenities. A big plus is the onsen - perfect for schilling after a long day of shopping! Will come back!

Hotel staff said they cannot call a taxi when I asked for one on a rainy day. I wanted to send a letter which already had a stamp and address but they said they cannot send it and showed me the way to the nearest postbox. A candy that had been under the chair in my room upon my arrival was still there when I left after two(!) weeks. In the bathroom the cups provided were not plastic or glass but mere paper cups.

APA is a business hotel chain throughout Japan that offers an adequate size room for its business clientele. This one in Kabukicho has more tourists because the convenient location right in Shinjuku shopping area and a 5 minutes walk to the Shinjuku station.It is a basic hotel room, if it is only for sleeping it is good enough. The room that I chose was small tiny, a double bed and the floor is not enough to open a big suitcase. Well I just have to manage.The room I had was not properly cleaned. The onsen is good to relax after all day walking around.

We liked this hotel on our last visit to Tokyo, so we chose it again despite the very high price. This time there were many problems. I reserved on their website, and found that "pay with credit card" means pay immediately, even though the reservation can be cancelled. The confirmation stated "pay at hotel, but I was 11,000 km away when payment was taken. If I had cancelled, I would have had to pay bank currency conversion fees twice, about 5%. As a reward for using their website, we were given three boxes of curry mix that we left behind instead of carrying around 3 weeks. The other "reward" was a room on the bottom floor close to a blank dirty wall (their website does not offer choice of room placement. The light from the window barely changes from night to day. The room lighting was also dim, so we were constantly in gloom. With 24 floors above us, down elevators often arrived full so going down one or two floors could be slow. We would be happy with stairs, but those were out of bounds. Other irritations were a TV that switched on with the same loud advertising each time we entered the room and precious space in the room given to publications with the opinions of APA's president.The hotel was very well maintained and everything worked well, except that the beds seemed soft and lumpy. The room was very quiet, but we didn't seem to be able to cool the room and opening the window was not allowed. Housekeeping was excellent, and made sure the extensive amenities were well stocked. Breakfast was again the high point, it was one of the best we had in Japan. It had a great selection, was never too busy, and staff was helpful and efficient.In conclusion, I disagree with the hotel's motto. I won't be back.

Great location next to subway with a beautiful sparkly lobby and friendly staff..and that's about it. I found it way overpriced for the teeny tiny room we got. The pool outside is small and unheated. The food at the restaurant was horrible, which includes the gross breakfast. The checkin process is confusing and took forever. Didnt find a lot of good dining options in the area.I wouldn't stay here again.

Hotel was better than expected after reading all the reviews beforehand. We had 3 rooms for family of 5- rooms/bathroom are extremely small (but very little time is spent in them)- rooms given a basic daily service of fresh towels/bins emptied/bedding straightened-fantastic location, close to all restaurants/attractions/station - staff polite and helpful

This is a modern straightforward hotel, right in the heart of Shinjuku that provides great value for money. Check-in was easy, our room was clean but small. The bed was large and comfortable but may be too hard for some. Bathroom was functional and clean with a very good shower. It's very close to transport links and within walking distance to all that Shinjuku has to offer. We had a very enjoyable four night stay whilst exploring Tokyo. Would definitely stay again.

stayed 2 nights at this hotel, the staff were nice, the room is squeezing, and the aircon didn't work at the time. there were some other guests complaining about the aircon as well. location is good, close to the station, price was cheapest compare to other APA in town during the time.

This is our last (5th) night in Tokyo and the APA Shinjuku so we feel well placed to offer an impartial review.Check-in was very quick and easy with friendly staff.We stayed in room 1111The rooms are small but immaculately clean and presented. The bathrooms are also very clean and everything you can think of is provided for you, from toothbrush, razors, shampoo etc. They also have the amazing Japanese toilets.Bottled water is provided after the first night and a small fridge is available for use.The beds are comfy and the pillows are 3D mesh so quite flat. This is fine for me but my wife did struggle with the pillow.The biggest issue with the room was a lack of storage space. There is nothing other than a few hangers on the wall. This meant we lived out of our cases for the duration. A simple shelf or under bed space would seriously help in this regardThe biggest appeal of the hotel is the location. It's right in the heart of Shinjuku and close to the main Shinjuku station which can get you all around Tokyo.If you are after an affordable hotel that is clean, comfy and in an excellent location you can't do much better than the APA Shinjuku.We didn't opt for the breakfast nor did we use the common cafe. so we can't comment on this.

Rooms are very small, beware if you have a couple of big suitcases. Bed very comfortable. Pillows flat but I prefer that. Room was stuffy and unfortunately the window doesn't open (not surprising given it was on the 26th floor). We found the room perfectly clean. Toilet a highlight for a foreigner! Lifts amazingly fast and smooth. Breakfast was great, staff there very friendly. Check-in staff seemed to be in training, but we didn't interact with them much. Never got to try the bath experience. Can't fault the location if you want convenience to train station/airport, places to eat, stereotypical Tokyo nightlife. Felt very safe even at night.

Don't fall for the hotel description. It is located in a rather seedy area with lots of girly shows and dirty streets. They talk about luxurious linens but the pillows are flat as a pancake. No bellmen to help with luggage. I realized the room was less than clean when I closed the toilet seat and saw someone else's urine and pubic hair laying there. Unfortunately I was booked and paid for 3 days and they refused to refund so I was stuck. Never again. I am attaching a photo if dirty toilet and street.

All staffs here are consistently with poor service attitude, from check-in counter to the buffet restaurant. Don't bother wasting your money here unless you would like to spoil your beautiful holiday and good impression of the Japanese people. I'm utterly distraught. Otherwise, room is efficiently small that's good for 1 person.

The air quality in the hotel rooms was terrible... so terrible that the hotel actually has air purifier machines inside the room for you (which kept blinking in red, which indicated the air quality was bad). I stayed here in April, and I could not breathe properly inside the room because it was so stuffy and hot. The air system only had heat coming out and there was no way to turn on A/C or the fan. Even though I didn't turn on the heat, every day when I came back to the room, it felt like an oven. I had to keep my hotel room door wide open (with the help of a chair) every night for a few hours before going to sleep because it was so stuffy and hot. I think the room was also dusty because my nose started feeling very congested and I also kept sneezing. The hotel was also very small. The whole room was basically the bed plus a small desk where you can open your luggage because there's no other space for you to do so. There was no closet — only 2 hooks and a few hangers. The bed and pillows were also super uncomfortable. The pillow was as thin as a blanket and the bed was so soft that your entire body would sink in. The hotel lobby was also very small and there's not even a restroom in the lobby. It was also very noisy, where you can hear people talking, throwing bottles, and listening to music on the street, and there was construction going on early in the morning as well. The receptionists were not very helpful either. Whenever I asked a question, such as if a room on a higher floor is possible or if I can have a later check out time, they would just show me a price that I have to pay. Usually, hotels would allow you to have a different room or check out a bit later if the hotel isn't full.The only good part is that the towels were very clean and the shampoo and conditioner (Shiseido) were nice. And also, there's a Family Mart across the street where you can buy water, delicious snacks, and beverages. There's also a Krispy Kreme nearby where you can grab donuts for breakfast, and the location was pretty convenient. Otherwise, there's nothing good about this hotel.

Currently part way through my 3 days stay here and it is so dusty in my room I've been breathing through my mouth whenever I've been in the room. The bed and room have clearly not been cleaned properly in a very long time. Made the mistake of opening my window and there is a thick layer of dust on the window ledge, and as there are carpets in the room god knows how much dust there is in them.As there is no safe in the room it makes it very difficult to get housekeeping to clean the room when you are out too, making the problem even worse.Small rooms as expected in Tokyo, the bedroom is manageable if you put one bag on top of the desk, however the bathroom is very tight. I'm slim yet struggled to use the toilet.However one positive is that location is fantastic.

This hotel is perfect for those who just need a place to sleep and good access to Tokyo's main attractions. I found the Shinjuku/Kabukicho area the most lively neighbourhood in Tokyo, you can eat, dine, shop, entertain here 24h per day. Its a 10min walk from the hotel to the Shinjuku subway station's Oedo an Marunouchi lines. There are plenty of 24/7 convenience stores (familymart, lawson, 7-eleven) nearby. The room has a refrigerator to store food or cold drinks. Room facilities are good, I especially liked the bathroom with its comfortable shower. Like in most of Japan's big city hotels, the rooms are relative small, but are clean and smartly designed. It was great to have at least one global TV channel (BBC news), instead of japanese channels only. The room can however be noisy, especially as of 6am in the morning you can clearly hear the trains starting to move at Shinjuku station. Although I enjoyed breakfast at the hotel restaurant every morning w/o any queues, it looked to me undersized - both in size and personnel - knowing that the hotel has around 600 bedrooms over 28 floors.

We stayed at APA Shinjuku Kabukicho for 4 nights.When we first arrived we noticed how small our room was but then we got used to it. This is expected in Japan too. The room was very clean and the staff were very friendly. The JR station is close by, about a 10 minute walk which was really convenient. The highlight of this hotel for us was the spa offered at the top floor.Overall, we enjoyed our stay and would definitely book again next time we’re in Tokyo!

We stayed a total of 6 nights and were extremely happy with our choice of stay. While the room is extremely small (11sqm), the bed and pillows were comfortable. The smart TV also allowed us to stream NetFlix by using smartview. The in-house bath and man-made onsen was awesome, with the availability of an outdoor bath. Facial products and branded shampoos and shower gels were also provided for all guests. The hotel is also located near the Shinjuku metro station which is one of the main interchange to many other metro lines. There were multiple restaurants and a few convenience stores near the hotel so one does not need to worry about late night hunger. Will definitely stay here again!

The location cannot be beat. The hotel is located in the heart of Shinjuku and Kabukicho. The JR station is just a short walk away and there is a lot of food selections in the area. The lights at the Shinjuku area are wonderful as always.The negatives are:1) The room is really small. Just a few steps and you are at the end of the room. It is almost impossible to open my luggage and have any extra space to move around in the room. And I only had one luggage. I guess they gave me a tiny room as I travelled solo.2) Be prepared to wait for the lifts. They are so slow that there is usually a queue of people waiting for the lift in the lobby. I’m general, the main selling point of the hotel is the location. The location is just really good.

We stayed at APA hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho towers for 5 nights. The location was great for us, walking distance to samurai museum, robot restaurant and Godzilla Rd. Shinjuku Station is about 8 min walk. Our room was very small but it was very clean and had everything we needed and more. It was much cheaper than other hotels in the area and we were happy with our stay. If you are expecting a luxurious spacious room you will be disappointed, but if you just want a nice clean place to sleep and shower it’s great. I would definitely stay here again.

Fantastic location and has its own onsen - both in door and outdoor right in the heart of the city! Food galore and not a problem at all. You even have the famous Ichiran and other famous restaurants just at your doorstep. You will be spoilt for choice too for shopping. Great place to be!

Close to most of the main attractions/restaurants/center and affordable price. If you are trying to save money on hotels, this is the place to stay, especially if you aren't going to spend a lot of time in your room.

Good Location, JR Shinjuku within 10 mins walk from exit. Restaurants and shops around, so you wont get bored or hungry. Convenience store is around the hotel.But the mattress is very old and bad. Extremely soft in the middle so you wont have a good quality of sleep actually. Air conditioner cannot turn into Cool Mode in winter, just keep in Warming Mode.Toilet or the toilet seat is a bit smelly.They have onsen on the top floor which is good at this price and location.

Convenient location that are packed full of eateries, shopping centers, nightlife venues, combini. The JR station might be a bit further than you would like, but is still within walking distance. The Seibu station however, is right beside the hotel. The hotel is clean and english speaking staff are at hand to assist you.

Great hotel and location, fairly close to train station. Room was small but not a bad if your going to spending most of your time out. Plenty to do near hotel and amazing restaurants. Would stay here again.

For a hotel in the centre of the entertainment district, the APA is great. Rooms are the standard business type, on the small side but perfectly adequate, clean and smelling fresh. In December/January the nice warm room is welcome. The best part is the sento on the top floor, a great place to relax and freshen up at the end of a long day.

Location is great. 9 min walk from Shinjuku station east exit and surrounded by convenience stores and food. But that's about it. Room is almost clean. The other reviews about the grime at the sink and dust in the drawers are true. I've been to Tokyo many times before but never before lived in a room so small. There's definitely no space to open 2 luggage. We had ours against the door which would be problematic in the event of an emergency evacuation. Hotel replies say the big bed and small room concept so you don't have to move around is not true. The bedside controls are just for the lights. Nothing else high etch about the room. It's TINY. In our double room, the bed was surrounded on 3 sides by walls. But the location is great. If you just want a place to sleep for yourself, this is it.

Hotel has nice location, but very noisy and many drunk people in the area. Staff in the reception is just horrible , not polite and very rude.We were very disappointed from the front desk staff especially someone name minami that after an incident when we wanted to complain she refused to give us the manager details

The hotel is in the center, but because of its location its very noisy in night, and it is really disturbing the sleep in night. The hotel staff is very unpolite and not welcoming! We visited in other hotels in tokyo and the staff were amazing, only here rude .We wont come back here again. Also the rooms very very small

The APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho is a convenient spot located in the heart of Shinjuku. It's right next to VR Zone, Family Mart & 7 Eleven, Toho Cinema with Godzilla on top, and much more. The hotel is 28 stories high, complete with smoking & non-smoking rooms. Mine was a non-smoking, and I found the room to be decent size. I am 6 ft 4 in, and I fit on the bed just fine. The blanket for the bed is pretty heavy, and while I stayed in the coldest time of Japan's winter, you may get a little hot. The heater in the room dries the air, but the hotel brings you a water bottle every day after cleaning (around 2-4 PM). The bathtub is narrow, but tall, with hot water that will last.For what you pay and the location you are getting, you are receiving a good deal. I would stay here again.

we stayed here with 10 friends. the location is awesome and the price is quite reasonable. we payed 150 a night. the rooms are clean but super pokey, but every place ive stayed in tokyo is pokey. tip there is a lobby bar. a great place to gather before you go out. if you show your hotel swipe card, you get a draft beer for 280 yen. bloody bargin

The room was very very very small. Matchbox sized. For 2 people we barely had any space to open our luggage and we kept bumping into each other. We used the corridor from the entry as our changing space as there was nowhere else to stand to get changed. The bathroom smelt disgustingly of mould. We made sure to keep the bathroom door open during the day and as we slept to air out the tiny room. I believe this smell contributed to us waking up with a dry throat every morning. Ventilation was poor. The room fogged up quickly while showering. For the price we paid, it was not value for money at all. We tried to spend as little time as possible in the room as it just wasn’t comfortable to be in for too long. My biggest regret is that I did not spend enough time reading the reviews of other guests before booking as I found similar comments. The Shinjuku area seems quite seedy. There are lots of gentlemen’s clubs around and prostitutes were a common sight. We also noticed many vomit patches on the grounds surrounding the hotel. I would not recommend this hotel to others and I certainly would not stay here again.

Lovely room with everything you'd need on a city visit - bath, good hot shower, nice toiletries, hairdryer, large comfy bed, desk, kettle, refreshments and new towels daily. View of Godzilla if you are also lucky! Microwave at the reception and ice machine on 28 were both put to good use. The hot bathing on floor 28 was a highlight with view over the city and the restaurant/cafe was very pleasant. Think the only trick they've missed is not putting underbed draws in to store clothes/luggage. That would save the floor space for people instead of stuff.

Obviously, thecleaning staff did not bother to inform you as the managerin charge.2.
