The hotel is nicely located. The check in process was fast and efficient and the staffs are also very friendly. The hotel room and the toilet itself is very very small and tight to the extend that is is very uncomfortable. With the same price, I found other hotel in the same area which offer a bigger room.

We stayed at the APA Shinjuku Kabuchiko Tower and used it as a base while in Tokyo. Brand new rooms and building a plus. The reception staff were average and the cleaning staff were very good except for the day they forgot to clean the room. Trying to organise a luggage service to the airport was very hard work full of contradicting information. Something they need to work on with tourists. We ended up organising Airporter ourselves, which worked out very well. The rooms are tiny, even by Japanese standards. The bed was comfortable but there really wasn’t room for suitcases that didn’t block movement within the room. Views of the Shinjuku area was nice from the upper floors. The main plus was the location - easy access to JR station and shops all around. As a family of 4 we had to split into 2 rooms - glad we did due to the size of the rooms. No amenities in the lobby, so once you check out, you’ll need to freshen up in a public toilet. Kabuchiko area was fine, we had young kids and felt perfectly safe.

Nice stay in a well located hotel in albeit the gaudy part of Shinjuku. Loads of eating options and not a lot of shopping in all reality but certainly a Tokyo feel. Rooms are tiny but clean and no real hotel features . Good always do worse 3.5 stars

Our double room was large enough for a bed and not much else. True, I expected a small room based on previous reviews. But man was it a lot smaller. A big plus, however, was the fact that the hotel is located in the heart of the Shinjuku area and a short walk from the Shinjuku train station. Overall (especially given the nightly rate), I don't think it was worth the stay.

The stay at this hotel is really a nice one. If you arrive early, they have an area where you can store your suitcase. You come back, get your keycard and go into one of the smallest rooms I've ever seen (I booked a single). However, it has a great bathroom area, a great bed and a desk where you can place all your things, and you're not going to be staying in your room that much - you're in Tokyo! The amenities are great and the staff is friendly. If you're like and like to take the stairs for exercise, don't count on it. The stairs are only for emergencies, but the elevator is efficient. I highly recommend this hotel. It's in a great area, and if you get hungry, there's a small fridge in the room and a Family Mart right across the plaza for you to stock up on food and beverage items.

Great stay but very small rooms! (+) Great location(+) Great top floor SPA(+) Great breakfast (western)(+) Great check in experience(-) Smallest room ever, don't fear claustrophobia!!(-) Not possible to open windows

First of all this is not that close to the train station, if you have luggage. 2. Instructions were useless. 3. You can not read the st signs. 4. This hotel is located on a plaza. Kids are outside all night even in the cold! 5. Rooms are tiny. The only saying grace is the soaking tub & good products!!! 6. No staff to assist you. Either they are swamped or the language issue. Shuttles do not pick up here which is why I would not chose this hotel again.

We recently stayed at this Hotel, it was only over night so we didn’t have long to experience the facilities. A little for check in so just be aware once actually being greeted at the front counter we were directed to us the self check in which wasn’t that hard to do. If you are thinking of breakfast it is a little cheaper to do it during the checking in process. The breakfast is well worth buffet style most dietary needs are catered for. The hotel is easy to find it it just under the big Godzilla which is hangs beside the movie cinema. For those who enjoy sharing a bath wit others the hotel’s onsen is ok a little hot but big enough when it gets busy. Would recommend this hotel it was good value for the location and the amenities provided.

Arrived early and being Japan cannot check-in till 3pm which is fine. Asked if room becomes available early can you call me as travelled from Singapore landing at 7am had a straight out no (I work in the industry and this is a industry standard to offer to guests to make their stay memorable to get a room earlier if possible). Rooms are extremely small but hey you are only there to sleep and should be out sightseeing and shopping. Location is great. Night before we left the receptionist was brilliant. The roof top spa area was also nice. Would I stay again, probably no due to many other choices and experiences to be had.

Location is strategic, in the center of shinjuku. Pro : near shopping center, easy to find restaurants. Con : I think not suitable for family with kids because the hotel is in red district shinjuku area.The room size is small.

Do not stay here!We booked to stay here for 3 nights over New Years and changed hotels in under 24 hours due to our room being over 30 degrees inside!The manager offered us a small desk fan as a fix. The hotel does not have air conditioning despite it advertising it does. The bathroom absolutely stank of mould and made us gag walking in. The staff were not helpful at all and refused to refund the following 2 nights booked. It is a tiny rip off hotel do not stay here no matter what!!!

The hotel is in the center of Shinjuku. However, it is a long walk from Shinjuku exit and its not ideal if carrying luggage. Its way too far.Food is readily available in the area as there are many restaurants.Hotel room is offers basic amenity and is very small. Its just okay for 1 person.

Subway station entrance a couple of blooks but a long walk inside just to get to the main area. First Impression, wow what a tall building, we paid a little more to be on the city view high floor 27, great view of the city. The rooms are small, so small the full size bedBarley fits the room. Once you put your luggage down there's no place to walk. The restroom is also small but doable. December it's cold and heater is a plug in portable unit but when you turn it on it gets all the dust in the air and everyone starts coughing, not sure if it's the filter. Cold in our room, window has draft leaking in room. Pros: large 60 inch flat screen niceCoffee maker good and little fridge Outlets US readyShower strong but weird small tub good for kids.Bathroom amenity kits and shampoo very nice.Toilet has a bidetEnjoy Japan for the food and shopping, people very respectful and helpful to tourist.

Definitely too small for a couple. We had two suitcases and one we had to keep in the tub because the room was extremely small. I have travelled a lot and this was one of the disappointing hotels. It was so cramped. The bathroom was unbelievably small. The area is not the best in Tokyo... lots of early morning partiers heading home... vomit on street.... prostitutes etc etc very dissapointed we ended up staying here on our last day in Tokyo. Lobby is deceiving as it look nice until you reach the rooms.Hotel is ok if you are single and just need somewhere to crash for the night. Pillows so bad and the bed was extremely uncomfortable. I'm not a high maintenance traveller by any means and i rarely leave bad reviews... I just can't look pass this unpleasant experience.

This hotel is very easy and quick to get to from Shinjuku Station, and it's great that you get to walk through all the streets to get there. The location of this hotel is very good - there's a Family Mart and 7/11 at your doorstep, a couple of VR and arcade places, and lots of delicious food. We arrived quite early before check-in and staff were happy to mind our luggage while we went exploring. Upon check-in, we went to our room and settled in. Please note, the rooms are not very big. The double bed takes up most of the space and there wasn't a lot of space for 2 big suitcases but we managed. The bathroom is compact and very easy to use.We didn't spend much time in ours rooms as we were out and about around Tokyo, and from other reviewers' photos, we didn't expect a big room. I found APA Hotel great value for money considering its location.

Hotel was located near a cinema, actually when you go out you will be exposed to everything. Great location I must say, but not too near the train station, there is one near but Shinjuku station will still be your main station. Rooms are very small, I stayed in a double room, and if you have huge luggages, better limit them if you will stay here. I liked my room since my bed is just beside the window where in when I sleep and turn on my side I will see the city! I moved to a twin room and I must say it was okay, bed are huge and very comfortable! The staffs are very polite when you are infront them, i think they some need more training with English. They offer luggage storage, and there is an onsen at the top, but I didn't try it. If you have enough budget, and travelling SOLO, I recommend this, but for a family/group, you might think about checking other hotels near that has bigger rooms.

Location is perfect, The lobby is nice.. rooms however are so so small, it was hard climbing over our suite cases to get to the bathroom and outside the room, the bed was comfy though. Might stay again.. not 100% sure tho lol

Stayed here for 5 nights when in Tokyo best thing about the hotel is location! You step outside the hotel and you are right into all the Shinjuku action! The room was very clean and as other reviews yes it is tiny but as long as you go in expecting a tiny room plus it is Tokyo! We barely spent any time in the room either! 5 mins walk to Shinjuku station also. Would not hesitate to stay again!

While the reception and auto check in experience was good, the first impression of our room was that it was dirty. For this price, I would expect better.Being primarily a tourist hotel, the turnaround of guests is number one priority, so cleaning rooms has perhaps been given a lower priority. Not sure of the reasons but please check my photos.The room was cold and temperature controlled by the management, so we ended up asking for blankets and a portable heater, which the staff politely supplied.Our room faced frontwards, so I’d expect some noise but there was a karaoke bar across the way from the hotel that played loud tracks into the street *all night*. I suppose to attract customers. The hotel windows were not thick enough, so apart from the cold, we could hear music blasting non stop, even on the ninth floor.Photo included.

Apa hotel is small...but the location is very good. Close to everywhere. Many entertainments. So much fun. Many restaurants, many types of resy , with good prices...many young people, and many tourist come here, the location is the best in Japan...

Most one star reviews are a bit of an exaggeration due to one small fault but this is one time that the business fully deserves the rating. I've been coming to Japan for over 10 years now and this is by far the worst service I've ever received. It's hard to point to one specific moment as every interaction was met by a disinterested, rude, and clueless staff. Some key moments include: prostitutes chilling the lobby and nothing being done about it; an extremely drunk person throwing up in the public bath area and security being called and nothing being done; workers not being able to find our bags after we stored it with them and asking us why we can't find it ourselves.

We stayed 3 days in this hotel but found that rooms are very small and no room service as well as it does not looks like a hotel . main train station is not near . The bath room is very compact and not easy for two persons in one time . location is perfect , its a happening area and everything is available nearby . Many stores are there to buy anything . One Indian restaurant is also nearby with veg food . To have a sleep only at a excellent location in Tokyo , its good property .

The location is near the JR station exit - HOWEVER, the shinjuku station is REALLY HUGE. So, it is still very far. By the time you get outside of the train station, you are already exhausted. Those with huge luggage beware that there are stairs with no elevator.But, to be fair with the location, it’s in the middle of everything - family mart, 711, don Quixote, Ichiran, Restaurants, fruit stands and so many drugstores where you can buy japanese products. They are very accessible, just 1-3 minutes walk from the hotel.The walk from the train to the hotel is bearable as it’s healthy, what we didn’t like is the fact that the bed sheets seems to be infested with bed mites. We’ve been lying on top of the bed cover for several minutes and we decided to snuggle under the comforter as the bed is really soft, comfortable and relaxing. But after being under the comforter for 15 minutes we started to get itchy. It’s as if there are bugs biting us that we cannot see. We immediately went to the reception area and reported it, and they immediately gave us a new room. We didn’t use the comforter anymore as we are afraid of the bed mites. We just requested for extra bedsheets. The customer service is great though.I would still recommend this hotel for couples without kids as the room is small (we booked double - they said you can bring 2 kids for free) because the customer service is great. But I hope they improve the cleanliness of their sheets.

We stayed here at the start of our 3 weeks in Japan and again at the end, Six nights in total. The hotel is in a great location..a short walk from the station, surrounded by restaurants, away from main roads, and just far enough away from the station so the trains are not heard. Near Golden Gai and the Robot show. The room is 'Japan size'...that is to say..compact...but comfortable, clean, well maintained...the bathroom is also very compact. The bed very comfortable. The hotel has a bar on the ground floor and breakfast is available. We didn't have break there so cannot comment on the quality.

Room - Very small, but got a double room. For the price, this is normal in Tokyo, especially in a busy place like Shinjuku.Facility - Japanese pool to relax, but no chance to try.Staff - not much interaction as this is an economic 'luxury' hotel as it self proclaim.Location - about 800m from Shinjuku station. Location is near the busiest area of Shinjuku, many shopping strrets.

The hotel is quite close to the Shinjuku train and subway station, and with many nearby food options. Rooms are modern, clean, and the bed is comfortable. The breakfast is a buffet with Japanese and Western options, both good, however the Japanese version is superior. We knew rooms were quite small from other reviews, but, this hotel pushes small to the limit of what we thought possible. The bed, as others wrote, touches 3 walls, the bathroom measures 1.2x1.6 mts, and, mind you, has a toilet, sink, and a tub with shower.

Excellent value for money. Unbeatable location, close to Shinjuku Station and many restaurants, clubs and facilities. I arrived very early from London but I was able to leave my luggage at reception. The rooms are spotlessly clean and full of amenities. Bed very confy too- yes the room might be smaller than European/American Standards but they are so nice that you don’t really mind. Views are breathtaking and yes, I will be back!

My wife and I checked in to the APA Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower in Tokyo for two nights after returning from Hiroshima. The room was so small that we could barely get our luggage in the place. The bed was less than a single; no amenities. A 50-inch TV covered one wall. It was abominable. The desk clerk said it was a "business" hotel. That indicated it was for prostitutes as there were sketchy people in the lobby, many drunk at midnight when we checked in. The room, as I mentioned, was so small you had to go out into the hall to change your mind. We said we were checking out the next morning--not wanting to stay--and they charged us $300 to get out of our second night. Streets were crowded with drunks and unsavory characters. This was the first time we saw police in the streets while in Japan. We would never go to APA properties after this episode.

Stayed at the APA hotel for approximately 10 days. Pros:- location is close to the nightlife, lots of good restaurants and bars - budget friendly - decent amenities (shampoo, conditioner, toothbrush, razor, towels, etc) Cons:- as others have mentioned, the room is VERY VERY VERY small & the bathroom is even smaller - note that this hotel is NOT a 5 min walk to Shinjuku station, closer to 10-15 min walk - note that there is very little interaction with staff, the reception people look miserable - no room service - maids did not really clean the room, they just quickly made the beds and replaced towels. I doubt they vacuumed All in all, I will likely not return to this hotel nor recommend it.

I had no issues with the hotel itself. I flew into Narita and caught the NEX to Shinjuku Station with two large suitcases, but was still able to walk the short distance from the station to the hotel. Checkin was super easy. I selected a higher floor room, and was able to stay on the highest floor with great views. Rooms are small as to be expected, but for me (a solo traveler) it felt quite cozy, rather than cramped. They’ll give you free bottled water each day that you request they do not change your bedsheets, but they require the sheets to be changed every 3rd day, and will not take ‘do not disturb’ as a request. I have tattoos so I could not have entry to their bathouse, but I’m a foreigner in their land, so I can’t complain about the culture. I still would recommend this hotel.The AREA the hotel is in is another thing. Kabukicho is quite seedy, and if you look like a male foreigner, expect to be harassed by African Men (I’m black myself, but you can tell by their accent) trying to scam you. One followed me for nearly a block as I was heading to Robot Restaurant, and would not take ‘no’ for an answer. Due to jet lag, I was up at 4am and the streets were still packed with people drunk out of their minds. I know this all sounds negative, but it was so cool to experience haha.Back to the hotel. There is a Family Mart and 7-11 within a few steps where you can buy booze around the clock, as well as get food for your room if you choose to not eat at the hotel. There is no microwave in the hotel rooms, so be sure to have the convenience stores heat up your meals (they offer to do it before you even pay.). Within the hotel, there’s a pub where they give hotel guests discounted drinks, although I found most/all places I visited in Japan give small amounts of red wine, and always serve it cold.I would definitely stay here again.

Great location in the heart of Shinjuku just steps away from arcades, VR Zone and Robot restaurant. Crowded all around so if you are looking for something secluded - not the place. Room was small but for Tokyo, expected. It had everything you will need and private bathroom. Pillows were my only complete as they were the thickness of a folded sheet. Other than the pillows it had everything you need in a compact space - even a fridge!

If you are looking for the place to be and you don't want to break the bank look no further than the APA hotel Kabukicho tower!My spouse wants to make sure I mention how minuscule the rooms are at this hotel. Listen I know that it is mentioned in every single review for this hotel but I'm not joking when I say that this is the smallest hotel room I've ever seen. This is pretty much the norm for Tokyo unless you want to pay a premium or choose a hotel far from the action. The bed literally touches 3 of the 4 walls. If you are two adults in this room and you want to relax a little before going out or in the evening one person will need to be on the bed and the other using the desk because there is nowhere else to go. You will not be able to open two suitcases at the same time.Now that I've gotten that disclaimer out of the way I need to mention how great the location is for this hotel. It is literally in the heart of Kabukicho. You want things to do, people to see, places to eat and arcades to play at? This is the place to be! Karaoke, sure! Clubs and bars? Absolutely! fine dining, street food or combini, no problem! This place has it all and it's open late! This place is a short walk from two different subway station including Shinjuku station on the Yamanote line.The hotel was surprisingly quiet, there was more sound coming from outside than from inside. We also utilized this hotels' parking lot. The hotel has a manned parking garage which offers a really good rate (1200jpy for the night). We arrived really late and still managed to obtain a parking spot even though they are limited. If ever it is full there are two other pay lots across the street.The micro washroom was one of those pre-built plastic units. Very small but very clean and the soap/shampoo was of nice quality. The bed was comfortable and the Television worked well. The only negative I have about the room was that the carpet vacuuming could be better in the corners.English communication was not a problem at this hotel.The only advice I will give you is if you are a tourist in Kabukicho beware of the TOUTS. They come out at night and they target anyone who doesn't look local! They speak English and will approach you trying to pass as a club/bar promoter trying to get you into their shady bar. DON'T. Walk past them, just ignore them they will not go after you. They only come out at night anyways. If you do this you will enjoy your time here.

Stayed for 3 nights in June 2018 at APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower. It must have been my 5th stay at this hotel. It is affordable yet the standard is good! I choose this hotel whenever I visit Tokyo as it is conveniently located near Shinjuku Station (East Exit) and there are a lot of shops and eateries nearby. Although Kabukicho is supposed to be the ‘red light district’, it didn’t bother me much. Most of the touts didn’t really disturb me when I passed by at night. The hotel is basic yet clean and comfortable. The room is small (as expected of Japanese hotels) but the bed is comfortable (although the pillow is too thin!). The sento (indoor bath) at the top floor is a great place to relax after a long day out. The staff are courteous and provide great service (as with most service staff in Japan). No problems communicating as the staff are able to speak English well. Will definitely choose to stay here again when I’m back in Tokyo!

Stay here for 2 nights. The double room is quite small where we can not open both our 28inch luggage together. Must one put up straight while open one luggage at the time. However, this hotel is very new and clean. They still change the towel, bathrobe and throw rubbish bin for us even tho we put the eco green tag (only bed sheet will not get change) for room service and gave us a bottle of 500ml mineral water as a thank you rewards for going green. Overall distance is 10mins walk from main station called shinjuku station. Very near to eatery shopping& family mart is just opposite and its happening at night as this area is red light district in shinjuku. Check. In time is at 3pm but i reach early at 12pm.they do provide service to help you store luggage for free. Very good English speaking staff.

I stayed at the APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower on a last-minute booking after landing at the airport to find all trains had been cancelled to Kobe due to the typhoon. My room was miniscule but everything fitted in and it was spotlessly clean and modern. Check in was efficient and after seeing Reception, you then check in via a kiosk. The downside to this was needing to make a quick decision whether to pay for breakfast or not. I did. Breakfast was buffet style with reasonable choice but I thought quite expensive at 1,800 yen.

APA Hotel takes you to the raw energy and fun vibe of Tokyo because of its accessibility to most of the city’s must-visit places. The hotel is just few meters away from Don Quijote where you can buy all the souvenir ideas you can possibly imagine. Nearby, restaurants abound so you can test the flexibility of your palate to taste the prided Japanese food, depending on your appetite and budget. On my first night, I ate at a nearby small restaurant and had my filling ramen welcomed me to the warmth and taste of Japan. If you want to explore other parts of Tokyo, the Shinjuku Train Station is near. It was September 24 when I roamed around Shinjuku and the night life was so alive and intense. The throng of people in the streets mirrored the electric vibe of Tokyo. However, if you want to have your much-needed nature rejuvenation, Shinjuku Gyo-en National Park is also nearby. Walking distance from the hotel, you can spend your entire day exploring thr garden and its splendor. After a long yet fufilling day, you can rest in the comfort of your room and enjoy the huge tv. Or you may choose to look outside the window and marvel on Tokyo’s skyline. The facilities are basic yet complete. To give you enough energy for another day of walking and exploration, their buffet breakfast can nourish and satisfy you. I especially like the salmon, Japanese rice and salad. It is a bitexpensive compared to buying breakfast at the convenience store but the comfort, variety, and ambiance of the restaurant will compensate. It could have been great had they thought of putting iron inside the room. During my stay, no iron service is available. When I asked if I can borrow an iron, the receptionist gave me a map instead showing the place where I can buy an iron. Direct to the point. Overall, it was a worthwhile stay and will definitely consider booking again if given a chance to visit Tokyo in the future.

Just got into Tokyo. Notified in our booking that we will reach 10am, no issues were brought up with regards to early check in. But at the check in counter, we were told that we can only check in at 3pm and with every hour earlier that we be charged 1k yen. That’s bad service: 1) poor communications. 2) no management flexibility 3) monetizing our plight

I loved everything about the hotel. Nice and close to everything I needed. Staff were very helpful and accomadating.Room was clean and well maintained.Loved happy hour at the bar. Close enough to the train stations I needed. Close to shopping.

Trade off with room size but central location for us... the rooms are tiny, and the bathrooms are standard Tokyo style, meaning you get a small standing bath and shower over it, but let’s all be honest, your not going to be spending much time in your hotel in Tokyo. The location of the hotel is right by the cinema in kabukicho otherwise known as the red light district. It’s surprisingly quiet in the hotel after hours. Reception staff were friendly and helped us with Ta Q Bin luggage forwarding with ease.

I wish I could give 2.5 stars, because there were some issues with the hotel.While we did sleep well, there are some points for improvement. Firstly, we noticed after a few days that the room wasn't vacuumed or dusted during our stay. We are clean people, but dust happens.Secondly, we had a do not disturb sign up during one day when I wasn't feeling well and wtanted to sleep. They called the room to ask if we wanted it cleaned. What's the point of a do not disturb sign of they call you anyway? The second time we had the sign up, we weren't disturbed, but staff left a laundry bag with fresh towels and amenities at our door, which was perfect.We didn't use them however (we don't require a daily change of towels, environment and all that), and the next day staff left the bag awkwardly in the very small room, so we ended up with two pairs of towels/amenities. Since the room was already small, this took up unnecessary space.Our room was on the 22nd floor, but we felt the outside noise was more like we were on the 3rd floor. I was expecting some noise because of the area the hotel is in, but for a new hotel the sound isolation could be much better. We had no staff interaction after check in, except for the unwanted call. You get your key at a machine, you don't pass reception when entering and exiting the hotel, and you leave your key in a box when you check out.Having said that, our stay was not unpleasant. The beds were good, the water pressure was good and consistently warm, and the location is very convenient. I appreciated the laundry bag when we had the DND sign on, and we were able to leave our luggage at the hotel before the official check in time.Price/quality was not perfect, you mostly pay for the location.3 stars because of location, beds and bathroom. 2 stars deducted for cleanliness and calling because we had a do not disturb sign.

Very central on walking distance from Shinjuku station (take exit East).Although hotelrooms in Japan are always kind of small these rooms are really small. With 2 people and 2 places of luggage it is a real challenge. There is a nice public bath in the 28tv floor (for free). Lot's of bars; restaurants and conviencestores around so we did our breakfast selfcatered.

Great hotel, incredible location heart of kabukicho and easy walk to Shinjuku Station. The staff was very friendly and rooms were clean and well maintained. High security. Only downside is that the rooms were a little small which is to be expected as most things in Japan are small but beautiful.

If you want to be in the middle of Shinjuka's craziness and only a few blocks from what claims to be the world's busiest passenger station with overground and underground connections to everywhere this place is almost ideal. The room we had was so small you had to step out just to change your mind! For a couple of nights it was OK but for any longer we'd have needed a lot more space (I know, it's Tokyo, but we had more space on the aeroplane!).Despite being in the middle of Kabukicho- with all its interesting nightlife - it was very well insulated from any noise and the check-in was as slick as you'd expect in such a hi-tech neighbourhood.

Hotel is really good. It is close from major station(Shinjuku Station), brand new movie theater(TOHO Cinema), lots of Japanese style delicious restaurant, and has 2 convenience store around. Some reviewers said that the hotel locates inside the Kabukicho, famous night life area so it was not perfectly safe for personal and female travelers, talking their experience of being seduced by touts. However, Shinjuku Police also know they should pay attention to this area. While I stayed, I saw police man to patrol around hotel several time in one day so there is nothing much to worry about your safety. The room is bit small but extremely clean. Room service and attitude of employees are normal. The amenity is prepared well. My busy schedule hindered me to eat meals in hotel but many bloggers said the breakfast of restaurant in Floor 2 is not bad. But, the one thing annoyed me was owner of the APA Hotel brand. She was traditional type of narrow minded Japanese nationalist who believe that Japanese Empire was great and did nothing wrong in 20th century. Beyond having wrong faith, she is obsessed to propagate her wrong idea. She ordered to arrange books about seceret of her success and Japanese modern history. It is creepy and bothers Asian toursist, especially Chinese and Koreans who have delicate historical issue with Japanese.

Stayed at this hotel for two nights in late August, we paid around $130 per night for a nonsmoking, 1 double bed room on the 6th floor. We knew that the rooms were going to be small so we were prepared and had only a carry on and a backpack so we sort of manage moving around but it was tight. On the other hand, the room was super clean, had a wide window, TV, WIFI, fridge and bathroom (equally small) with strong pressure and plenty of hot water (beds and pillows were not the best though). One thing that I liked is that it was super quiet, I’m a light sleeper and I never heard the neighbors but it might be also that there is an AC portable unit on the floor which added a bit of white noise. Due to the size, the room really cooled down in minutes, and this was a relief during this year’s hot days. Based on the videos that I saw of rooms at this hotel, I think this is definitively one of the smallest rooms that most people complain about, but there are bigger rooms so just pay attention to what you are getting; we wanted to save $ so we choose this room and did not disappoint. The location is great as you are in the middle of the Shinjuku that you see in the pictures in 1 minute. I need to say that there is a plaza in front of the hotel and at least during the weekend there were a lot of drunk and completely wasted people (woman and man alike) and to my surprise, lots of trash in the street in fact, in our two weeks trip this was the only place where we saw this situation, of course everything was clean next day. We always felt safe and due to jetlag we went out for food very late after 1am and there were plenty of places open, we choose Ichiran Ramen and we were in and out super-fast. One other thing, we choose the Airport Limousine bus to get to this hotel from Narita, we did this knowing that we didn’t want to deal with the subway system, however, the ride was long maybe 1.5hours or more, it was OK for us as the bus was empty and we just slept the whole ride. Make sure you have a print out of google maps on how to get from the bus stop in Shinjuku west to the hotel; basically, when you get out of the bus, keep walking to the left as soon as you get off the bus walk for 5 minutes in which you will be passing other Shinjuku exits, you will get to an area under a bridge, cross this street, you can keep walking straight and pass the Shinjuku Cebu station then make a right. The hotel is really tall with a sign that says APA so keep looking up and you will find it. All in all, this was the least expensive option in the area so will stay here again only if I get a good price, it will be hard to pay more than $150 for a small room but I will be willing to pay that for one of the larger rooms.

The hotel is well located in the centre of Kabikucho and not too far from Shinjuku's station. (5 mins walk) However, the room is very tiny and if you have large suitcases, it will be very difficult to open them in the room and go through your stuff. The room was clean but the bed and the pillows were not very comfortable. We only stayed for a night but a longer stay would have been cumbersome.

The APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower is a high rise hotel in front of a big plaza. Affordable rate and near to a lot of restaurants, games buildings and malls. Shinjuku Station is about 7 minutes walk from the hotel. There is a Family Mart in front of the hotel where you can buy snacks like hot buns, sandwiches, drinks and a lot more. To get to the hotel from Narita Airport the fastest way is via Narita Express. RT fare is 4000 yen or about $39.00 per person which is best rather than one way only which cost around 6000 yen. The JR ticket counter is on the ground floor of the arrival area. Travel time is 1 hour and 12 minutes. There is no shuttle buses going to APA Hotel.My negative comments are the double room is best for a single occupant rather than for a couple. You can only stay on one side of the bed as the other side of it is by the wall with a small window and curtains. The bathroom has a small deep bathtub and the sink on the left side is somewhat low if used by a taller guest. The bathroom is elevated from the floor. There is a desk with a mirror and a chair next to the bed and one big mirror by the wall. The hallway going out is so small and if the luggage is open it’s hard to fix your things. Kind of really hard to move around. Overall it’s a budget hotel and near to a lot of places to walk around day and night.

Okay for a short stay. Rooms are. Dry small i can't even describe do not stay for longer than a few nights. Rooms were cleam. Got slippers and dressing gown every day. In a great !location near main stations.

We had air con issues...it’s summer....so you can imagine how hot we were. BUT! - this seems to be a problem as I’ve read other reviews concerning air con problems.The staff did not want to deal with it... so I have realised that this is to be expected once you are here. You wouldn’t have known. And you won’t until you go through it. But now you know guys. - So please be aware! Other than that, no complaints. Always remember you are entitled to things like a working air con in hotels when paying for it. Happy travelling.

Well located less than ten minutes walk from Shinjuku station and on the door step of Seibu Shinjuku station, this hotel is very modern and well appointed.Why are reviewers obsessed with the size of the room? If a spacious room is required in Tokyo go to the nearby Park Hyatt and pay. This is Tokyo.The check-in staff are helpful in English, the room cleaners very thorough and the clean bath-house/ sento an ideal place to relax after lots of sight seeing. Very well priced for what you get. I did not use the dining room as there are an abundance of small places that are authentic and interesting very nearby

APA Hotel is about a 10mins walk from Shinjuku JR Station. The location was convenient as it is surrounded by lot's of shops and restaurants. The room itself was very small, not much walking space and definitely wasn't enough room to store our two luggages, nor can we open our luggage flat on the floor (had to open a bag at a time on the bed). The bathroom was super small but otherwise clean.

Good locationVery small roomThey put us in a smoking room when we asked for non smoking. The hotel is nothing amazing. If u want convenient then it’s a good area, close many shops and restaurants. Basic and simple rooms with English speaking staffs.

Whenever I review a hotel I try and be as objective as possible. However, that said, this one is a shocker from a room perspective. Location is great. I am here at the moment :11 Aug to 16 Aug. If it was not so difficult to relocate hotels I would have done it. Furthermore, I am very upset as booking.com (where I made the reservation) gave a room upgrade option after I booked. They send an subsequent email with the option to upgrade.To explain, I originally paid 63,000 Yen for 5 nights. After modifying my booking the new amount is 71,000 Yen. Guess what- when I checked last night the hotel said there was no such option available and blamed booking.com! booking.com is yet to reply. Meanwhile, I have wasted 8,000 Yen. And get this, after I complained last night they said my room has a city view. What a joke. Take a look at the photo from the small window in my cell. I am in room 1123. Avoid it.

Good location. But things were not clean. Getting old and lack of professional maintenance. Bed were too soft due to long use on the bed. You could feel that the positions where people sleep were a lot softer than the other side. Room was usually very small. Hard to turns. 2 luggages will consume almost the entire space.

A great hotel overall. Staff were kind and friendly. Although the rooms where indeed small they still did a job for 2 of us. I really liked that there was an public bath located at the 28th floor. It was very relaxing after a long day in Tokyo. Unfortunately I couldn’t try the breakfast.
