review_body: Me and my husband travel to Japan in Oct. We booked a double room for 3d2n, the location is about 10mins walking distance from Shinjuku JR station. Room is tiny but clean, the view from room is quite nice, reception is very friendly. Family mart(convenient store) is just opposite, mcdonald is around the corner.Overall, i like this place, will book this hotel again when i visit shinjuku next time.

Clean, tidy, comfortable, modern and pretty new it seems (at least very fresh looking), and yet so affordable. It felt amazing to wake up in the comfortable bed, at such a central location. We couldn´t hear any noise from outside either! completely satisified with everything here

How to ruin your last 2 nights in Tokyo - Just stay here!On arrival the reception area was just like airport baggage claim with a small corridor through the bags to get to the check in desk as they have nowhere to store luggage if you arrive early. The cases are just left in main reception right by the main entrance, (Not very secure).Once checked in we went to our room and it was tiny. I know most Tokyo hotel rooms are small as we did stay in another hotel at the beginning of our trip to Japan, (Central Citadenes), but this has been designed for children. The rooms are not big enough for couples at all - especially if traveling with big bags. We were constantly getting in each other’s way and trying to sort out our luggage was a nightmare.And to top things off... No air con! Yes, there is a unit in the room but the cooling function is switched off. We complained at reception just after midnight on our first night and we were given a fan which helped a little but just blew warm air around. We complained again in the morning and they said it’s all centrally controlled working off the air temp outside. So if it’s cold outside then the air con units just blow warm air. And as the rooms are so small and there were 2 of us in there it soon got to a very uncomfortable temperature. As I have a Facilities Management background I know that the units can all be controlled from a central computer but the receptionist was unwilling to help. We asked to speak to the manager but she said there wasn’t one on at the time, we asked when will there be one on duty and she just repeated how the room conditioning worked. We asked again if we could speak to a manager... she then replied she was the manager so that didn’t help. It confused us just as much. Tip: Use the public baths to shower at night because using the shower that’s in your room will only increase the temperature more. The public baths are the only good thing, spotlessly clean and good to relax.The management response I will get to this will go on about how the room is designed for compact use and the air con is part of their eco policy in other words - cost cutting.To sum things up, the hotel is in a great location, handy for the station and seeing Tokyo but the tiny uncomfortable rooms and poor customer service are not worth the trouble. There are so many better places to stay in Tokyo for little price difference. You have been warned.

Terrific location near by shinjuku station rooms are small but we enjoyed all facilities are available in room and hotel.Family mart and seven eleven are down stairs opened 24*7I recommend to stay in this hotel

The size of the room was slightly unexpected for the price. The photos on Hotels.com make it look a bit more spacious.The onsen was clean, comfortable and well maintained. Amenities were plentiful and good quality.I paid extra for breakfast, and the buffet was a great selection and quite fresh. They have an espresso machine, but I was told espresso was not available for breakfast.I also paid extra for a "city view". I am now guessing that just means you are in a higher floor. The view from our room was of part of the city, but not the best direction. The view from the other side of the hotel was much better. On the 24th floor, all directions look out on some part of the city. I was quite disappointed in the view and would not recommend paying for it.

I have been two this hotel twice and will be visiting again in late November 2017. APA hotels were referred to me by a co-worker and the Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower has exceeded my expectations. I traveled twice with my boyfriend and we had such good things to say that soon I am returning with my parents so they can experience it. The location of the hotel is unbeatable! It is a short walk to the Shinjuku train stations, great bars and restaurants and shopping-you can experience so many things all within a short walk from the hotel. Traveling to a different country you do not always know how tidy it will be-this hotel is immaculate. There is always someone cleaning and hotel staff ready to help. Rooms are compact, but very functional. Each room has a good view which is great for pictures. No complaints on the bed and there is a large tv. The bathroom is great, crystal clean and has every amenity, included, that you could need (shampoo, hair ties, soap, Q-tips, etc.) I highly recommend spending the additional money and ordering the breakfast. I found finding nearby breakfast a bit difficult and having it downstairs is incredibly convenient. The food is tasty and they have a wide variety of food offerings. I do live in America and for lunch and dinner we eat local foods that I am not used to it is nice to start the day with a breakfast that my body is used to-cereal, eggs, toast. However, they offer local cuisine too and lots of it! Staff is great.I cannot wait to visit again in few weeks. Round 3! I HIGHLY, HIGHLY recommend this hotel- Have fun!

If you are looking for a place to stay that is in the city - extremely close to a variety of restaurants, public transportation, convenience stores, APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower is a great option!We spent a lovely night at APA during a stopover on our way to the United States and it was perfect for us. We were able to travel easily from Narita Airport to Shibuya Station, wander around town, do some shopping, have an awesome dinner, and catch a train to Shinjuku Station to check-in to APA Hotel.Later on, we wandered outside and had fun at the Games Center right next door and across the street, got delicious desserts from the Family Mart across the street and 7-11 a few steps down from the hotel.The room was admittedly small, but nothing surprising or unacceptable for large city hotels - we've stayed at multiple hotels with similar sized rooms in New York. The room was clean and comfy, amenities were complete, staff were friendly and extremely helpful, checkin and checkout was very quick and efficient.Our 4AM checkout was a breeze and we were able to travel from the hotel to Tsukiji Market for an early morning stroll before heading to Haneda Airport to catch our flight. It was perfect for us! Thank you APA Hotel Shinjuku.

Great two night stay at this Hotel. Clean comfortable rooms and facilities. Very nice breakfast. Close to Shinjuku Train Station and shopping areas. Short train ride to Harajuku and Shibuya for the worlds busiest pedestrian intersection. Nice restaurants in the area

Very happy with this hotel although from previous posts it's true the rooms are a bit of a shock at how small they are at first but they are completely functional if you just accept the quality and you get what you pay for.The rooms are very clean the bed is extremely comfortable the pillows are AWFUL may as well be non -existent !!! Hotel should look at giving an option of a bigger pillow maybe ??!! Check in was easy and the staff extremely efficient it is a really busy hotel and the lifts are TERRIBLE always packed and expect a lengthy wait most times .... I've never stayed anywhere where this is such an issue :(( no stairs as an alternative either ??Great there is a microwave and vending machine on 28th floor so handy ... Would not even go near the public bath seems really busy all the time !!!!!Breakfast was OK lots of options but suggest you get included in your room rate because of the cost if you don't quite expensive but most hotels the same ....Staff are lovely some with better English than others but will do anything to try help you or understand what you are trying to ask :)) cleaning staff very courteous and do a great job the toiletries supplied every day a great bonus !!! Razor, toothbrushes, sponges, cotton tips, shower caps and generous big bottles of soap, shampoo and conditioner supplied .The location is the main highlight this hotel is so handy with a couple of 7-elevens/Family Mart so close and great to all Shinjuku has to offer really .... Lots of places to eat close by I have nothing to compare this too in Japan but it is a nice place to stay it's functional and good enough for the rate. I had a pleasant stay ....

This was a pleasant stay in Shinjuku. The location is excellent for the station and for nightlife options. It is not seedy at all and is great for those looking for restaurants and nearby Golden Gai. The breakfast was good and filling, as was the onzen upstairs. The rooms are very small, even considering Japanese standards, but they have everything you need and just enough space for two people and two cases. I did find the price expensive for what it is, but the location made up for it. Shinjuku is definitely the place to stay in Tokyo, particularly if you are going as a group of friends or as a couple and want to be near the nightlife and action.

APA is a lovely hotel, with a beautiful onsen on the top floor however the rooms are rather small for western tastes, truly tiny. So if like us you are staying for just a couple of nights, it will do, but if you stay a while, maybe look for bigger space!

After reading the reviews about the size of the rooms i was expecting small.But seriously when you open the door and enter nothing will prepare you to actually realise how small the room is.I think some bathrooms in american homes are way bigger.I booked a double room even though i am a solo traveller and i found it cramp.2 persons in the room and there will be no room to stand.That being said...after i juggled around the chair i managed to open my big bag.No closet just hangers on the wall.A small fridge under the desk.Usual amenities like boiler,toothbrush etc.Double bed was against the wall facing a big tv up high so one has to look up while watching.Soft mattress and thin pillows but i found it just right for me.The futon was very nice.Aircon worked well and quiet.Room faced Shinjuku station but was quiet could hardly hear any soundCheckin was quick and friendly.Given keycard and then directed to auto machine for payment by credit card so have your PIN ready.Location is superb right in Shinjuku entertainment district so no worries about food and shopping 24hrs.A bit of warning though the atrium runs from a few floors up right to the top so its very high.If you have children take care because the barriers are not that high and can be climbed through.

This place must have been a prison as the rooms are like cells and the beds are small and uncomfortable. It is built around an open atrium from top to bottom, thankfully the suicide nets are still in place as we lost the will to live staying here. The staff are unhelpful, even to the point that they couldn’t book a taxi for us at 7.30am and we had to wait for one with all our luggage in the street. If you want to stay in Shinjuku stay try somewhere like the SunRoute East Shinjuku, bigger rooms, better price, more helpful staff and then just get a cab into Central Shinjuku itself.

Comfortable beds and quiet despite being in a busy location. The rooms were obviously tiny but functional. We thought the location was good. Only reason it hasn't got five stars is we found the staff quite unhelpful when we asked for help making a reservation (we couldn't do it ourselves as we don't speak Japanese!)...

APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower is located about 10 mins walk from Shinjuku Station. It is close to convenience stores and right next to the VR zone and vending machine games. Across the street are an abundant of restaurants with variety of food options. We stayed there for 1 night, booked a double bed room in 1025. Checking in was a breeze, passport scanned and details filled out. We were ushered to the check in vending station shortly (I’m guessing to validate our room card?) Only one room card was given. The room itself was small, and had a standard APA design. Not a lot of luggage space for the two of us. Amenities such as toothbrush, toothpaste, shower cap, hair band, cotton bud, razors were provided, and a conventional indoor robe and slippers were provided (for onsen upstairs). Air conditioning was our saving grace as it had been raining all day and our luggages and clothes were wet. WiFi was available but slow. Upon checking out, found out that in order to use hotel luggage transfer services to Narita, this required booking 2 days in advance. Overall average stay, may come again. Budget hotel anyway.

Room: Stay a Dbl Roomsmall & compact as its only 11-sq-meterfit 2 med size luggage anything more will have to jump from the bed.Price wise: ReasonableBed too SoftPillows too THINLocation:Great!next to Seibu-Shinjuku stationEast exit from JR Shinjuku & Bus Terminal to AP Shinjuku Station and walk north about 6 minutescheck out from you tube how to get to Gracery Hotel, its juz beside.Shopping:Don Quijote is 5 mins walk away (do not advise to shop at this as its very very cramp & limited items)Prefer the other branch (newly opened) which is 5mins walk away & 1 min walk away from JR Shinjuku.Lots of shopping centres surrounding which is walking distance.in Japan have to walk & walk... so yea cant really tell u how many mins to get there as too many shops along the way.Food:Ichiran is 3 mins walk awayLotsa of food eateries around the area Overall i am satisfied with the stay w the price i am paying for.

i stayed at this hotel 2 weeks,small room yes,thin pillows yes.some times the clean room inspector missed some dirt and dust in the after the room cleaning,i am a senior solo traveler,the check in was straight forward.My wife was trying to call me from canada,the hotel staff would not connect her to my room due to that she did not know my room number.she was told those are the rules,after sending e mails and telling the reception the booking number etc i was asked if i wanted to talk to my wife,every time my wife called i was asked if i wanted to talk to her.Some services depended on the attitudes of the person asked,some reception staff members were very helpful and had good knowledge of English.Particular the receptionist AL Sahara,she was very helpful and english communication was very good.Some staff on the reception had minimal knowledge of english.some times the service was inconsistent and inflexible.For me as a solo traveler the room size was ok,the room was comfortable, good value for the money

Room is really small. Had a high tech checkin and checkout machine which allocates your room after paper work is done. Next to bustling Shinjuku if night life is your piece of cake. Train station next to it is quite useless. It's not part of the main subway grid. Hotel is very particular about check out timing. They charge ¥1000 for every hour of late check out.

we stayed 4 nights here and thoroughly enjoyed our time here. Service was excellent, our room was compact but very clean and had everything we needed. The breakfast was brilliant with lots on offer, hot and cold western and japanese alternatives to choose from. Free toilettries were very welcome too. The hotel is just a short walk to the central Shinjuku attractions an Shinjuku station. Stay here and you won't be sorry.

APA hotel is know to have one of the smallest room in the market but also a lower rate. Which attracted tour bookings. This one is no exception. The room barely fit a bed, a small desk, a tiny fridge and a narrow pathway plus the very tight bathroom. The court yard is kind of interesting to see how this hotel was built with a lot of metal beans that join together. But the courtyard is actually exposed all the way to the roof, the building is kind of hallow in the center so there is no AC once you step out of your room. Did I say the room is really small?

The rooms were so small you had to go outside to change your mind. They were, however, functional. If sharing with another person the only way it can work is for only one to be moving around at a time. The room is equipped with the basic equipment and the bathroom is well appointed. Staff could be more helpful but patience would be stretched for anyone working in an environment such as this every day. The 3.00pm check in is also out of line with world standards. For stays of one or two nights it is ok, more than that it would be a stretch.

My boyfriend and I checked into this hotel for our first 3 nights in Japan and I'm so glad we did.It was easy to find coming from the airport as it is very centrally located in Shinjuku (look for Godzilla and you're sorted!). They allow for early checkin and it's charged at 1000 yen per hour (and so worth it when you've been traveling and need a nap!) Staff were very friendly and accommodating, check in/check out process was very easy - you can pay at a machine with credit card. There are loads of great places to eat nearby, along with entertainment/sights/transport! Room is definitely snug but has amazing city views of Tokyo skyline. Also has a fridge which is very useful!Thanks for a great stay! :)

We were on our way to Cambodia and had a 19 hour layover in Tokyo. The bullet train from the airport to Tokyo was very easy to use! Once in Tokyo, finding this hotel was a breeze as well. This hotel is in a great location, near all the night life, restaurants and shops of Shinjuku. The staff was very nice, and willing to help, which was a relief because we don't speak Japanese. To get to your room, you need your key card to access the elevators (another plus for me, because I knew no one that wasn't staying here was getting in). The room itself was awesome! Very clean and updated. The bathroom had all the amenities, including shampoo, conditioner, and body wash, which as someone who wasn't staying long in Tokyo it was nice not to have to pull out everything from our bags. The bed was comfortable, although the pillow was a bit non existent, it was more like a mat. In the morning we needed to get back to the airport, and it was raining. The staff at the desk, were generous enough to call a taxi and translate where we needed to go. Overall, our stay here was great! We would stay here again.

Just a few minutes from JR Shinjuku, this place was great. It seems to be brand new -- all amenities in the room were sparkling. HUUUUGE flat screen TV, nicely appointed unit bath, comfy bed, kettle for tea/coffee, etc. Other business hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo in this price range have been tired, stained and smelly, but this was great, and just steps away from the places I needed to go on this business trip.

This is a budget hotel and that is why I have rated it average and not poor. The rooms are simply to small for 2 people for any period of time and space could have been used in a better manner.So for example we had 2 suitcases and no where to store them. There is no wardrobe to put them in or on. Where if the bed had not gone to within 2 inches of the floor we could have put them under there because the bed base did go to the floor they could not be slid under the bed. Instead of a wardrobe there are two short metal rods sticking out of the wall each containing 4 hangers. The end was missing from one of these meaning that when clothes were on the hangers there was nothing to trap the hangers to the rod and they just slid off. Leaving 2 people 4 useable hangers.There is a really large Tv running most of the width of the bed. Far too large for the room the Tv could have done with being half the size and then some useful shelves could have been placed at the side of it to store items. The Tv only has BBC world service on it for free anyway all other channels need to be purchased.There is a tiny drawer in the desk but that has hotel books and hairdryer in. So basically all clothes etc had to be kept in the cases and then the cases lifted onto the bed each time items were required. The wall coverings were in a slightly tatty condition. And where the carpet met the wall was full of crumbs the entire stay. Bathroom was cleaned nicely though.The air conditioning ran either too warm or too cold and had to be adjusted every few hours.The worst part was that one person had to climb over the other person to get in and out of bed at night as there is only one accessible side to the bed.The rooms were not noisy though. Overall staying here did not ruin our trip to Tokyo but if we ever went again we would not stay again.

To start off, this is my 10 times in Japan and never had this experience. Upon check in, I told the staff that I have multiple bookings in the hotel for the following week as I'm travelling to Nagano and Nagoya after. I ask if I can leave my big luggage there, they said no overnight (all other hotels always allow me to do so as long as I'm returning after. Then I ask if they have self service laundry and they say no but is listed on the APA website. Then I ask them to call a restaurant to make a reservation for me, they also said no. What?! Even a hostel does this type of calling service. How can you tell me that a hotel like APA is not willing to call a restaurant for your guest. I'm so upset that I cancel all the remaining reservation at this hotel and will never come back!

Great location right in the heart of Shinjuku. Use the East exit from Shinjuku Station and walk north about 6 minutes. Lots of restaurants, department stores and bars, including famous Piss Alley within a short walk. The hotel is modern, and comes with all the amenities. But rooms are very small - think the size of a cabin on a cruise ship. It does have a gigantic 55" TV, but not many English speaking channels that are free. Rooms have bar fridge, kettle, coffee and toiletries. Strong wifi reception. 7-11 steps away for breakfast, snacks and beer. A great price for the location.

We stayed here for 9 nights, the hotel was fine, functional, but not more than that. We didn't really have anywhere to put our suitcases and stuff, ended up putting them outside the bathroom door which, by the last few days of our trip meant that we were literally climbing over our stuff to get to the bed. I'd wanted to do a basic gym routine while we were there but there was literally not enough room for a pushup. I'd recommend this hotel for a short trip but not loads

This APA hotel is located in the heart of nightlife in Kabukicho, just a 10 min walk to the Shinjuku Station. It's a great location, with plenty of nearby restaurants and shops, and only 5 minutes from the Robot Restaurant. The hotel's breakfast was very good. But my room was so small that I almost couldn't open my luggage! Still, I realize that it's a typical Japanese hotel and, overall, I thought it worked out pretty well.

I stayed here for 7 nights. Location is good. Some info- the laptop rental is only configured to Japanese. The staff said it cannot be changed to English. They told me this after I checked it out. It was a bit inconvenient since i had to go up and down to ask about it. They later phoned my room to aplogize and offer a refund. Not sure if the staff didnt know how to change language to English or it really is set to Japanese. The elevator can be slow at times. Wifi isnt perfect. Shower pressure was excellent as you can control it. So overall for price I paid (~70$ average) it was a pleasant stay and glad I stayed there.

Grand view from the spa.Great view from my room.Location is good - though his is the love district of Tokyo.Room are good. Sitcon - strong!However, my 3. Stay at a APA where there are bugs biting me.Wifi is so bad. I have to go down in the lobby. Here it is good. But takes time to go down there everytime.My suggestion - stay somewhere else or bring your own wifi and poison to kill bugs.

Very nice hotel, good service, friendly people. Room is cute good only for one Asian person. But complete of everything.Location is good also, ten minutes walk to train station, malls and restaurants.

I arrived after extensive transit delays and had missed my first night (out of two booked).Arrived to be told my reservation was cancelled and that my room had already been sold on.Had to pay an inflated price for an inferior room, as well as the two additional nights - total of three nights for one. No refund was given, at a loss to understand why I was charged double for the extra night.Avoid at all costs, very dishonest and dodgy.

We could not be happier with our choice to stay at APA Kabukicho Tower. We stayed for three nights and everything was lovely. We had a nice view from the 12th floor. The room was clean and efficiently cleaned each day. We were provided all the amenities one expects plus extras daily without asking, such as tooth brushes and tooth paste, razors, disposable slippers, q-tips, etc. The room was a bit small, but that was to be expected. Friendly, helpful staff. Easy access to all of Shinjuku, very close to bustling Shinjuku station. We certainly would love to stay here again. Thank you APA staff for a lovely visit.

Compared to similar modern hotels in Shinjuku, this hotel is cheaper and features better views. I had a 27th floor single room and it was a million-dollar view from my room. Bed was very comfortable. Shower had great water pressure and fancy toilet. Room size was small, but fine for one person -- no different than a small hotel room in Paris or London or New York. Onsen on the top floor was a nice amenity. Unfortunately, one would expect WiFi to work great at a modern hotel in the center of Tokyo -- not here! At times, I would get a normal 10-20 mbps speed, but mostly it was like 200-500k (i.e. dial-up speed). When I complained at reception, they said they would try and "restart the WiFi," but that didn't work (or they never attempted to do it.) Housekeeping was also inconsistent: some days they forgot to replenish tea or coffee, one day the remote control was hidden under the duvet, etc. But, nevertheless, good value-for-money for central Tokyo. Would stay again, but hope they would fix the horrible WiFi.

This hotel is nice but as you know japan beds are smaller than other country , staff very help full , they dont have a meeting room , so if you have to talk with someone you must go somewhere else since at the reception you are not really welcome to talk.

My partner and I had a great experience staying here. The location was perfect - short walk to the train station and surrounded by amazing shops and restaurants. The only downfall was that we arrived at 7:30am and weren't allowed to check into our room until 3pm. They allowed us to leave our bags in the reception area however did not have a bathroom - meaning we had to walk around a new city trying to find one as soon as we arrived.

Location was great !!! Rooms are big if you get the biggest room but for our kids room a double room it was super small which is common in Japan standard . Breakfast is always the same everyday, boring and not so enjoyable for what you pay for. Over all it was a good hotel, clean and you check out by just leaving the card key no fuss !!! And very safe hotel except that there were gay prostitutes outside the hotel who waits for customers. Disgusting . Perhaps hotel management can do something about it .

At first I was very surprised where I was going to end up in this Hotel, however, I have to say it was very clean, very nice in terms of how it is a very direct and technological service but still friendly. As well as the beds were very, very nice I have to say. Getting a good nights sleep here is very quiet and good. The rooms are quite small, but they are super clean and very practical, as well as the toilets are very nice with their Japanese flushes. Overall I recommend this place if you are looking to not spend too much and enjoy a fun atmosphere in Shinjuku, as well the metro is very close by.

This hotel has a very gracious staff. I was only there for one night, so I wanted to be in Shinjuku for my final night in Japan with access to all the glitz and zaniness that can be this part of Tokyo. My room was super tiny, but honestly, perfect for just me as a solo person with two bags, who uses her room to keep stuff safe and sound and to sleep well. Although small, the room was spotless and comfortable w lots of bath room amenities. I'd stay here again without hesitation. The bath on the top floor was an added bonus and a perfect way to unwind after a long travel day and before one final night in Tokyo. Easy walk to Shinjuku station and the NEX train service that takes you straight to Narita airport.

1, Terrific Location2, Five min walk from Shinjuku Station3, All amenities are there you just name it4, only the rooms are small no space for luggage but not much option for big rooms @ Tokyo5, i overall enjoyed my five days stay and will stay here only again in next trip. 6, Seven eleven, family mart and some bars just downstairs opened 24*7

The hotel's location is great, it's in the middle of shinjuku one of the famous areas in Tokio, with lots of restaurants, shopping and nightlife just stepping out the hotel. The shinjuku metro station is about a 5-10 min walk away. The rooms, however, are small, very very small, with just the bed fitting in and a small bathroom. There is almost no space for storing your luggage.But I guess that's what you will find in most of the hotels in Tokio.

Not a good place to rest after a long day of sightseeing in Tokyo.The room is so tiny you need to plan every movement in the room and no place for the luggage. If you want to go the toilet in the middle of the night and you are the unlucky person sleeping near the window you need to be an acrobat getting there without waking up you partner. The level of cleaning needs to improve, as there was a dusty feeling in the room. It was hard to breath in such stuffed room and hard to get a good night sleep with noisy AC, an uncomfortable bed and thin pillows. They don't put water in your room in the first night, even when we came a day late because of a flight delay. They fully charged for that night including the breakfast that we didn't eat but didn't bother to put a small bottle of water. The only good thing about the place was their breakfast buffet.

Location, location, location. It is super convenient with couple minutes walk to the JR/Metro/Odakyu line, you can also find everything you need like convenient store, nice restaurants...etc in walking distance. Rooms are small as usual, barely fit 2 adults + 2 large luggages; but clean and tidy. Self-service key collection is quite amazing.One thing to complain is that we stayed for 1 night, heading to Hakone and will return to the hotel for another 3 nights (which we fully paid in advance), I understand why they refused to keep our luggages but I hope they can offer some alternatives instead of saying "no" right to our faces.

Location is near to train station, about 5min walking distance. Hotel amenities are fully provided hence u dont need to bring your own. There's onsen in the hotel but not many people would go in there due to summer. A family mart and 100yen shops are opposite the hotel .. a good place to get what you want :)The hotel size is relatively small. The pillows provided are abit thin in my opinion..

The APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower is located in the heart of Kabukicho, 'The District that Never Sleeps'. The rooms as small, as are most hotel rooms in Japan, but the beds are comfortable and all the necessary amenities are provided - hairdryer, flat-screen TV, great shower/bath, kettle, alarm clock, etc... The hotel is walking distance from Shinjuku station, many restaurants and bars, the famous Robot Restaurant, and plenty of shops. Make sure to arrive before breakfast by the last seating (9:30 when we were there). The buffet breakfast had a good selection of Japanese and Western foods.Greta base for exploring Tokyo and the surrounding areas. We would definitely recommend this hotel!

Small hotel roomThe room is really small. We had two large luggages which we are not able to open up all the time. There will be no walking spaces if luggages are opened up. Although toilet is small, it is compact. One person can only use it at one time. Toilet is something like the plane toilet if you can imagine. Room serviceAPA don't really do cleaning. As you can see from one of my photos, there is dusts on the bed head board. The bed cover was dirty and not changed despite their policy says they will change if it is dirty. They recommended to go green to keep the bed linen unchanged if not dirty and will give guests a bottle of water. The pillow were laid the same position up right as before after room is makeup. Luggage storageThis hotel does not help to keep luggages overnight. We had to check out two days in between for fuji hakone, the hotel recommended a travel center to store our luggages at 500Yen per day. It is about 8 -10 mins walk from the hotel. LocationThe location is not too bad. It is 10 mins walk to Shinjuku station. We had to drag our luggages on the first day when we alight from yamanote line. But there are a lot of food nearby the hotel. Kabukicho is a red light district, therefore till midnight the streets are still filled with people. Many drunkards as the night gets later. ShoppingThere are many shopping centers. Lumine, GU, uniqlo, isetan, takashimaya, adidas, Don Quijote (24hrs), many drug stores, and many other brands. However Don Quijote and the drugstores are full of tourists. It's very packed which makes the shopping experience bad. Try go to other outlets if you travelled out. EatsLumine has lots of nice restaurants and cafes. Just one min walk away apa, there is a very nice ramen shop which soup base is fish stock. It's always long queue during night time.

Worst hotel I stayed in my entire life!Surprisingly least hospitable Water is not given on your first day of stay so guys take water with youThe AC in the room does not work...This being said the hotel is in a pretty convenient place close to the Shinjuku station

Located in the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku this is the k- car of the hotel world, does everything it says in the tin just smaller. If you're used to traveling around the size of the hotel room is below average to the point of being cramped if you have more than a backpack each. All the usual amenities are there and plenty of extras included in the bathrooms, things are just tight. The penthouse spa/onsen is also available to use for most of the day. If you're getting a hotel in Shinjuku to spend most of your time in the room you're there for the wrong reasons.

our room was small as expected and the bath was well appointed. But the beds were too big and occupied space that we would have liked for luggage and other uses. the air quality was horrible -- every time we returned the room smelled as though the cleaning staff had smoked in it. on top of not very good air quality in Tokyo this exacerbated a cold I had arrived with. It cleared up quite a lot as soon as we left Tokyo for Kamakura.The location was fairly good although taxis were frequently confused between this and another nearby APA hotel. I regret not using the onsen (bath) which was very popular with guests and looked quite nicely appointed. Loved the bathrobes that were changed every day. Saved laundry for sleeping clothes.

In a nutshell: APA Kabukicho Tower Hotel did not handle the fire situation correctly, and did not provide adequate information about the fire, nor did they voluntarily offer explanation or apology. My family and I stayed in the hotel early-mid June. On 6/9 morning around 7am, there was a fire on the first floor of the hotel. We first heard many emergency vehicles coming towards the hotel, and after about 5-10 minutes of hearing the first fire truck/ambulance siren, the hotel fire alarm sounded, instructed us to evacuate. We lived on the 26th floor (the hotel has 28 floors), and did not want to risk taking the elevator. My family and I encountered three other guests, and we fought open the emergency exit door to go down the stairs outside. The staircase is pretty narrow so everyone lined up to descend the stairs one by one. To some extent it prevented some possible elbowing, but the one-man line makes the descending process a bit long. As we reached closer to the ground, I saw two firefighters exited the hotel from a separate staircase to the hotel restaurant on the second floor. When we reached the ground, I saw fellow hotel guests stood frightened and disheveled in the little plaza in front of the hotel. We were herded right back inside the hotel as the hotel staff said the situation was resolved. Nothing else was said. No explanation or apology was given. After the family trip, I emailed the hotel expressing my concern about the situation and asking for explanation. Due to Tripadvisor restriction on reviews, I cannot post quoted material, so let me rephrase the hotel's response as: We are sorry for the inconvenience, the cause of the fire is unknown. The last two lines of the email reply were even in a smaller font size. No one signed the email. (Knowing a bit about the Japanese work culture, words not in the same font size and no signature in a business letter are just not allowed, not to mention the grammar mistakes) I sincerely do not feel that they took my email seriously. The thing that bothered me the most was not the email nor the attitude, but the way the situation was handled at the start of the incident. The very first thing the hotel staff should do after noticing the fire is activating the fire alarm immediately, NOT AFTER ALL THE EMERGENCY VEHICLES HAVE ARRIVED. This procedural misconduct I have to point out, is unbelievably dumb and scary. Seeing the London apartment fire in the news today, I feel very lucky that the fire I experienced was quickly contained. I hope the hotel could read my comment in a serious manner, and improve their emergency SOP to ensure the safety of their future guests.

We spent two nights here in May and the only reason I rated it 4 stars was probably the size of the room. Much smaller than any cruise cabin :). Our bed was against the walls/window on three sides, so I had to climb over. Anyway it didn't prove to be a huge problem and actually gave us many laughs. The room had everything else expected of a good hotel room, including slippers, robe, many bathroom amenities and of course the free Onsen on the top level. Bed was soft and comfortable, pillows too flat for us, but were soon provided with another when asked. Location is excellent. Breakfast was more than enough. A strange thing though was that we didn't read the sign which we'd placed on our door correctly....thinking it was simply a 'make up my room sign', but it turned out to be the opposite, so were surprised when we returned late in the day to find the bed unmade....our fault, though bath towels had been changed and water bottle left. Staff at front desk were obliging and spoke enough English. Check out is a simple drop off of the keys in a box. Would definitely recommend this hotel.

Yes the room is small but what do you expect for Japanthe room was clean new towels & toiletries everyday even waterits in an ideal location 5min walk to station7-11 & family mart right on the door step so was able to stock up plus with the fridge in the room we stored snacks etcthe only downside was no safe in the room

Double bed room small however it's the same everywhere. Clean and well presented. Spa/ bath area is segregated and absolutely amazing, clean and refreshing. Lovely smelling toiletries provided.Hint is to google etiquette on' Onsen Bathing/ public baths ' as it helps your confidence and we didn't want to offend anyone. The difficulty we had was to find English speaking staff. Staff appear well presented and so very polite and courteousClose to food, shops and train station Able to leave bags at hotel upon returning keys, very helpful thereTwo large bags fit in room standing lengthways. Two Travel bags will fit in at end of bed

Japan is known for their small rooms so no surprises here. But rooms are very clean, quiet and comfortable. Toiletries supplied are fantastic (especially the body wash) have everything you need, even a hair tie. Staff are very friendly and helpful and speak great English. Location is right in the middle of things, walking distance to Shinjuku station, restaurants, bars and the bright lights. Highly recommend

We went to APA Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower for our last days in Tokyo. The best thing about it is the hassle free check in and check out, also the centre location in Kabukicho. It's surrounded with fun Sega centres, restaurants, bars, and even a batting centre. However it is a bit of a walk from JR Shinjuku Station, which makes it a little bit inconvenience to walk with a big suitcase. Seibu Shinjuku Station is only a couple of mins walk but you have to change to the private line. The room is very, very small - we had the double room. Barely any space for two of us, let alone to open the suitcase. There's a public bath upstairs that is very nice, which is a plus. The place is great for one person travelling, but the room may be too small for two, let alone a family.

Stayed here for 7 nights in May. The hotel is about a 10-15 From Shinjuku station East exit. Check in was very easy the language barrier was abit hard but they do try to accomdate you as best they can. The room was very small however I didn't expect anything more for a hotel in the big city. The bed was very comfortable however the pillows were that great. The hotel provides some handy items like hair ties, bath sponge and water every day. This hotel is close the public transport, restaurants, shopping and gaming centers. I can definitely recommend this hotel for your stay.

Clean place, easy payment upon check in which is done thru automatic machine where you can get your door card key, friendly frontdesk officer, very near to restaurants, temples and other bars in shinjuku.

Previous to my review of 16th May we were offered another room the next morning which should have been offered, better still, given a room to accomodate 2 persons not 1. First night was spent trying to sleep in a chair after approaching reception at midnight to no avail. Day staff most helpful. Room was clean and bed was comfortable so last 2 nights were good, felt we should have been given a complimentary night to compensate but otherwise good and close to station, restaurants etc. would consider staying again providing the room was a decent size and comfortable bed.

It is unhygienic.The Vomit Smells from the Carpet made me sick.The staff was rude and refused to help me to book any restaurant and said it is company policy without further explanation. I never have such experience before in any hotel in Japan. This is the worst experience

The hotel is so well situated. Metro and JR stations nearby.2 Convenience stores just outside the hotel. Next to the hotel is an amazing eating place with delicious food and also movie theatre. Now about the tiny room. The double bed was cornered against the wall which is very inconvenient. I think these rooms are for one person with hand luggage only.My husband and I juggled with the tiny room. On the other hand the TV was huge but with only one English news channel.The bathroom on the other was small but clean with a powerful shower, good toilet and very good shampoo, soap and hair conditioner.The check in and out was easy. The staff had problems understanding English.We travelled in April so the price of the tiny room was high.Wi fi good.The location of the hotel is very good. Close to good eating places. They stored our baggage because our flight was very late in the evening and the check out time was 11am.

Good condition,service,reasonable price❤❤ near train station Near korean street that you can have foods&drinks all night long. Not far from Shinjuku near shopping area ...I will visit this hotel again if I go next time... only thing I don't like about this hotel is the pillow too thin for me.

Yes it is small but we don't stay inside much so it does its job. I saw other rooms which was slightly bigger so I am sure if you want bigger roons it is available but it will just cost more. Clean bed, and washroom. Flushlet toilet. Love the shampoo, cond and shower gel..oh they were so soft!They even have disposable sandals for you.There is a TV and despite small room, you get a table and chair, great for ladies to use for make up.Free wifi does its job.Staff is friendly and spoke English quite well. They also allow you to store luggage on check out which is greatly appreciated! Location is convenient, leisure walk is probably 10 mins to the scramble, heaven of shops, eatery, and metro/JR station. Quiet at night,The only thing you have to prepare is, if you have lots of luggages it will be a challenge going from main shibuya metro/jr to the hotel. I believe there is another metro stop close by but I forgot the name, maybe use that metro station if u cone with lots of luggages. Reasons are: Shibuya Jr has NO escalator or elevator for their exit!!! (Not sure about metro). You will need to carry your heavy luggages up and down flights of stairs but thank God there are not too many of them. Then, from the station to APA is an uphill battle. We had only one luggage ~ 35lbs each person and by the time we got to the hotel, we sweat like a pig :) maybe a taxi is a better idea.Overall, it is a great stay with no trouble.

So it's a little small, but it's right in the heart of Shinjuku. The train station is 5 minutes away. Easy check in and out. Plenty of facilities close by. Rooms were clean and soundproof. Good hotwater. Bed was comfortable. Could have used a better pillow.Staff were polite. Easy check in and out. Easy to find.Overall, would recommend and would stay again.

I realize for the location (fantastic in the heart of Shinjuku and Tokyo in general is expensive) the price was great, Shinjuku station is close, convenience store right out side, and while small the hotel has money exchange and some convenient amenities...HOWEVER, the room is incredibly tiny even for its standard. Had I Known I would've upgraded more or stay elsewhere for 2 of us, it was barely doable and I literally fell on my husband trying to escape the bed and I'm not a large person! I've stayed in tiny rooms but this is tiny! The small nature of the bathroom didn't bother me too much actually, it was clean and modern but it was the rest of the living space especially the way our double bed was cornered against the wall so every time I would have to hop over my husband if I needed to get out of bed. I'm usually not easily deterred by the foreign country's standard of size but I don't think I can ever repeat this size for 2 people.Surprisingly the room was quiet.I could recommend this hotel only for singles or couples looking for cheap option in the heart of it all. The location was absolutely great because we walked everywhere in Shinjuku.Also, I would like to comment on those concerned about the location. The red light district isn't that far but you need to keep in mind that is part of Shinjuku, Shinjuku is huge, Shinjuku has a ton of shopping and restaurants as well...so if you aren't looking for the hustle and bustle perhaps you shouldn't stay in Shinjuku altogether.Great fine shopping and restaurant options within walking distance. The best element other than the convenient location would be its breakfast. I think the price was great considering it included daily breakfast, while small it provided fresh and diverse options to grab before heading out.

We stayed here sight unseen. I must say that the staff were all friendly, spoke English and check in was painless and managed through a combination of reception and a stand-alone computer terminal check-in station (used a lot in Japan).But...it is small, super small by western standards. I am talking about 10 to 11 square meters!!The bed head is up against the wall at one end and the foot of the bed is up against at the other. The room is about as wide as 2 double beds. The air-conditioning system switches off at night but the fan keeps blowing so it can get a little stuffy in the room.If you don't mind or are a single person staying here then OK as it is a lot cheaper and has an awesome location. We stayed for 2 nights but got stir crazy and went over to the Gracery (5 mins away) because we just needed the bigger room.You can't unpack so you need to put your case on the bed take out what you want and close it up and stand it up against the wall again.No other complaints with the place.

If you're going to Japan and expecting a large room you're in for a shock! Tokyo hotels in particular don't have rooms you can lounge about in, they're for sleeping only! Bed was comfy although the pillows left a lot to be desired (flat and rock like). APA Hotel Shinjuku was the perfect location for us being about a 10 minute walk to the JR train station and in the centre of Shinjukus eateries and nightlife. Breakfast was quite average unfortunately even though there was a big spread (food was often cold).

Perfect location, close to everything, less then 10 min walk to Shinjuku train station, and tours stop. Very quite hotel, rooms are very small except if you book 2 single bed double room non smoking (be aware smoking room very strong smell). Room are super clean. Changing sheets, towel and robes every day even if you put the do not disturb sign on the door. They leave the clean pk in front of room door. The only complaint is the elevators. Oh my, make sure you get out early, other way U will be waiting more then 15 to 20 min. Busy, busy and super duper slow. Everything was perfect for us except the elevators during the busy time from 9:30am to 1pm.

review_body: Hotel room was very small! No closet to hang clothes. However, room was very clean and well sanitized. Outside the hotel, ambiance is not so great. I wouldn't recommend if you want to relax and get a nice view from the hotel. Shinjuku station is a far walk. Overall, my stay was fair enough. We got the room cheap, less than$100 a night and only stayed for 2nights as we had to go to Nagoya and Osaka.

Ok... lets get this out first... YES the room was small but we were there just to sleep!Everything you need is available, very clean, bed was very nice, staff friendly and very helpful.Ok some of the "Trainees" were not fluent in english but between my poor japanese and their english we got to fix things perfectly!The location is great and we really enjoyed our stay with my wife.Would for sure come back!Thanks again!

This hotel is in the heart of KABUKICHO in Shinjuku. It is right next to the Gracery Hotel (Godzilla Head). It is within walking distance to (Robot Restaurant, Alice in Wonderland Restaurant, Cat Cafes, Toho Cinemas, just to name a few). The rooms are very tiny however this is expected for Japan. Compare them to a cruise cabin. The hotel provides all amenities (tooth brush, tooth paste, razor, hair brush, shower caps, toned, slippers) you name it. The pillows are not that great I must say but you walk so much in Tokyo that once you hit the bed you fall asleep and don't really notice the pillows. I had breakfast included and it was good but they don't change the menu and after the 4th day I just could no longer eat the same. There is a 7-11 right across the street and you can purchase some breakfast items and coffee there as not many places open early. There is also a McDonald's about 3 minutes away if you must. All in all I really recommend this property. Very nice staff, easy check-in and check-out and they all spoke English.

The Apa Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower Hotel was in an excellent location - a short walk from Shinjuku station (very easy to find) and right amongst a great variety of restaurants and bars. Check in and check out were both very easy and staff were particularly friendly. The room, whilst typically small, was modern and very comfortable with many amenities. It was great to have the onsen on the top floor of the building! Breakfast was good with a wide variety of food options. This hotel was excellent value for money - I can confidently recommend it.

We stayed at the APA Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower for 7 nights. The whole stay was very good value, one of the cheapest for the dates (end of April). The location is amazing, 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station where you find all the connections to pretty much anywhere in Japan and Tokyo (including airports). The room was extra small but you don t expect much more in Tokyo. The room was clean, products in the bathroom are available and very convenient (toothbrush, razor kit, cotton tip...) and filled up everyday if you use them. 2 minutes to one of the busiest area in Tokyo, but in the meantime the room we were in was surprisingly quiet. When we checked in we went to the wrong hotel (many APA hotels in the city) it was pouring rain, the receptionist at the other hotel offered us assistance, a dry towel and umbrellas !

review_body: You should go on the top floor ! Why ? It is the spa !! Really good after a day at work !You should be naked ( I know it's can be a problem for some people) but girl and boy are separate. The bedroom is small but the tv is soooooooo big ! Good place but night time little be "hot" not good for family after 10pm Legroux Romain

The location is perfect, very clean rooms, easy check in. Main disadvantage - rooms are quite small, but I guess that's normal for Japan. There is pretty good free wi-fi in the rooms. However, I was surprised to find out that they do not have a toilet in the lobby.

The location is good. Rooms are a bit small but comfortable and equipped. The common pool at top is very good. Hotel payments are machine automated and caused us an initial scare. Missed a cupboard which could have helped keep the bags inside

When we checked in, there were flyers on the desk offering upgrades to Large Double Room. The staff assured us that was what we had already booked and paid for. So when we entered the minuscule room we burst out laughing, trying to imagine a less than large double room. We couldn't. We were two, each with one large and one carry-on size suitcase. Positioning them, and us, took some Tetris skills, and a little dance whenever one of us needed to visit the bathroom or move anything in general.That aside, if you're a single person with small suitcase, I'd recommend this place. The prices are reasonable, and the location excellent. A few minutes walk from Shinjuku station, countless bars and restaurants, as well as shopping.

The rooms are minute. Even small for Tokyo and the staff seem only interested in getting people in and out. Breakfast is average at best.The location is okay, but is in the heart of the red light district so unless you're into that type of thing avoid.Wifi is also so slow you cannot use it.Rather look elsewhere

My family of 4 just stayed 4 nights at this location. I did a lot of research prior to our trip with the understanding that rooms are small in Asia. I decided to book 2 rooms with each adult rooming with a child. I had requested rooms next to each other or on the same floor but when we checked in we were on different floors. A bit inconvenient but having 2 bathrooms makes up for that. The rooms are very small with barely enough room for 1 suit case. Since we were there as tourist and spent all day outside it did not bother us. The rooms are clean and the bathrooms are filled with basic necessities like toothbrush, toothpaste, hairbrush ,etc. I love the Shiesido hair and body products. The location is so convenient. 2mins to the Seibu Shinjuku line or 8mins to the Shinjuku JR line. The underground walkway to the JR line is full of shops and restaurants. The area around the hotel is line with restaurants, bars, arcades, shops and entertainment. We took walks around the Shinjuku area each night and always find something new. We would stay here again bc of the location.

convenient, but better not walk around finding the hotel alone / with gals only, at night, cos of the district issue, not very safe feeling. The room is small, very small, even in Japanese standard, real small, the smallest i've ever been in. belive me, i've been in quite a number of other hotels, incl ones in Shinjuku, Tokyo, too. Bad pillow, can't imagine it's like a piece of paper. (semi double room) need to queue for the counter for check in, and then u won't get your room number. Need to go to the machines to generate your own room number afterwards. Wonder why the hastle.

Stayed 5 nights in a standard room with my 6 yr old twin boys.Room was very clean and stylish with all the amenities needed for an international traveller.Breakfast was included in our stay which was well worth the extra dollars as the array of food offered in the buffet breakfast was amazing.To be expected though the room was very small especially for two people.Location wise was very central to everything including 5min walk to Shinjuku JR station, supermarkets and restaurants.

ProsCentrally located in TokyoNear JR stationNear Shinjuku StationIn the middle of Shinjuku areaRestaurant or eateries are within a walk awayCustomer Services - staff were friendly and helpful however still a challenge communicate in EnglishConsAverage hotelPriceySmall roomNo laundry facilityOne tv station with English available Hard to catch a cab A walk to the subway station with luggages, you better flag a cab from there

We stayed 8 nights in this hotel. For 2 persons, our room size was only 11 square meters. Though small, everything that we needed were provided in room, no complaints. I must add the bed and pillows were extremely soft and comfortable. We stayed on the 27th level, and you have a bird's eye view of Tokyo city skyline from the window! The awesome onsen is on the 28th floor and I would strongly recommend it. The hotel reception staff were friendly and spoke English. Much has been said about the location being in a red-light district. However, we felt quite safe moving around since we were not the night-fever people. Hotel is conveniently located near Shinjuku station, just a short 10 minutes' walk. There are many shops near locality, including Isetan, Uniqlo, Kinokuniya, all within 10 minutes' walk.Overall, it was a satisfactory stay and we will stay again for future visits.Just a note though, if you are big in size, to evaluate the floor area of the various types of rooms to see if size is acceptable to you before booking so you will not get a 'shock'. Keep in mind your luggage size as well! Once you are prepared mentally, you should be able to enjoy your stay :D Think twice also if you are going to spend a great deal of time in the room. Otherwise, it is a great hotel for singles/couples/those who need a nice place to rest after their outings!

For those of you who comment it is claustrophobic and small, that is the norm in Japan (particularly Tokyo) - unless you stay at one of the top star hotels. These rooms were roomier than others I have stayed in (APA in Takasaki, for example!) This APA has a fun neighborhood and is convenient and secure, with a nice breakfast - breakfast starts at 7 but great coffee in the 7-11 in the Square if you are up at 5 am. Downsides - on the top floor I was on, the Internet was ABYSMALLY SLOW. My goodness. I nearly missed an appt because the map would not download. I had to go to McDonald's. Don't be fooled by the high bars. It's not very good.There are 'flat as a pancake pillows' and a secret stash of nice, fluffy pillows. They should just change them all out. Request the fluff!

the policy of the hotel that not having family more than 3 persons in a room we booked for 5 nights and we came from long flight and came late night so we was very tired we have 2 kids and that means the parents will separated in 2 rooms each one of them with one child so this is not for family it is for solo travelers and the room was tiny i think one person will not be comfortable all APA hotels are same and really it is tank room not for humans even there are no cabinets or space for the luggage. Do not stay in this chain of hotel if you are tourist and couples or family this hotel not suit you even if there location is the best.

Out of Shinjuku subway, it is about a 10-minutes stroll down to the APA Hotel. Plenty of shops to visit which are within walking distance though most would be in malls.After checking in late at night after the flight, Shinjuku station is situated further away from the airports. The room was pretty small in size, however for most parts sufficient for 1-2 pax. Not much walking space from the door, with the bathroom immediately at the side of the entrance.The room does has curtains however my room was facing the hospital if correct and in the morning the sun rises from this direction. At that moment, sunrise was about 4am which is truly a scene to see though it would not be the best if you are looking to sleep through the morning as the room fills with light soon after. However i was on the higher floors (26 if i remember correctly), and the bird-eye view from above is truly beautiful that includes the sunrise. With the contrast from a quiet morning town to a bustling nightlife city, while enjoying the onsen (hot springs) the hotel provides.There are small shops selling food which some are definitely worth trying, and there are a host of shops near that sell a large variety of IT products and a printer brand shop that still sells the previous generation of supplies not found much else where as referred by a friend.Through my 5 days stay, it was an enjoyable stay as i did not require much space for my luggage fortunately. Would recommend for its location (although the red-light district is nearby which does come alive at night that is worth visiting once but that would not be family/kids friendly)

I wish I've done my research better before booking this hotel. The rooms were a joke. There was no space for both of us to stand up at the same time. The room was so hot at night because the temperature is controlled centrally, and we had no control at all over it. The breakfast was bad, not worth paying for it.The only good thing was the location.I will never ever stay in this hotel again.
