review_body: This hotel gave us a good starting point in Tokyo. Being close to the city's biggest and most trafficked train station, Shinjuku Station, we had no problems with getting around Tokyo, to and from the Narita Airport, and doing some trips outside the city. This hotel is located close to some shady areas; keep in mind that Shinjuku is also host of Tokyo's most famous red light district. But nonetheless, we were never bothered by it and the area is actually quite nice with the big Godzilla themed cinema right next door, the great many small restaurants scattered about (some good, some the opposite of that), the arcades and the many, many lights, all over, brightening every alley and street and flashing in all the colours of the rainbow. The room we stayed in was a double. It just had room for one crammed in bed for two, a small desk, and the tiniest bathroom I've ever seen. Let's just say you could sit on the toilet, wash your hands and have your feet in the bathtub all at the same time, it was so small. But all in all, the room had everything we needed but a hairdryer. In need of a hairdryer then? Take a visit to the traditional Japanese baths at the spa on the 28th floor, where you can both shower and wash yourself, take a scolding bath outside or inside (I recommend the outside tub) and dry your hair. Take note; you're expected to be naked from top to bottom here and there are some strict rules against people with big tattoos, as they'll be thought to belong to the Japanese mafia (Yakuza). We lived on the 25th floor facing west, and the view was magnificent. The breakfast at the hotel was overpriced,we could agree on. It wasn't great and eating out at better places like Le Pain a short walk away was cheaper. The staff was very nice and helpful, always ready to be of assistance. Everything was clean and there were no bugs or anything like that to speak of. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone who wishes to travel affordably, wants a central starting point for their Tokyo adventures, and who can live with a living space that's smaller than your average bus.

There is no getting away from the fact that the rooms here are TINY. The bed head and foot were the exact width of the room, there is space to put any more than carry-on luggage and no wardrobe (couple of hangers on pegs). No ironing facilities in the hotel, but there are trouser presses available to borrow. No view at all - the reason that they left the curtains drawn - we looked straight onto a wall.Yet, everything in the room works, including the free wifi.Rooms are set around an uninviting dark courtyard, with netting across the void on each level, in exactly the same way as a prison. Breakfast was mediocre and over-priced. The area is lively but rather seedy - locals we met later in our stay used the word 'dangerous'. Of an evening, there are lots of men hanging around the streets, who constantly (and tediously) approach single men to invite them into meet girls in their bars.Once you know the way, it is a quick 5-10 minute walk to Shinjuku station and all the transport options this has. Staff were pleasant but not overly helpful - even assisting us to get a taxi at the end of our two day stay was not possible. We had always planned to stay here for a couple of days before moving to a hotel in another district, and on reflection as long as you are near Tokyo's fantastic transport infrastructure there is no need to stay here. There are certainly better hotels for the money.

We loved this hotel, and it's super convenient location. Staff were friendly and willing to help. Wish they had more English speaking front desk staff though. Great service, otherwise! The rooms were small, like most hotels in Tokyo. But this was fine with us, we had an enjoyable stay!

Loved it here. Was about 130,000 yen for a week stay. Staff was friendly and helpful. There is a money exchange in the lobby along with several vending machines. Accommodations were as expected, very nice and small. There is a bath house upstairs, but no tattoos allowed, so I couldn't go. There is an arcade right next door, and a "square" right in front (sometime they have festivals in front) but the hotel is in a great location. Very close to everything, but not right in the middle so it's not crowded. Located right next to the Big Godzilla Head, several convenience stores, Sega Arcade, and restaurants. I would stay here again.

-10 mins walk to the Shinjuku JR station- standard room is small but acceptable- clean and tidy- bottled water only provided for visitor who has a longer stay and requests not to change the bed sheets etc. for a environmental friendly reason- big public hot bath is provided at 28/F- hotel staff are helpful

in the middle of Shinjuku where you have everything close to you including the metro station and restaurant , do miss robot restaurant very close and some nice shops , some places not good for kids, it might not be OK for some families

I have never heard of this Japanese select service hotel brand before, but have seen some good reviews and decided to give it a try. My husband and I were aware that rooms in Tokyo were small, so we purposely picked accommodations suitable for two. Boy, was it tiny! Two of us couldn’t use the same space at the same time. For instance, we had 2 carry-ons and there was no space for them; I am not sure what people with full size luggage would do. While we had everything savvy travelers are looking for (a clean room, high speed Wi-Fi and the ability to purchase breakfast on premises), it felt impersonal (remote?). Our stay was lacking some emotional connection from the staff. The check-in desk is tucked in far from the entrance and when you come in and out of the hotel there is no one there to greet you or even have any eye contact with. While this hotel did not meet our ‘touristy’ expectations, it would be perfect for a single business traveler.

Convenient location with fair value, the room is ultra small in which not much space left with two luggage placed in the room. Not much service and the cleanliness needs further improvement. Not even a guest toilet at the lobby..it's inconvenient for guest who has an early arrival after a red eye flight.

This is a safe, clean, and friendly hotel in the busy night life district. Staff speak/understand English and are helpful. Breakfast was adequate and a nice add on. Location gives this hotel a 4. The room size is minimal and very tight for 2 adults. Bathroom is very efficiently laid out and feels like an inside cruise cabin. Bed is very comfortable, but pillows must not be a normal part of Japanese hotel as it was like a foam bath at. Our view was nonexistent and you could hear street noise until 2am and birds and workers at sun up.

Having stayed here for two weeks, I think I can give a fair impression of this hotel.The rooms are tiny, but this is quiet normal for Japan - they are clean, you just can't swing a cat.The food is unusual, runny eggs on a pizza and a can bar, where the serve various flavors of spam and seal curry! You cant sign to the room either, which was a pain to be honest, I always needed to carry cash.Lifts are a pain too, it took me 10 minutes one day to get from floor 44 to the reception.Great location for the Makuhari Messe, a good 30 mins train from Tokyo City Center.A strong 7/10 for this hotel, its just a tad wired - but hey, your in Japan!

This is a well located hotel. < 200m from JR Shinjuku station and next to the Godzilla cinema. The hotel is 28 floors - upper rooms very quiet. The rooms are small - we were struggling a bit with our 2 suitcases and no hanging space. Would stay again.

The location of the hotel is perfect when you stay in Shinjuku. It is clean and the staff is very helpful. But the room is very tiny, not much space to move around when we were 2 persons with luggage.

If you are after the Tokyo nightlife experience and want a clean, safe hotel in the area, then this is the hotel for you. And no need to read any further.If you are not, as I apparently was not, then read my review and take it into consideration.The location is very continent, easy to reach as there are three train stations in easy walking distance. But if you are not specifically interested in taking an active part in the Shinjuku nightlife, there really is no reason to stay here specifically.. The hotel is OK, the rooms are Tokyo Style SMALL, but they lack the overall design ingeniousness I have found in other similar sized hotel rooms. The overall feeling was a bit too dark and oppressive. And I missed the "Japanese" finesse and attention to detail and customer. I guess it caters to the young party crowd looking for a good deal in the right location. As that was not me, I can't really find fault. But next time I will explore options in another area.

Choose this hotel by searching via internet and found this hotel located in very busy street. Although the location is in the middle of busy street you will feel convenience since this hotel close to shinjuku station, restaurants,bars. The room is suitable and clean . Highly recommended.

Just know that you don't get service here. It's dreadful service. Scrap that, NO service... I asked at the front desk whether they could help me book a table at a restaurant that evening. They refused and suggested I either return to my room to call the restaurant myself and pay the phone fee, or go to a tourist centre to ask for help (then they handed me a pamphlet for a tourist center). Of course I called the restaurant who didn't speak a word of English. Terrible/No service - I have gotten more help at a McDonalds.

Stayed in early March. Room 207. Okay for doubles but small room is more for single traveler. Window looks out into alley so, no traffic to worry about at night. Typical city noises but not impossible to fall asleep. The staff was good although I had very little interaction. When checking out, you just deposit your room key so you don't need to check with the front desk.They offer breakfast for about $6 more but looking at the prices, it would seem to have been cheaper to pay upfront. You have a choice of American, Japanese, or Chinese style. Coffee is complimentary as are other drinks.Television has only one English speaking channel.

The APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower had everything I needed for my trip to Tokyo. It is affordable, and comfortable. The rooms are small, but the views of Shinjuku are breathtaking. The amenities provided are of great quality, and it has public baths for guests. The pillows are not the best. The hotel location is perfect for going out at night without worrying about the subway closing and having to pay for an expensive taxi. It is at a walkable distance form Shinjuku Golden Gai and there are lots of fun places to go to in Shinjuku Kabukicho.

The hotel is at bottom end of Shinjuku but it is still a good place to be. It is only ten minutes walk from the station and it is separate from the neon and bustle of the restaurants, shops, cinemas and night spots. The staff is super friendly and helpful which I have found is standard for all of Japan's hotels but it's still nice. The check-in/check-out can be done by machines and this is always convenient. The rooms are relatively small but this is also standard for Japanese hotels. The rooms are very neat and clean with all the mod-cons.The onsen on the top floor is excellent with spectacular views of Tokyo. Safe and secure systems of entry and use of elevators.

Whilst not right in the middle of Shinjuku, the walk to Kabukicho tower from the station was easy and their was handy access from the square outside. Check in was a really simple process and the staff were friendly and helpful. The room was small but had all the amenities and was well laid out. Everything was impeccably clean and this continued with the housekeeping each day. It was fantastic having the private onsen on the top floor, with windows to look out over the city.

The hotel is located in a calmer area of the red light district. It is super close to everything (10 minute walk to train station, steps away from food and bars), and there are 2 convenient stores just steps away. The room IS really small but expected. The hotel site actually lists the dimension sizes of each room, so take a peak at the dimensions and expect nothing more. Housekeeping did a decent job and provided a bottle of water for every day that we chose the "eco option". Truthfully, aside from not making our bed, we saw little difference between the "Eco option" and full housekeeping as we always got fresh towels. There isn't much room (or even a closet) for luggage, so be mindful of how many suitcases you bring with you. We stacked 2 of our full size luggage on top of each other and had to open and close it each time for access.Pros:-Safe hotel-Great toiletries provided-Free onsen on top floor-Staff can speak English (limited)-Same day pick-up storage option (for checking in/out early)-Relatively quiet rooms and streets (can't really hear party noise at night)-Close to many 24 hour food sources for Jetlag/ late night drunken munchies-Free Wifi in roomCons:-No bathrooms on main floor-Room temperature control issues-Dry air in rooms-Pay upfront prior to end of stay (Not usually an issue for me, but I was moody after being on a 10 hour flight with major time difference. A few hours after checking in, they decided to call our room at 9 p.m., because the staff undercharged us by 500 Yen -about $5 USD. They could have slipped an invoice under my door or completed my tab at check out instead of waking us up to get it done right away).

APA offers hassle free check-in and check-out via machines which is very convenient for us. The hotel security is pretty good too, you need the room key to able to access the elevator all the time. The location is good at Shinijuku area! But i have to say the rooms are really small. If you only got a luggage it's fine but if you have 2 then properly hard to move around the room. The amenities are good, but the bathroom touch up of the housekeeping were not so satisfying.

This Hotel is in a great location its under a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku Railway Station. So easy access to wherever you wanted to go. We even took the N arita Express back to the airport from there.As for the room I had mistakenly booked a semi double room and it was certainly that but that was my mistake not the hotels. As for the room itself it had everything in it and supplied Hairbrushes , Toothbrushes etc. The toilet paper was like sand paper but the toilet was a Bidet as well. The shower was over a very small but deep bathtub . The TV was huge but everything was in Japanese and when we found a English speaking show they would have a voice over in Japanese. But we weren't there to watch tv so no real drama.The housekeeping was a little hit and miss as far as cleanliness went and we somehow lost a T shirt we presume it accidently fell in the bin of the top of my suitcase as it was old..The Buffett Breakfast included in the price was pretty good and we went to dinner there 1 night and the meals were fantastic really enjoyed it. We were going to go again for dinner but it was closed to the public as they had private functions I was. disappointed we were not informed about this being paying guests in the Hotel.Reception was ok but there was one who stepped up and was fantastic Megum Yamaga she was incredibly helpful and made us feel very welcome. I hope have spelt her name right.

Oh wow, this hotel is in the most perfect location, in the centre of Shinjuku with absolutely everything on the doorstep. The hotel was very clean & the staff were very helpful. Be prepared for very small rooms, but very clean & very Japanese! We really would recommend this hotel for location & value.

Luxurious small rooms with a comfy futon for sleeping. Amenities include public bath ( if you aren't tattooed) and grand spa. My only complaint was when asking for help with air conditioning I was told to" please open the window". That made the room only slightly cooler and allowed all the street noise in.

We spent 3 nights in a double room. First time in Japan & coming from Australia, despite knowing that rooms were small we found the size of the room quite frustrating at times. While we did not spend much time in our room, trying to get to items in our cases and generally get dressed and changed was challenging! Everything else was great - location, staff and an amazing breakfast made up for the room!

When booking this hotel I was not expecting much considering how little I paid. When I finally did arrive the hotel was clean and staff were very nice, but the room I got was unbelievably small. I could not fully open my carry on luggage easily in the main room but I managed ok. I experienced this once prior in Tokyo, but from the photos online this hotels rooms appeared bigger but sadly were not. I did book a single room but it was barely big enough for a child. Bathroom as well was very tiny and a larger person over 6ft 150lbs+ would have difficulty getting into and using the bath/shower. My main issue with this place was the location. If you are arriving from Shinjuku JR station it's a bit of a hike to get here. It's a good 25 min walk to get here and that's if you know where you are going (which I did). There might be another subway station you can transfer to in order to reduce the transfer time but either way it's not in the heart of Shinjuku. This might not be terrible if you are only heading back to the hotel once at the end of the day otherwise this place is outside the normal tourist zones by 5-10 min walking so its a bit inconvenient. I was only here 1 night so that was not an issue for me. Also be aware this is on the northern edge of the red light district, but it's not a huge deal in Japan and it's very safe. Overall it was well worth what I paid but I don't believe it's in the best location for most tourists unless you can't afford other more convenient locations.

A great, reasonably, well located, traditionally tiny but well appointed hotel in the heart of Tokyo's famous Shinjuku prefecture. Not for families or the feint hearted.The room is tiny, there's no wasted space - you're really staying in a pigeon hole but this is Japan, this is how it's done. You pay for the room through an automatic machine & you check out the same way. The staff are very helpful and hold onto your bags after check-out but before departure.The bathroom has it all ... just in miniature size. It's great and very typically Japanese.The hotel has a spa on the roof in the typical Onsen style. Not your Kuranda Onsen class but good enough. Expect to get naked, if you uncomfortable with this then don't go - it's not for you.Location is fantastic, the heart of the neon lights district. There's a robot restaurant on every corner and Godzilla on the roof of the building next door. The main railway is less than 5 mins walk and an easy walk with your bags. Shinjuku Station - follow your google maps - very easy. The train from the airport goes all the way so no need to change etc. Two train stops back is Harajuku or Shabuya where the famous intersection from 'lost in translation was filmed'. It won't disappoint.The hotel was convenient - it's not for families or the feint hearted. I stayed 3 days, I was ready to move on. I was ready to seek the quiet traditional serenity that Japan has to offer.

The key thing about this hotel is the location. You're right smack in the middle of the madness that is Shinjuku. In fact you can actually see the big Godzilla statue from the hotel. Given the central location in Tokyo you can't really expect too much in the way space. Our room was very small indeed and you wouldn't really want to be spending extended periods of time in there (other than sleeping). This is hardly really an issue though as the location of the hotel means you're going to be effectively using the room as a base and exploring the weird wonders in the local area.

A standard size hotel with less fuss but offers the comfort and convenience especially travelling in a crowded city of Tokyo. Most of what you need is within reach. Public transport (JR) trains, food, drinks, big shopping malls, local souvenir shops & convenient stores. This hotel offers a separate male & female onsen which is very handy after a big day out touring Tokyo. Amenities and tea/coffee supplied with bath robes (yukata) to use for onsen. Have an indoor and small outdoor onsen. A nice experience and enjoyable way to relax after a busy schedule. The area is safe and busy with bustling crowd. A great experience not only for young adults but also for mature generations. A short distance to shinjuku JR train (5-8mins walk).

I did a lot of research prior to to booking this property and did not have any regrets. This is my second terrific experience in an APA hotel. The only negative was the size of the room. The length of the room was the length of the bed plus 4". The TV was way too large for the room and was actually hard to watch in bed. Breakfast was fabulous but the 2 days of breakfast offered the same selection which might get boring if stayed longer. Did not do onsen. Took the long way to the hotel from Shinjuku Station but once checked in, they helped with an easier route.If you get a good rate all inclusive;worth it.

The hotel is located right in the Shinjuku area which is convenient to many tourists. There are two local convenient stores right next by and plenty of restaurants in the area as well, so you don't have to worry about the food options. It is about 10 - 15 mins walking distance from the subway station or the airport bus stop. The hotel room is small, but perhaps a little bit too small compare to the other business hotels we stayed at previously. If one person is standing in the room, then the other person can only stay on the bed lol However, they do have a rooftop onsen, so we pretty much go there every night to take a shower since the bathroom is a bit of too small for us. The hotel guests are most likely tourists. We rarely get to see local Japanese people check-in. Therefore, make sure you come down early for check out, otherwise, you have to wait in a LONG line to check out.

Great location in Shinjuku. Small room and bed. Weekend prices are more than mid week, something to note when booking. Free onsen on top floor is really good & has outdoor section. Room cleaning was done everyday.

The hotel located right at the center of Kabukicho – Tokyo’s most famous entertainment area. If you are looking for around the clock entertainment – this is the perfect location for you: hundreds of restaurants, coffee shops, movie theaters, convenient stores – all within a two-minute walk you’re your hotel. If you are looking for a more quite place, or a place really close to a central train station – you could find a better location.

Great hotel in a great spot !!Very close to trains,food & shopping!! Rooms are small but this is Japan. Very clean & lovelly amenities. Easy check in. Perfect spot to jump on a train to Harajuku & Shibuya. Would definately stay again.

APA Shinjuku-Kabukicho Tower hotel is centrally located in the happening (red lights) district in Kabukicho,Shinjuku. There are 7-Eleven & Family Mart (local Japanese convenience store) within walking distance, less than 5 mins! Also there are good selection of other eateries, cinema, Pachinko slots & entertainment outlets within walking distance. Some of the eateries open til late. Do be advised that most shops & departmental stores (espc apparels) close at 8pm. The nearest Subway station is the Shinjuku Station - East Exit, which is around 10-15mins walk. If need any directions or use any of the JR / Subway lines, just ask any of the Information Counters (they are conveniently located) around the stations & most of the staffs are quite helpful and friendly [although they may reply you in Jap ;) ]. Rooms are clean & well equipped with amenities. Though bathroom & room may be a bit small in size (but that would pretty much be the same for most Japan hotels) but we're satisfied with the coziness. You won't be able to lay flat your luggage but it's OK. As long as bed is comfy (that's more important) coz that's what most of us look forward to after a long day out! They do have onsen (public hot baths) on the top most level. Men & women's baths are separate. We did not have the chance to try it.Would definitely stay in this hotel (or Kabukicho area the least) for next visit as it is very vibrant at night. Easy access to food & public transportation & shopping.

I arrived to a automatic check-in that actually worked and was fast, and the lobby staff was very helpful the whole stay. Cozy, clean, small rooms with comfortable bed. The bathroom was Ok, with a tub that is either a very large footbath or a very small bathtub..

Another chance of staying at APA in Tokyo after once trying a year before in Nagoya and I would say that this hotel is very new comparing with other and its location is really good as there are many restaurants, 24-hour convenience stores and lots of entertainment complex near by especially a short walk to metro station. I arrived before 3 pm check in time and would leave luggage with no problem with the hotel but there is no toilet available at the lobby which was not inconvenience. The room size is small but no need to worry about facilities and amenities provided. There is big TV Screen in the room but limited channels which I could not enjoy due to language condition however in house movies are also available but with additional charge. Overall is good but only one negative comment is related to cleaning service as I have seen dust from both air grill on the ceiling and air filter from refresher. The container which is provided to put toothbrush, comb and razor is dirty too. Please advise your housekeeper team to more thorough check while cleaning up the room.

Its Tiny!!! even the bathtub is tiny! the bed is small! even my window. the Hall way is also small..BUT Clean. The front desk checked-in us fast. Near metrotrain and malls. they have hard time in speaking english but they are hospitable.

My experience when stay here was so satisfied.. this hotel has a clean room, very helpful staff, and the most important thing is this hotel very near to the entertainment centre. U can see so many peoples walking together at the same time, near to the shopping outlet.

Nice hotel, with very good location. You can get around easily from there, with several restaurants, stores, and a cinema very close by. Also a few minutes in walking distance from one of the metro stations. The room was very small, with a small bathroom.Breakfast was good. The staff were very friendly and helpful.Overall it was an okay place to stay.

Don't be fooled by the good reviews of the hotel!!!! The hotel lies in the red light district of tokyo The upgraded double room is literally the size of the double mattress that is all!!! Even the corridors of the hotel feel stale and factory like. On top of this the bed had not been changed from the previous people in the room with numerous long black hairs in the bed. I told the staff of the dirty sheets with the response the cleaner will come in the morning leaving me to change my own sheets... Needless to say i checked out the next morning as early as possible to find a new hotel

Be prepared to wait at least 10 minutes for the elevator, especially in the morning. There are no stairs, so we did not have the option to take the stairs. The room was the smallest I have ever stayed in. We actually had to figure out where to open our luggages. The only good thing about this hotel is its location.

The hotel is not far from Shinjuku station and 3 min walk to seibu shinjuku station.The room is clean but small.Good onsen bath is located at the top floor of the hotel without charge.A lot of restaurants are around the hotel and some 24 hr open.

The room is small, I mean really small. For a single person it's alright just to sleep or shower. Otherwise pay a bit more for an upgrade to a bigger room. Staff were friendly enough and could speak English.The location however is superb. Lots of food , shopping ,entertainment and the train station, all walking distance. I would stay here again if I'm in shinjuku.

Poor service, staffs and the management are very arrogant, rampant and very racists. Not recommend any Asian travellers to book this hotel as they only welcome Japanese tourists.If you makes a complain, they won't care about it and would not do anything. The attitude is so what, you can't do anything to me. And you already paid me so No harm will be done.

We stayed in this hotel twice over the January period, once on the 7th floor and then on the 12th (we went for a 5 night stay in Kyoto mid honeymoon) staff are lovely, rooms are tight for 2 people but bearable, everything is clean and tidy. Towels and amenities are left outside your door if you leave the Do Not Disturb sign on. 5 mins from Seibu-Shinjuku station, which connects to Takadanobaba, which can get you anywhere!!!! If you are going to Tokyo for a chilled holiday where you spend less of time in your room, stay somewhere else, this is a simple, awesome, breakfasts serving hotel for those looking to eat and get on a train and go out to explore Tokyo. Also being in party central surrounded by arcades was awesome!

A typical modern city dwelling design, the room is small but surprisingly livable, the size and shape of the room's inner parts are measured to centimeter, I don't knock on anything when taking a bath in the tiny bathroom capsule. Located very close to Shinjuku station, the central transport hub. Many good eats around this area, especially sushi on conveyor, big fish little rice and good price. The best part of the hotel is the onsen bath on the 28th floor, clean and well maintain.

The room is need and tidy, however is small which is good for one person.It is in a great location near nightlife and plenty food, near Shinjuku train stationThe staff are friendly, helpful and speak English. There are good facilities including Spa, laundry area and guest waiting area.A cafe serve simple food and reasonable price.

This hotel is in the red light district area which makes it interesting. Overall it is clean and modern. Rooms are not very big as with all Tokyo hotels but amenities and furnishings are new. The hotel is very busy with hundreds of check ins daily. There's a heap of luggage bags at the reception to prove it and is an eye-sore but not a big deal. Staff try to be friendly but have probably lost some personal touch due to the thousands of people staying here.

Checked in on the 8th, had to move out the next day to a nearby hotel in Shinjuku. Quick summary:- Check-in queue was long. When I told them I could only speak English, I was told to wait in another line while another Japanese businessman jumped ahead.- Check-in staff were not exactly polite, but not impolite - far too direct, for example, "Your passport!" doesn't count as good service- The room is clean, but tiny in the extreme. It is also inadequately lit. Bathroom is even smaller, so anyone hoping for some space between the shower & toilet will be disappointed- Toilet did not flush properly - Some questionable literature in the room drawers too promoting Japanese ultranationalist views & revisionist history. Seems insensitive to East Asian tourists who may take offence to this. Should include more travel literature glorifying Tokyo instead and focus on the present.- Narrow corridorsI know this is a three star hotel so I won't be too demanding, but Shinjuku has plenty of other hotels that offer far better service. Won't return to this hotel.

Clean hotel with complete amenities . Though the room is small but its comfortable for 2 person inside the room . Its common for the japanese standard . You can just drop off in shinjuku or seibu station . Just less than 10 mins walk . Ohh yeah for muslim , you can get halal kebab at the corner of the street maybe 1 -2 mins walk from the hotel .

Out of a 7.4 magnitude earthquake, that was so scary on the 25th floor of 28!!! This hotel was really nice. Have never been Japan before, but watched lots of YouTube about Tokyo and some expectations did help a lot! Accommodation Rooms aren't meant for walking, unless you have to do "something" that's all the space you have. It does however have everything one needs, all but the space we are used to in western countries. Automation and space are common thing in Japan..just have to begin the experience, and enjoy the differences. This hotel has a HIS/HERS (free) spa at roof top, a plus. Also a friendly staff, even under difficult circumstances (*quake). **A must city to visit while in Tokyo; Shibuya!! Google everything as much as you can prior. Safe travels!

We stayed at the APA hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho mid December 2016.We moved to the APA hotel from another hotel 3 days into our stay (we wanted to stay in a different area for some of our stay). Whilst the hotel is located right in the heart of Shinjuku (close to shops, restaurants and stations) it was very small and soulless. Rooms in Tokyo hotel are notoriously small but the room here was TINY! The double bed was against a wall so I had to climb over my fiance if I needed to get up in the night. There was barely room to store our luggage and we couldn't both move around the room at the same time. Whilst perfectly clean and functional the bathroom was equally tiny. I certainly wouldn't recommend this hotel to anyone over 6 foot or of a larger frame. Also worth noting is the hotel only supply one very flat pillow per person. This wasn't personally a problem but I note it was for other reviewers.Overall, this wasn't a bad hotel but with so much choice in Tokyo you could probably do better elsewhere!

The hotel is located in the perfect position to explore Tokyo with lots of restaurants nearby and easy access to the train station. The rooms were small but had everything we needed. It was good for a couple of nights but I'd want a bigger room for a longer stay.

If you'r'e not very particular on the size and would like a no fuzz hotel room, then APA Hotel in Shinjuku is your ideal place. The room is tiny, and bathroom is small but still able to fit a tub. What I find interesting about this hotel is the room expense is the basic that you pay. Anything extra, you have to top up your card in the machine with a load of money like watching video on demand. They don't even need your credit card for guarantee as there are no alcohol or drinks to consume.The toiletries are replaced everyday including comb. The only caveat I would say is the aircon control is in Japanese.. so if you need to switch to cool air maybe ask room service.

Liked best: overall value; location close to train station; friendly, helpful staff; excellent amenities, including a great shower. Comfortable bed with good linen; the staff was very responsive, and quickly supplied the extra pillows we requested. The VERY small size of the double room was a surprise at first, but we easily dealt with it - this might have been more difficult if our room hadn't had a window with an interesting city view. Very efficient check-in and check-out. Good place for tourists.

You are only paying for the location and convenience. Close to subways, restaurants, etc.Beware of rooms that are facing the construction site. I slept in on the those rooms and you can hear the music from downstairs all night and constructions going on all day. We had to ask for a room switch.Room is tiny. But this is expected of Tokyo hotels.

let's start with the PROS so I don't sound too negative: *location is great. *Toho cinema 15 seconds away* Family Mart right across the hotel ( perfect for late night ice cream or water runs)* Tons of restaurants/izakayas nearby. Japanese and western * drugstores ( selling Japanese makeup --my fave!!) in every corner* relatively close to JR stations. ( East Exit) if you are traveling with older people or kids please take note that "close" still takes around 10-15 minutes. * room is tiny but that is normal in Japan. Bed was comfortable. * bathtub includedNow to the CONS. Terrible Customer Service. 1. We arrived at the hotel at around 1130PM and check in took 30 minutes. I have no idea why since all my documents where complete. Traveled with my parents and baby nephew and I felt bad that they had to wait for so long. We spent the whole day traveling and were all famished. 2. I wanted to make a reservation at a local restaurant and the front desk absolutely refused to make it for me. I kindly explained that I didn't know how to speak Japanese but she still said no. She spoke good English so I guess she just didn't want to. Imagine if I had to do something more important like let's say God forbids talk to a doctor about an accident. This is the first time I experienced something like this in Japan. Usually even if the Japanese don't understand a word i"m saying they will try to help..no matter what. Even if we have to play charades. 3. We had an early flight so I was in the lobby at 4 am. I rented a pocket wifi and had everything prepared in it's return package and I asked the front desk ( a different person this time) to drop it off at a post box for me. I've rented pocket wifi before and all the other hotels did this task for me. but not APA Hotel. The guy ABSOLUTELY REFUSED to do this for while giving me the worst attitude. then he proceeds to give me directions to a post box so far away I had ask the kind people on the street to help me. Finally I got to drop off my package at a Lawson Konbini. this usually isn't a huge deal but I was traveling with my older parents and a toddler and it was 4AM!!!! I would NEVER stay here again because of the preposterous customer service. And I'm not even hard to please! UGH.

This place might be a little hard to find as it is situated in the dead center of Shinjuku's night life street. But rest assured it is without a doubt the perfect spot for those who want to experience Shinjuku. Toho Cinema 15 seconds away/ Izakaya and every variety of restaurants you want right out the front doors/Family Mart across the road. Pool, Darts, Virtual Golf right next door, and you're pretty much right where you want to be as you leave the hotel.As for the hotel it is extremely clean. Reception are capable of speaking engrish;) Wifi included.There is an Onsen on the top floor.It says no tattoos but honestly I never had a problem.Smoking area outside.Close to Shinjuku Station JR West Exit.

Shinjuku is the bustling heart of Tokyo's clubland with plenty of bars, restaurants and nightlife which can cater for any travellers discerning requirements.The hotel is just a short walk from Shinjuku mainline station (but be warned, is not easy to find at first!) It is situated at the end of a narrow square that includes restaurants, convenience shops and a multiplex cinema complex complete with Godzilla on the roof.The hotel lobby is the height of opulence with massive chandeliers, marble floors and black and gold paintwork. Reception staff are friendly and helpful, though the checking in process involves entering details into a machine which then produces your keycards.Our room was located on the 25th floor of this 28 storey hotel. Suffice to say, the view over Tokyo was spectacular! Rooms are tiny however and it was difficult for the two of us to manoeuvre around our large suitcases (let alone each other) which we had to live out of for 5 days as there was virtually no storage for clothes.An oversized TV dominated one wall at the foot of our double bed which was predominately set up as a pay-per-view system, the tokens for which could be paid for at the vending machines on each floor. Also within the room was a desk (complete with kettle and plenty of literature on the hotel and surrounding area) and a small fridge. The plastic bathroom we had grown accustomed to during our holiday was well appointed and included toiletries, toothbrushes, razors, hairbands, etc.In order to get a comfortable sleep, I had to ask for additional pillows which were brought to our room after the second request. This really did make a difference so ask at Reception on check-in if you need more than one very thin pillow.Rooms are aligned around an open-to-the-elements atrium which made the corridors cold. Also, if you are worried about heights, and as the corridors are narrow, don't look down!On the 28th floor, there is a spa which includes a communal bath. Males and females are completely separate, but expect to be naked in the bath as my partner soon found out!!! Robes and slippers are provided though to protect your modesty once out of the bath. We didn't investigate the advertised massages as these appeared to be reasonably expensive for not much time. Bearing in mind the hotel location too, we felt the phrase 'massage' could have been a euphemism. For a more forthcoming traveller, perhaps find out and report on Tripadvisor!The restaurant was tasteful and modern but dirty (shelves were covered in dust and fluff) but its staff were very friendly. Breakfast each morning consisted of a reasonable selection of western style cooked food together with an extensive continental buffet. Japanese food was also available including grilled fish, rice and Miso Soup. The downside to breakfast was that the elements of it did not change at all from one day to the next and it was served on compartmentalised plastic trays which we found odd and likened them to those prison food is served in. We chose to eat in the restaurant just one night and was disappointed by the options available and its high costs in comparision to some of the numerous restaurants in the area. We both opted for burgers which were OK, but including two drinks felt that almost £50 was far too expensive. We were also surprised that the restaurant stopped serving food relatively early given that it remained open beyond midnight for drinks.We did like the hotel but on hindsight probably would not return given that there are many, many other hotels in the area - something we did not realise at the time of booking the room in the UK. I guess it goes with the territory that as the hotel was located in the clubland area, you can expect to be regularly accosted by people trying to drum up custom for their clubs at all times of day - this was quite off putting for us naive country types. Word of warning...don't go into a club if you can't afford it! We didn't, but expect to have a massive drinks bill landed on you at the end of the night!!We knew that Tokyo would be full of hustle and bustle and so have no regrets over chosing this hotel, it all contributes to the incredible contrasts that you experience when travelling around Japan.

My husband and I recently stayed at Apa Hotel Shinjuku and we only have positive things to say about the hotel.Although the hotel room was a bit small, it was enough to accommodate us. The hotel itself was really clean and staff were really friendly. On the last day of our trip, we accidentally left our camera in our room and the staff were kind enough to send it back to us by international courier, without any cost. The hotel is also very close to Shinjuku Station and very easy to find if you're coming from Haneda Airport.We'll definitely stay here again if we come back to Tokyo.

Stayed here for 4 nights whilst exploring tokyo. The hotel is in a great location as it is only a short walk to Shinjuku Station so easy to explore the city. The area is very lively with lots happening! Room was tiny- much smaller than expected, however this was doable as little time was spent in the room. Unfortunately the windows do not open, and we were told Air conditioning is not get turned on in the winter, therefore we sweated through four very hot and stuffy nights with no air! Room was clean and new - would recommend for a short stay to explore the city and not in winter if you like to have a comfortable sleep.

Brigitte S
Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia

review_body: Ok first off, the room is tiny and we were in the bigger room,still tiny. Thats all for the cons. I'll start with the reception. The staff were really friendly and they spoke english that was understandable. The restaurant was pretty good. The food and coffee, not to mention the Pancakes, were outstanding. I stayed for 9 days and on one of the mornings, i misplaced my wallet. I was panicking of course, in the room, to the cafe, to the reception. Both the Cafe staff and the reception were very warm , understanding and friendly. I eventually found it to my relief and embarrassment. The breakfast had a pretty good spread, but unfortunately, it was exactly the same all 9 days i was there. It has an Onsen on the top floor and the location was super convenient. Family Mart and 711 less than 100 meters away. A Pub that shows Soccer close by. Awesome Takoyaki, Ramen, Sushi, and other foodie goodies just at your doorstep. Loved every moment of it and couldn't recommend it more, if you're ok with Claustrophobia. Try not to bring huge luggage.

Booked for 6 nights stay here, staying the 1st night at the Onsen. Bringing a small child with me, Hotel won't let us leave one of the luggage overnight even though we were checking in the next day because they won't allow overnight luggages except for check-in date, fine. They won't even let us leave our luggage for 1-2 hours so we can find food around the area! Struggling with 2 big luggages, travel trolley and a small child. They don't have space for 2 hours??!! SO INFLEXIBLE! Bad experience even before check-in! Should have gone for a more reputable establishment!

Although is quite near in shinjuku but the room is very small. I don't really mind that the room is small but the bed is very soft, not very adequate to the spine. Secondly, although I went there is winter, but there is no aircon at all in the room, it was very hot in the room. Their eco cleaning, don't even clean about the hair in the toilet, I don't mind they don't change the sheets, but if we request that we want to clean up all, they dont give us water. If we want water than they don't clean the room.

The location is alright. Right in the middle of Kakubicho, but a bit of walk to the JR Shinjuku station. The room is super tiny, but tolerable. The pillows are super thin, and the hotel refused to provide extra ones. The hotel wifi is so slow and unstable, it's almost useless. There are much better options out there, and I will not stay here again next time.

Pros: - Convenient hotel, 5 minutes walk to the one of the exits of Shinjuku station - very clean - Many eateries around, including Yoshinoya - Rooms well-equipped with hairdryer, kettle, comb, toothbrush etc - Lovely public bath (rare in Tokyo), indoor and outdoor pools - trouser press on every floor Cons: - They lost our reservation twice (because we went to Kyoto and came back), made us wait 30 mins twice, and started a new reservation twice, which begs the question, why couldn't they have started the reservation earlier? They didn't even ask for credit card confirmation when they started the new reservations! - If you want late check out, you're going to have to pay for it! - The rooms are small. If you're tall, it's going to be very uncomfortable for you. Getting in and out of the room/toilet is going to be difficult if someone is standing in the same room - Thin and soft pillows. We asked for extra pillows, but they never came - cannot leave your luggage here overnight, but a couple of hours is possible - no toilet on the ground floor

The Hotel is located at the heart of Shinjuku, Kabukicho. With lots of shops, restaurants and entertainment open till late. You can definitely fully experience the nightlife of Tokyo right here. The Hotel is located about 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku Station. The Double Room I had was rather small, just enough comfort for the night rest and my luggage. While I believe the cleanliness of the room could be further improved. My friend and I noticed that there are visible spots where dusty are accumulating and irritated my sensitive nose. While we do noticed that throughout the 6 days, our bedsheets were not changed at all. Also, the air-conditioning of the room is difficult to configure. There might be nights were it is too cold or too warm for comfort.During our check in, we realise that some of the electrical appliances were not working in the room. The Hotel staff quickly attend to our issue but only decided to re-arrange for another room after an hour of trying to rectify the issue. We were downgraded to a small room with small bed-size but only approached by the Hotel staff the next day. We were refunded for the downgraded due to their mistake.As a bonus, the Hotel has an Onsen at the highest floor which is free for all guest.

Very good location - right in the action and lights of Shinjuku. Within walking distance from Shinjuku JR station. So close to food, shopping and entertainment (karaoke, arcades)Your standard APA hotel - much like all the others in layout. Small rooms, small bathrooms. Hotel staff speak good English. Hotel had breakfast service/restaurant.

This hotel was a fantastic location for train stations, bars, restaurants and some shops. There is a 24 hour store selling snacks and drinks opposite one of the entrances. It's a very tall building with far views of Tokyo. It's also close to a hospital, but I hope you wouldn't need it. However I had a very bad toothache and it was great that we were staying so close by for medical advice. The rooms are very small, but not so small that you'd feel claustrophobic. No one really needs a big hotel room in Tokyo, you should be out and about enjoying the culture all day long. The staff didn't speak much English, but this is typical of Japan in general and you'd experience this in most other hotels in Tokyo. I picked up some medicine for my toothache and asked if they could read the instructions for me and this was very problematic to say the least! To summarise, small but central.

I stayed here most of the times. The room was clean but small (This is Japan) Great location and very convenience. Staffs nice but difficult to communicate in English. (Again this is Japan) I really like the shower room and all facilities, Housekeeping is the best too. But the price keep up and down too much depending the season of tourist vocation. One thing that they don't recognise the repeating guest. All the rest are ok.

We stayed for 3 nights in this hotel, it is relatively clean and tidy. Rooms are extremely small and you struggle to fit a suitcase in the room, but it's in Japan, so we expected that. The worst thing is the room temperature, you might like to be warm, but the Japanese love to be hot. And even though this hotel has individual air conditioning in each room, they keep the control panel in your room locked under central management control and they don't let you venture more than a degree or two either side of a preset limit. So the coolest we could go was the equivalent of a hot summers day in the south of Spain... they even have a notice at reception saying that "you can't change the room temperature, so it you don't like it don't check in"!! I stayed in two other hotels in Japan with this brand over the course of two weeks. This is my only issue with this chain of hotels but unfortunately it would stop me from staying here again.

Great location, close to restaurants and shops but not too noisy at the same time. Just a few mins walk from main Shinjuku station. Room was quite small - as can be expected in Japan but we found it fine for the amount of time we were in there. Huge TV was almost comical in the small room but we weren't complaining!

This is our first time to Tokyo, we stayed at APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower 5 nights, the room was clean but little small, the staffs was very attentive. Only the problem was climate control sometime too hot. If we go Tokyo will book again.

I have visited Tokyo and stayed at Shinjuku , selected this hotel as located in a center of shopping area. You will find many restaurant and brand name product ( LV, Coach ,Gucci etc) shop . Hotel have a clean room with a tiny space as usual of Japanese Hotel style.Nice reception , you can selected to check-in by yourself or let them do for you.Room has a window but can not open as a high building. Good for spent time on your sleep.on 28, th floor has onsen bath for all customer with a nice view of shinjuku, separate men and women.TV is quite big and only one English channel, Good to stay here

We stayed at APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower for three nights. The hotel is centrally located in the Kabukicho entertainment district. Thus, there are many shops, restaurants and arcades around. The rooms in this hotel are very small. They seem to be even smaller than the rooms in other Japanese business hotels of the same category. Our personal highlight was the onsen on the top floor of the hotel - a great place to relax from the hectic city life!

The hotel is about 7mins from Shinjuku station. Clean rooms, fresh towels every day. Rooms are tiny, like cabins on a cruise ship, but as long as you are aware, it's not a problem. There's a small convenience store outside the hotel, has almost every ting. Hotel is not suitable for stay with children.

I was happy with my stay here with a couple of exceptions. The room was one of the smallest on our Japan trip, but it was well maintained and complete. Breakfast was exceptional. It was well stocked with Japanese and Western items, it was served in a nice room with views, and the staff was very attentive. The climate control was a problem, the cooling was too powerful so every time it turned on the bed area was blasted with cold air. The temperature fluctuations made sleep a bit difficult. Also, sound from outside came into the room but there was no noise from inside the hotel. I enjoyed Shinjuku and the availability of food and entertainment all night. Shinjuku station was an easy walk away, and getting anywhere from there was simple.Finally, the price was excellent for what we got.

The hotel is well-located in the Shinjuku shopping area with lots of shops and restaurants. The room was very small but there were everything you needed in the room, free wifi, all of the amenities including the big flat screen TVs. After a long walking day, dipping in the hot bath at the rooftop onsen was a plus.

Location is great. Near to restaurants, train station, shops etc All within walking distance.Room however is rather small but then that is quite normal in Tokyo.Has a great hot spa at the top of hotel which is free and this feature is really something to look forward to at the end of a tiring day. Also near to meeting places for joining organised day trips out of the city.

Everything thing I thought Tokyo would have been.. big.. neon.. busy and something so utterly different to anything I had seen before. Hotel was a great location, close to EVERYTHING and easy to find. We were lucky to be staying on the top floor and the view was heartbreakingly incredible. Would deffo stay here again! Thank you!

The hotel room was very small. The bed touched three walls. However I could find everything I needed in the room. There were hair ties, shower caps, coffee, tea. It was a good price for the room. Location was very central. I didn't have a problem getting around. There's a 7 11 nearby that's open late.

review_body: I'll get the only real negative out of the way first in saying that the rooms are REALLY small, but it's to be expected if you do your research online. The location couldn't be any better. Restaurants, bars, shopping, train stations, etc, are all a stone throw away. It all comes down to value, and this hotel has plenty of it!

Ideally situated a few minutes walk on the East side of Shinjuku station. Plenty of places to eat and shop and easy to explore the surrounding areas by JR rail. Found fares really cheap and not to hard to navigate or operate ticket machines, which have a 'English button'Room very small, with just a few hangers to hang up your clothes (no wardrobe ) but that didn't bother us as used to living in small spaces. Lots of goodies supplied daily...toothbrushes, combs, razors, cotton buds and even hair bands oh and slippers and robes. Was a bit disappointed we couldn't use the bath on top floor as we both have tattoos and so banned. Large flatscreen to at end of the bed but if you don't pay for movies you only get repetitive sky news. I had kodi on my iPad but did get a bit of buffering though.

Perfect hotel if you want to be in the heart of Shinjuku! It's a quick walk from Shinjuku station right near the Toho theaters (look for the godzilla). The rooms were clean and the beds comfortable, but be warned that they are small. You would have trouble opening two suitcases in the room. The bathroom was well appointed and was stocked with toiletries. I didn't go to the spa/bath on the top floor but my husband did and said it was nice. The hours are great (unlike the usual early closing hours in the US). The bath is open from 3pm to 11AM. Free wifi in the room.

The room is basic, small but clean. Location is great, walking distance from many of the attractions in Shinjuku. Lots of eateries, shopping and entertainment outlets. The train stations are about 10-15 mins walk away, so a really convenient spot to stay in. I recommend this to tourists and families who want to explore the area. Note that there are a few APA hotels around the area and some are in a dodgier part of the place near Kabukicho, so please ensure that you are booking the right hotel. Also, it can get a little rowdy after 11pm, but nothing to be worried about from a security perspective.

新宿JR 站東口出，直行10多分鐘，見到TOHO Building 即到。未到check in 時間可以先寄存行李，再出去玩，很方便。房間各樣設備，床，浴室都好乾淨，畀到客人舒服的感覺。但size 真的不大，啱夠行李喼打開攞嘢。電視是高清解像，好正；床很軟，好好瞓。早餐貴，冇試；28樓大浴室要全裸入，冇去。酒店樓下對面有24小時Family mart, 買嘢、拎錢都好方便。Overall, it is a very good hotel in a convenient location.

The location of the hotel is excellent. The shopping area of Shinjuku is within walking distance. Rooms are relatively small but most hotel rooms in Japan are tiny anyway. There is a hot spring on the top floor which is great after a long day of shopping.

Positives•location is walking distance to station and bang in the middle of all the madness in kabuchio area, next to robot restaraunt, golden gai, piss alley etc •Asahi vending machine on top floor next to ice dispenser with panoramic city views•beds super comfy memory foam topper • great toiletries replenished daily •spa/onsen included and is an amazing experience read the rules on the wall to the left as u walk in and you will enjoy it! •great wifi, very fast connection•great shower pressure and the mirror is heated so never steams up -nice!•never heard the busy streets below or any other guests coming and going good sound proofed windows and roomsNegatives•check in always has a queue with luggage everywhere it's cramped and carnage •small room •only one bottle of water given despite it being a double room •sink is too big for the size of the small bathroom•slightly pricey for the size of the room

I really liked this hotel! It still feels new! We arrived at 1130pm and reception were very welcoming. The receptionists English was good enough for us to check in, ask for extra pillows and explain we were having our pocket wifi delivered to the hotel the next day. We stayed in a non-smoking double room for 4 nights. The room was a surprising size as I was expecting a shoebox! It was definitely comfortable for my boyfriend and me. The bed was very soft and comfortable with the extra pillows we got. The bathroom was a bit small but good for one person at a time to use. They supplied so many toiletry items as well - toothbrushes, hair brush, disposable razors that they replaced daily, Q tips, hair bands, shower caps and little scrub towels. The hotel was really quiet too, our room had a nice view towards Shinjuku station. It was an easy 12min walk to the JR Shinjuku station, but also easy to walk to lots of different metro stops. The hotel has a lot of restaurants nearby and a 7/11 with an ATM that accepted our travel card. I highly recommend this hotel!

I chose this hotel primarily for its location - a 5 minute walk from Shinjuku train station. Also, being on a limited budget, I wanted the nicest possible 3 star property that I could find. I was pleased with every aspect of the hotel...except the VERY small room size - but I knew it would be small so there was no surprise there. I had a double room with a double bed (144cm wide) and there was very little space to move about the room. The length of the bed was the entire width of the room - so I don't know how the housekeeping staff managed to make the bed so nicely each day. The room was very clean and the towels were changed daily, even though I was happy to retain them for several days.The TV was HUGE (compared to the room) and the BBC channel was in English which was great.The bathroom was very compact with a whiz-bang, bidet-style toilet and a very deep, high-walled bath, which was ok for me but I imagine rather difficult for an elderly person to access.The staff were very helpful and polite and a pleasure to deal with.If I were to return to Tokyo for a short stay, I would definitely stay at this hotel again. It was great value for money, excellently located (for public transport and shops), 20m from a convenience store and near some great little 'cheap and cheerful' Japanese restaurants which served delicious Miso Ramen for only 690 yen! The small room could prove a little stifling over a longer stay but for only 4 days it was absolutely perfect.

clean and safe rooms in the heart of Shinjuku, quick walk to train station. spend the extra bit of money and upgrade from the standard room, well worth it. staff was very polite and helpful. easy check in/out process. would stay again

The rooms are tiny for the paid amount(11SqM to 200$ a night)They have "free WiFi" that is the slowest WiFi available ( it takes you a minute to transfer data like pictures over the web not to mention ho painful it is to try and open a video or a remote connection to the office). Also you cannot open the windows in the room.Basically you are stuck at an extremely small fish tank (even if you upgrade to a double bedroom room) for a high sum of money ~200$ a night.I've been to a much better hotel at the price of 100$ a night.

Rooms are too tiny but if like us you only come to hotel to sleep at night, it's not a problem. Location is fantastic. About 10 minure walking to station which is very 2ell connected with JR to other parts of Tokyo. The communal bath is also quiet good, clean and relaxes. Will recommend for the not-overtly sensitive traveller.

Well located near the public transport. I would advice this place for one person only. The rooms are too small for a couple. The prices and the breakfast are honest. The staff does not speak English. Good place for a solo trip if you are just looking for a place to sleep. The bed is very comfortable.

Its tokyo people. If you didn't expect a tiny room you did zero research for your trip. That being said this hotel is located supurbly. Close to shinjuku station, lots of great food nearby, game arcades, small casinos, sights to see. For the price we paid its incredible.

The hotel is in the heart of Shinjuku area, brilliant location, walking distance to Shinjuku metro/train station. The room was tiny, I called it capsule, but was enough for me as a solo traveler just to have shower and sleep. The mattress had the best years served. Air-con/Heating was working well. Water pressure in the bathroom was good. Breakfasts offered both continental and local food, not such a big selection, but do its job. The rooftop onsen is awesome with full toiletries stocked. Also hotel uses Shiseido cosmetics which is very nice. They also have microwaves available for reheating your takeaways:-).
