review_body: Firstly this is a Japanese business hotel. That means curt service and tiny rooms. As long you keep that in mind this is a great hotel. Location is perfect although it is a loud, busy, somewhat seedy area of Tokyo so keep that in mind. It is perfectly safe however. Nice spa with hot pools upstairs, confronts me rooms although the pillow are terrible. -1 point for having the smallest rooms in the world even by Japanese standards.

This hotel is in a great location. Rooms are tiny and compact but serve the purpose and are of a very good quality, modern (huge tv!) and clean. Good supermarket across road and coffee shops nearby to buy breakfast. There is an option to check in early but they charge 1,000 yen per hour before 3pm.

The location is about 3- 4 blocks from the Shinjuku Station and the room was non smoking. The bed was comfortable. The room is literally 7 feet by 7 1/2 feet with a tiny bathroom and narrow path to the door. It cost 11,500 Yen per room per night and did not include breakfast. It is clean and you can store your luggage in the lobby for a few hours at no additional cost. (Free luggage storage is available on the day of check in and check out.) Breakfast was pricey and we chose to shop at the local nearby family Mart and 7 - 11 for our meals. The AC required some figuring out, but did work. The size was too small for us, but it is a better value than other APA hotels. Another positive is that the WiFi is free. Per their website: Guests with tattoos may not be permitted to use the property's public bathing areas or other facilities where the tattoos might be visible to other guests.

We had so much fun here. The traditional baths on the top floor are fantastic, don't miss! The rooms are very small, but clean and comfortable. You are in easy walking distance to trains and great food. Excellent for a short stay in Tokyo.

This place is great for a short stay which was my situation. For me even the double bed room was too small, had large suitcase no place to open it! But, other than that perfect location and does the job. Surrounding area is filled with restaurants and nightlife, 10 min walk to JR Shinjuki, can take NexEs Narita express train from here,

This hotel is great, located right in the center of the happenning streets of Shinjuku. Great access to food and shops. It also has a good public bath on the top level looking over Tokyo and is clean and professional.

This is a very nice hotel. If you want to stay in Shinjuku, this hotel is very well located, clean and cosy. There is a public bath facility on the top floor which is clean and well maintained. It is short walk to golden gai too.

This hotel in only a 10minute walk from Shinjuku station ( take the east exit) which makes it a great location to explore Tokyo. The rooms are very compact which is not unusual in Japan so if you want space you will need to pay extra for that luxury. Our room had a bed and small desk, no wardrobe just some hooks on the wall for a few items. It also had a small fridge, slippers, bathrobes and plenty of amenities in the bathroom. Again the bathroom was compact but included bath and shower facilities. Good airco, excellent sound proofing so peaceful nights sleep and a large flat screen TV which is ironic when the room is so small! I would recommend this hotel for those looking to pay a fair price within Tokyo and I would stay here again.Just a mention to the reception staff who were also very pleasant when we checked in. We were offered some free snacks and they also provided us with umbrellas for a very wet day inTokyo. Small touches but appreciated.

I was there for a week. When I first saw the room, I almost scream "oh my God! This is so small!".However, the good things are this hotel is very clean & neat. The foods are delicious.There was a giant LED TV right in front of the bed.Irrespectively of the fact that I struggle with the space of the room, I like this hotel in term of cleanliness and the food.

The tower is very high with 28 floors and good views of Tokyo. Lot of rooms. The single room is small but all necessary is included. The bathroom is also good. The location is simply perfect in Shinjuku. The price is a reasonable for Japan.

This had to be the smell instead hotel I've ever stayed in. The staff (especially re eption) were rude and unhelpfull and the rooms are filthy. We asked to be changed to a different room due to a terrible smell of smoke and we were told there were no other rooms available-despite being told by booking.com that there were several roo.s available. The smell of smoke is overpowering even in the so called non smoking rooms. I would never stay here again.

The hotel is very nice and clean, located near a station e lots of facilities such as markets and restaurants and various shops. Staff is super kind!We stayed in a small double room, wich was pretty small as the name suggests but also comfortable and equipped with everything you need.I would stay there over and over again if I ever will visit Tokyo again! Shinjuku feels like a second home <3

Top position in the heart of shinjuku just 2 minut walk from the shinjuku east station.Also the mega onsen in the roof (28 floor) is top.On the other hand, services are not so efficent ( we had a problem with credit card and Atm and ask of it possibile ti pay half at check in and half the Day later..no collaboration).Room are very very small ( it seam to stay in a capsule hotel). There were no space for 2 luggage and we had to take our breath to get in and out the room because the door opened half cause behind it there were our luggage.It cost so much than it offer.

This hotel was surprisingly good for the price we paid (around £75 per night for two people), considering it is in an excellent location. We stayed for one night as part of a post cruise city break. The hotel is smart and contemporary. Thd location is excellent, right in the heart of Shinjuku which is the neon district. I had read that Shinjuku had s red light district, and I'm sure that there were some bars advertising 'girls' but no more so than Soho area in London etc. I certainly didn't feel unsafe, the area was bustling and packed with interesting bars restaurants and shops (cat cafes, robot restaurants!). The hotel is a 5 minute walk from the main Shinjuku station and 2 minutes from Seibo Shinjuku subway station which makes it really easy to get round Tokyo and see all the sights. There's great nightlife around the hotel to enjoy too.The rooms are absolutely tiny which I believe is to be expected in Tokyo, but as we had 2 large suitcases, there was literally no room to put them and one of them ended up in front of the door which was surely a fire hazard! Aside from the space (or lack of) the hotel was fairly clean and had all the amenities provided. They even had Shiseido toiletries which was a nice surprise! There is a Japanese bath spa on the top floor which looked nice but we didn't use it. The hotel corridors don't seem to be air conditioned but the rooms were, with an added booster box/ fan which we had on all night but it was noisy. To sum it up, I would definitely stay there again or recommend the APA hotel but only for a short stay as it is pretty cramped. If you are staying more than 2 or 3 nights you may want to consider staying somewhere bigger and more luxurious! A tip we would have found useful- don't spend lots on the Narota Express to get back to Narita airport (3100 yen or £24 each). Instead, get the subway from Shinjuku main station to Nippori (Yamanote line) which cost (200 yen each or £1.60) then get the Keisei Limited Express to Narita airport - goes every 20 minutes and costs 1030 yen each or £8 each, takes 75 mins from there to Narita. Overall journey allowing time for finding where you're going takes around 2 hours which is a bit longer than the Narita Express but not by much, and costs £10 each rather than £24. Taxis in Tokyo are very expensive. In the subway, you pay by ticket fare rather than for which destination you are going to, so look on the maps to find your destination and it tells you how much it costs to get there. Easy when you get your head around it!

Near to Shinjuku station, the position is perfect to sightsee the city. Hotel is beautiful and clean. However, Our room was quite small. Public bath at the last floor. Entertaiment just around the corner.

This hotel was very convenient and well kept. About 10 mins walking or less from the Shinjuku East exit. Lots of restaurants, shops around. Very colorful and lively.Check in is strictly at 3pm.. if early check in required you will have to pay ¥1000 per hour. We booked the small double room as it was just 1 night's stay but it gets claustrophobic if one has to stay there many nights. The check in- check out process is so automated and convenient. I loved this hotel & chain.The -ve's are that there's only paid TV & movies... maybe a BBC on the TV channels that avl. Rest all in Japanese.The onsens are the best part of the hotel... please don't miss out... so clean and we'll kept... great stay overall.

We stayed there for 5 nights. To start with, the lobby only had check-in counters. And the staff at the check-in counters told me that she could not make reservation at restaurants for guests though I told her I could not speak Japanese. Of course, they only do check-ins. We opted for Eco mode of cleaning for our room, meaning only removal of rubbish and clean towels everyday and nothing else - no re-filling of amenities no changing of bed sheets etc. One night when we return to our room at 10pm we found the door opened, towels changed, and there was a bag of amenities in the middle of the floor in the room. When I called the reception about the matter I was just asked if I had closed the door when I went out in the morning, and if I had lost anything. No apology whatsoever. Can you imagine having to remind the hotel staff to close the door to ones room after they clean it.

My boyfriend and I stayed here for 6 nights while touring Tokyo. This hotel is a prime location for eccentric travelers, with the Kabukicho always bustling right outside of its doors. Great for walkers and non-walkers alike, it is about a 5 minute walk to Shinjuku station and a 30 minute walk to Shibuya. There is both a 7-eleven and a Family Mart right across the plaza, which both accept foreign cards with a small international fee. That being said, if you are traveling with children I wouldn't recommend staying in Kabukicho, as it is technically the red light district. Granted there aren't nude photos plastered up all over the place, but unless you want to answer a lot of questions from your kids about what a girl cafe is, I wouldn't stay in this particular APA. The rooms are obviously quite small, but you can't expect anything more than a wealthy family's shoe closet when you're paying ~$100 a night. Stretching room is a pricey commodity here in Tokyo. In The double room You can usually open one suitcase on the stand, and leave the second one closed at the foot of the bed. The bed is pretty much the only area pull be able to lay out your suitcase in this room. The room service is fantastic, cleaning every possible speck of dirt in the bathrooms they can find. If you're a victim of The TSA's ridiculous liquid restrictions then fear not, they provide a small tube of toothpaste and a toothbrush for their guests. Leave the toothbrush in the cup provided if you don't want them to throw it out and replace it each day. Razors (with shaving cream), Q-tips, bath sponges, a hair dryer, slippers, yukatas, trousers presses, tea and coffee, and a tea kettle are also provided.The bath spa (I'd call it and onsen but I know there's an intense classification system for onsens that I'm not sure this spa meets) was one of my favorite parts of this hotel. It is a public nude bath, so if you don't want to be rude, you better strip down. People in the bath honestly don't care, and they sometimes will strike up a conversation with you to practice their english. If you're caught hungover after a night at the izakayas, then nothing feels better than sitting in the open air bath in the morning. Just make sure you've washed yourself off sufficiently before entering to spare yourself some judgmental looks. Though is doesn't look like it, The hallway outside of your room is technically outside, which explains the intense humidity and perplexing amount of rain you'll see coming from the "roof". Fear not, the rooms are wonderfully air-conditioned to accommodate. All in all, if you're spending your days wandering around the city, then this is a lovely hotel in a convenient location. If you plan on spending a lot of time inside, are claustrophobic, or have any kids, I'd bite it on the premium and stay somewhere larger and more expensive to spare your sanity.

Stayed at this hotel for a couple of nights.I would say it's around 5min walk from Shinjuku JR (provided that you got the right exit).Loads of restaurants around. 24/7 convenient store opposite to hotel.Room is of standard Tokyo size, but clean as usual. Reasonably priced.

Stayed here for a few nights in April and it was a nice enough hotel, despite the small rooms which is typical in Tokyo. I don't often write reviews but felt compelled to after finding some of the literature on display in this hotel. Initially I couldn't believe what I came across - after all, this was a well-regarded and reviewed hotel chain. In every APA hotel room, there are books describing extreme right-wing nationalist accounts of historical events with a focus on WWII crimes in China, Korea, etc., either denying, downplaying, or justifying them in the most insensitive and racist manner (I had to stop reading by this point). Aside from the fact that these views are horribly offensive to humanity, the hotel has the audacity to actively perpetuate these views (the books apparently are even on sale at the front desk) and it appears they have largely gotten away with it. I did a quick search on APA hotels and outside of a handful of reviews citing the same thing, it's largely unknown and ignored. It would be as if Chik Fil'A put out sex ed material with their burgers on how premarital and gay sex was wrong. If Chik Fil'A gets backlash for its comments on gay issues, APA (in a similar environment) would be utterly shut down. I get that most people here are on vacation or business, perhaps on a budget or booking at the last minute. I'm also not one that often takes a hard stance on where my money goes (what products not to buy, etc.) but something like this was so egregious and inexcusable that I can't in good conscience stay at or recommend this hotel. I want people to be fully aware of what they'd be supporting by staying at this hotel and decide for themselves whether or not it's acceptable to them. I have to say I am surprised this was barely mentioned online but hopefully this type of thing is dissuaded in the future.

This hotel would be ok if it wasn't for having the most uncomfortable bed ever created. Honestly it's like they gave up stuffing the mattress half way though and thought 'that'll do'. To top it off we were provided with two 1cm thick pillows. There is a massive TV which is great but I came to sleep so yeah.... Useless

Stayed here for 2 nights. Room is comfortable. Hotel is in the center of the nightlife. There are restaurants, clubs, and shops nearby, a gameroom next door, family mart and 7 eleven yards away from the hotel and then the neon signs. Just beautiful! Stayed here a couple of times now and also introduced our son and his fiancé to this hotel.

Located at the most convenient spots in Shinjuku and there are many restaurants and bars around the hotels which open until midnight. Downside is the rooms are very very small - can barely open one luggage in the room. Bed is clean but personally I think it's too soft and no support. The worst thing is the SERVICE. Understand it's an economy hotel but the staff is ignorant to my request. I asked a front desk staff (in non-peak) hour to make a reservation by phone for a restaurant. She said no for a few times and pissed me. She ignored me until I asked to speak to her senior. She then left without a word and minutes later, she eventually called for me rudely. I didn't expect such a poor service in Japan.

Not far from JR, Close to lots of eating places. There is 7. Eleven just outside of the hotel. Room was very small. They provided all toiletries which was very nice. Onsen was very nice. After a long day of site seeing to have an Onsen was lovely.

On arrival we were pointed to a check in machine, airport style. That was the last time we spoke to an employee. The location is great for the station, food and Golden Gai.The room was comfortable and very clean if a little small.Ideal for a short stay.

During our trip we stayed just two nights in Shinjuku (at the above hotel) during which the staff were friendly and quick to resolve any problems we had, including faulty toilet and lost key cards. The room size was small, but reasonable, for the most basic double room. The location is fantastic with many different surrounding areas to accommodate all needs. There are many brilliant restaurants and attractions within walking distance and the metro is just a 10 minute walk away.

Stayed here for 5 nights on the Tokyo leg of our honeymoon. This hotel is located smack bang in the middle of Shinjuku. 50m from the cinema (the godzilla). It's around 300m from Shinjuku train station which translates to 2 small city block and around 5 minutes walk through the crowds of people that Tokyo is famous for. The check in was extremly fast and efficient. The 4 x lifts are fast but can be bogged down with the sheer volume of people staying here. Funnily enough the floors and rooms were very quiet though. There is a public bath on the top level but no large tattoos allowed so we didnt get a chance to try it out. There's plenty of vending machines around for supplies and 2 x convenience stores within 30m of the front door. The rooms are very very small but this is to be expected in Tokyo where space is at a premium. There is barely space to put your luggage but it didnt bother us and the room actually had a really nice and cosy feel to it. The bathroom was also small but adequate and very clean. The room was serviced like clockwork daily too. There is free wifi throughout the hotel and it was very good quality and didn't drop out for as long as I used it. No room safes but never had an issue here, even when I accidentally left cash and my Samsung tablet out on the bed, (love Japan right?!). Overall I'd definitely stay here again, centrally located, efficient, clean and safe. Exactly what you're after in this price range. Enjoy!

Perfect location, walking distance to trains, robot restaurant and loads of eating places.Good serviceVery small roomsBuffet breakfast was a bit limited and did not provide any fresh fruit.Good communal bath spa
user_name:
Dee P
Sydney Olympic Park, Australia

review_body: The hotel is set in the crowded area of Shinjuku. Very tall building with 28 floors. There s a public bath on the top floor. You can check in from 3pm. We were fortunate that we can check in a bit early because there s a room available. The room size is usual. Small. But very functional. Very large tv screen. I guess it s 55 inch plus.Would recommend to my friends to stay here.

In general a great hotel. Rooms are very small, but everything has his place. Very clean and modern. The price is fair since its extraordinary position (just in the middle of Shinjuku, the central area of Tokyo!). We were maybe a little "disappointed" about the floor of our room (8, and the hotel has 28 floors!).

Location is superb. The hotel is easy to find and it's just 5-10min walk from the Shinjuku train station. This hotel is right in the middle of the busiest city, there are shopping malls, convenience stores, cinema, restaurants and cafes around and everything is within 5-10min walk. Room is really small, in the standard twin sharing room, you basically need to take turns to open your 24" luggage. But for what we paid, I wouldn't complain. As the usual check-in time in Japan is 4pm, I've requested for early check in and was still worried as, judging from their slow email reply, I thought they might not meet my special request. Was very happy to know that my room was ready when I got there at 12pm+. What to eat? Try ICHIRAN ramen (the best ramen I've had in Japan), or Coco Curry House (for their non-spicy curry rice). Or if you want cheaper option, there's a Yoshinoya nearby too. This place is highly recommended if you want to have a feel of Tokyo city life. But due to its size, it's not a place you could sleep in for the whole day.

Central of Shinjuku, just 10mins walking to JR Shinjuku station, very convenience for food and other stuff you needed from 7-Eleven, Family Mart & Lawson. Just keep ignoring all the 'promoter' for restaurant or other 'entertainment' as you walking back to the hotel at night.Good service from the hotel, even the room bit tiny, just enough for us Asian size.Reception fluent in English, hotel very secure,only patron with key card could enter the floor. I'd come back to this hotel again the next time I'm in Shinjuku. They just don't have laundromat service only for dry cleaning. Bed is very comfy and quilt quite fluffy it's just the 2 pillow we had only too small not the average size pillow. That's the only down side of it the rest we are very please with the hotel/room.

Very tiny room, but sufficient for two people. Shinjuku is such a large station that the walk from the station to the hotel was a little longer than we anticipated, but it was fine. The rooms are clean and modern, and there is a very nice public onsen (hot spring bath), which was great for relaxing our tired travel muscles. This hotel is in a prime location for experiencing Shinjuku. I recommend Itamae Sushi in the nearby building that houses the cinema - some of the best sushi I've ever had.

Very nice guests at the reception, good English speaking. The room was little but this is Japan... the location is perfect for night life as well as close to metro and JR station. Very good wi-fi service at reception and floors.

Good and modern hotel with good facilities near shinjuku station and central parts of Tokyo. Good transportation and connection options to other parts of Tokyo and in the middle of bars and a lot of restaurants. The Spa was included and was really good and clean. The only bad thing is they dont allow people with tattoos in their SPA but this is everywhere in Japan so either you have to cover your tattoos and even then maybee if they see they can tell you its not ok. But this is every onsen and pool in Japan that they dont accept tattoos. Everything with this hotel was good and clean and near everything but the rooms are very very small but double bed is ok for two people. Overall good hotel.

There is a space crunch in tokyo, hence all average hotels have small rooms. Apa hotel rooms were small, but enough for two people. The size did not matter as almost all day you are outside. It had all proper amenities. Hotel check in is automated. We stayed there for three days and not once did we feel that we are in the middle of a red light district. Lot of restaurants, pubs, shopping places etc. are just a walk away. Most of the pickup points for tour buses are walking distance. And the best part is ten minute walk from shinjuku station. Do remember to exit from east kabukicho side. They have an onsen (public bath) that provided a good relief from a tiring day. We were initially intimidated as you have to enter the bath without any clothes but gradually it doesn't matter. The lotion and creams provided are quite nice. They even changed our room for last day as one of our washroom component wasn't working. Must stay here for couples, family or friends.

Very small room, but clean. Check in staff very basic service, unable to provide further information on area. Buffet breakfast nice, good range of choices, but same every day.Convenient location. Public bath very refreshing. Inconsistent cleaning service, got one complimentary water every second day!

Everything is new and clean. Hotel building, room, bathroom and Public Bath. Short walking distance to JR Shinjuku. Nearby Family Mart, 7 Eleven, Toho Cinema, Isetan and so many restaurants around. Room is too small. It is hard to fit 2 luggage.Suggestion : you need to go down earlier when check out because the elevator is always crowded during check out time.

Typical "Japanese" Size Room but Modern. Room was Extremely Small wherein our Bed was literally next to the Window & Walls. But it did offer an excellent view of the Area. Location was Super Excellent. Access to everything is right at your doorstep, Food, Shopping, Train Station. Dont stay here IF you want a more "Serene, Quiet & an area next to nature coz this is NOT the Place for your. Very HIp, Modern, Bright & alive area !!! Loved it !!!

We arrived after 11pm at night. The hotel has a nice lobby. However when we had trouble getting the key card and one of the female staff was very rude and not helpful. The bed is too soft and the room is extremely small that cannot fit a suitcase. Location is good but dont think we will be back.

Stayed in APA from June 6th to 13th. Great location, close to many restaurants, bars and Shinjuku station.As it is located inside Kabukicho red light district, single men walking alone after 8 PM are approached by nigerian touts when walking around, who offer adult-only services. Just ignore them. As it is Japan, even this kind of neighborhood is extremely safe. The place is crowded with young Japanese boys and girls having fun after work.Rooms are very very small, but as I was prepared to it, no surprises.Perfect for a single traveler.The hotel looks very new and everything is clean. Service is OK.APA is a kind of Japanese version of Ibis chain, so do not expect luxury, concierge, bell boys in the front door etc.No wardrobe and safe available in the rooms.I would definitely stay again there.

The hotel is busy; probably due to the relatively low cost and convenient location to Shinjuku station. Room key access control to elevator lobby. I stayed in a twin room. Although the room was small, it was clean and comfortable. The Kabukicho area is not a quiet area; however, the room was quiet. I stayed in a non-smoking room and did not detect any cigarette smoke seeping in from adjacent rooms or floors. For the area, and accommodations, the price for the room is low.

Stayed at this hotel with my wife for two nights, between our trip to Kyoto. It is located about 10mins walk from the Shinjuku main station (Lumine Est entrance) in a vibrant area. Room is small for two adults and two suitcases but it comes with a comfortable bed and decent bathroom.

My wife and I stayed at APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower on our recent honeymoon for 3 nights and it was great. Hotel was clean and the location was fine for us; very convenient. During my research I read how some people were saying the neighborhood was shady. I cannot disagree more. Coming from NYC, Shinjuku is tame and our favorite district out all of Tokyo that we visited. DO NOT be swayed by the "shady" area comment from other reviews!!! Now onto the room. We booked a one double bed room non smoking. I requested a high floor with a good view. They complied and gave me floor 25 and a view of the rail lines. The room was small, the bathroom was small, but that didn't matter because it is not like we are staying in our rooms all day. The bed was comfortable. The pillow was a little too flat for my wife. This hotel was a nice base for our first leg of Tokyo, we would stay here again in our future visit.

New York City, New York

review_body: We really love Japan but it is really frustrating to stay at this hotel. We plan a trip of 10 days including first day at the hotel, followed by a 2-day trip to Fujisan and back to the hotel for the rest of stay. Upon checking out on the first day stay, we asked if we could leave one piece of luggage at the hotel so we don't have to bring two pieces to Fujisan. Sadly, the staff refused it in an extremely poor attitude. We were definitely offended by her attitude and her reason that "this is a busy hotel". We had no choice but to cancel all the subsequent stays in this hotel and move to another one next door. We are still puzzled if it is really the hotel's policy or it has been a bully by the staff.

Very clean and friendly, idea for us as sight seeing. 80 Min train from Narita airport £24 return with 20mins walk from Shinjuku train station. Hotel is very clean and modern, all toiletries provided including toothbrush to hair band. Heart of Tokyo with Lots to do in the evening with restaurants and bars all in Japanese . Great stay with lovely people

Stayed at the APA Hotel Shinjuku Kabukicho Tower for three nights. On arrival, the cab driver took me to the wrong hotel run under the same APA name which was about a ten minute walk away, so it was not fun dragging my bags across ten blocks...but I made it to the right hotel pretty easily.The hotel is very busy with tourists in and out of the small lobby all day. Hotel staff are very efficient and friendly. Rooms are on the small size, but fair for Japan. Beds and linens are very good in the rooms, and the single bed is a semi-double which is of good size. Bathrooms are unit-baths with ample amenities, and the ofuro (public bath) on the top floor is a great way to relax.Location of this hotel is fantastic, just a ten minute walk to JR and subway lines. Shopping, restaurants and bars are all right outside your door. But the area is still a little seedy with the peep shows and other things- but I am sure this is going to fade out over the next ten years.Would I stay again? Sure, location is great, and price is not too bad.

After staying in APA hotels chain in Osaka, we knew what to expect! Fantastic, Friendly service from the staff! The hotels location is perfect! 5 minute walk from all main sights in Tokyo! The rooms were very clean and modern but quite small! However I think you will find this everywhere in Japan! Perfect for anyone travelling on a budget! Best value for money!!! Definitely recommend to anyone staying in Tokyo!

A very busy hotel in the hub of the CBD with activities occurring out side your building and walking distance to restaurants and the night life. A 5 minute walk to the train station. The rooms were small but comfortable - the bathroom felt like you were in a boat but great price, excellent customer service. We had a problem with the booking but the resolved it quickly with a professional approach - we were there during Golden week so there were limited options but they really worked to find a suitable solution...we would book there again :)

The location is convenient close to subway and JR lines, this is a new hotel, the room was clean and had a big tv. But the only big thing is tv, the room is so tiny and there is no sufficient air for two people, and you can not open the window. It is not comfortable with big luggages. But it's a good value for money.

The rooms are TINY! However are absolutely brilliant. The baths on the roof were fantastic! The men's has beautiful views over the city - not sure about the ladies though! Everything is clean and the staff are very friendly. We really could not fault this hotel. Go in expecting a small room and you'll love it. It's super easy to check in - all automated and in all languages. Same with checking out! It's very easy to get to Shinjuku JR (for those with a rail pass) and the metro is even closer than the JR.

So glad I booked here. They speak English so well enough and even let you leave your baggage in case you still want to explore after the 11am check out time. Close enough to the JR train station to walk to. Food all around the place and free wifi in the hotel. Bed was so comfy and room was full of amenities! At 1am we walked around and everything was still open! Love it here! Will stay again:)

This is a decent hotel in the midst of Shinjuku Kabukicho entertainment district. I stayed at this hotel along with 4 more members of my extended family. We had booked 3 double-bed rooms. We were all international travelers and had big suit-cases with us. That was a mistake for these rooms as there is no space to accommodate big size suit-cases. The rooms are just big enough to accommodate two in-cabin size baggage. Bathroom and showers are quite small as well. Everything in the rooms is very clean and very well maintained.Location of the hotel is great if you are planning to be staying in Shinjuku close to entertainment district. There are many good restaurants almost adjacent to it including Indian, Italian and Chinese. Shinjuku station is about 10-minutes walk from this hotel. Hotel has excellent buffet breakfast in the morning and is very much worth its price. One can buy the breakfast buffet coupons at the time of check-in into the hotel. I would highly recommend international travelers to buy the breakfast buffet coupons upon check-in and enjoy this breakfast every morning. There is a coffee shop and bar within the hotel which is open during day time. Restaurant within hotel offers minimal menu for lunch and dinner - but we never felt the need to use it due to plenty of eating choices in the vicinity.Kabukicho is the red-light district area. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find the entertainment district to be very safe and appropriate for everyone including families. Due to many gaming places and karaoke bars around the hotel, the neighborhood is always very crowded with youngsters. Inside hotel it was always very quite and we never heard any noise.

This is my APA hotel stay in Tokyo(after great experience in APA hotel in Kyoto).This one has a slightly bigger space and the hotel itself has more rooms available.Staffs are able to converse in english which was a major plus point for me.Many restaurants around the area so no worries of going hungry.

This hotel has a very good and lively location but there is very less space in the room. You hardly can move in the room.Online booking cant really give you an idea about the size of the rooms. If you request the hotel management to show you the room ,they wont let you see the room and after paying the money you get shock.Few good points are..1. Very clean rooms and house keeping very friendly and professional.2. Spa is an added attraction.

This hotel located in downtown of Shinjuku, only take 9minute walk from west exit of Shinjuku station. The room pretty small but clean and they have complete bath stuff. The staff on the front desk so humble and good english. Also they give us 3kind of butter for free

The hotel is well organized, new and cozy. I had the higher floor room with a little bit view on the west Shinjuku. After the long day of walking around the city, the spacious public bath on the top floor gives you a great relax, no worry , it's a separate bath for female and male.Location: It took about 15 mins walking from JR or metro main lines because of the late night crowds and long.For 2-3 night, its a great, for longer, it just took too much of walking which i know it's quiet valued for it's location already.

This hotel was fantastic. Sure the rooms were small, but this is Japan - it's totally normal. The only complaint is that the pillows are super flat. I would ask for at least two pillows per person. Other than that, we had a wonderful stay. The location is not loud or noisy (though we were up high). We felt completely safe walking around at night. Would definitely stay here again.

APA hotel really satisfied me this 5 days as it had a comfortable bed and a very convenient location for shopping, transport and eating. Shinjuku Station was the best Pick because it held the JR Yamanote line. Really satisfying and hoping to it again.

I really liked the APA chain of hotels. this hotel was located in Kabuki-cho and perfect for good food and entertainment. The room is small but comfortable. However, if you have got a huge luggage, you may end up opening it only on your bed. For the price we pay, it's a good deal.

We stayed at the hotel between the 4th to 7th May and have to say that we were more than happy! Very clean, great amenities, plus points for fast check in - this hotel had it all. Not only was it centrally located, the Shinjuku metro station is also very close. Highly recommended!P.s. The room isn't very large but by Tokyo standards, it was great!

We moved here unexpectedly from the nearby Gracery Hotel and I'm repeating a bit of info that applies to both hotels. We liked this hotel for its public bath - we're kinda hooked on them. The room is smaller than the Gracery's. One tip is to request a room with 2 twin beds rather than a double - the room itself is larger to fit them, and they push together. The view was great, very similar to the Gracery's - we were up high in both hotels. The wifi was good. In the daytime, the lobby is crowded with left luggage.To get here, exit through Shinjuku Station's East Exit (yellow signs, also eventually says "for Kabukicho") and follow the crowd past the smoking pen. Look for Studio Alta (the big video screen up ahead). On the left side of Alta is a ped-only street. Walk down it to the next light (Yasukuni Dori). There's a Don Quixote store across the street. Cross and continue up to the end of the street and the hotel. Godzilla is obvious on the Hotel Gracery ahead. Turn left when you reach the IMAX theaters, then skirt to the right around the Gracery. Take a left on the sidewalk past the on-street bar area (maybe half a block down). APA Hotel's on the right, past the indoor arcade.The walk here is easy in the morning but gets more and more crowded as the day progresses. There's actually a big shopping mall beneath Shinjuku station and the streets here, called the Subnade, and you'll see entrances to it along Yasukuni Dori. We took advantage of it when we were leaving for the station and it was raining buckets. It connects to the station (goes through a Lumine department store first). Follow the signs.APA Hotel is barely within the Kabuki-cho neighborhood, the historic red light district, but it's more family friendly these days. We took an audio tour of Kabuki-cho one night, just the two of us, and went waaay back into the interior streets, amid love hotels and host and hostess bars and yakuza territory and never once did we feel unsafe. There are people walking around everywhere. Yes, there are prostitutes and shady bars but they had no interest in us. So don't let the location worry you. Just be sensible and don't go into a bar with touts.

This was probably the smallest room I've ever stayed in. However the room design was very well thought out and it had every I needed. The room was very modern and clean. I would really recommend this as a base to explore Shinjuku as the location was perfect

The hotel is nicely located close to Shinjuku station, about 5 min walk from the East Exit. Newer hotel but the lobby is small and very chaotic because they don't have a Bell Desk, so suitcases took up 70% of the lobby space! The room is quite small but that was expected in any hotel in Shinjuku. The only thing that was a huge put off was the musky smell from the bathroom. Not sure where it came from because the bathroom looks very clean, maybe just because it was a small space with no window, the humidity caused the smell. Even with the fan on, we couldn't vent out that smell. The public bath is not as big as I expected but it was a nice feature to have.

Kabukicho is a very nice location, it has a lot of restaurants nearby. Just within 5 to 10 mins walk can find shops, department stores, coffee shops etc. etc. it is really convenient, easy to access just less then 10 mins walk from the JR station EAST EXIT. The hotel....honestly was a bit unexpectedly ...... small. We had a double room, 2 persons, one of us had to stay on the bed all the time when we were both in the room..hahahaha!!!! The bed was a bit too soft. The toilet was really small too, I think if a guy that is over 173cm has to open the door to sit on the toilet bowl...hahahah!!!! well~But I think it is fine, as most of the time is not inside the room. The room was clean, the staff were helpful and efficient. Definitely will stay here again, as I really like the location. ^^

The hotel is centrally located. Very convenient to travel around. There is a public bath at the 28/f which is very nice. A bit expensive given that the room is very small without breakfast included. Room is very clean. You may get some disturbance if you are a single male to workaround in midnight near the hotel area but you may ignore them. I will stay in this hotel again.

- The location is very good. - The area is a busy area but good for tourist.- Kabukicho is the red light district but we hardly even realised that. - Walking distance to the train station & lots of eateries and shops nearby.- Public onsen on the last floor is nice.- Staff are friendly- Rooms are small though.

1. Room is clean 2. Nice public bath and Spa area3. Great location, easy access to restaurants and shopping area of shinjuku4. Very nice staffBut:1. Bed is too small2. Mattress is too soft and pillow too low

The hotel is located in Kabukicho, which is the red light district of Tokyo. I don't think this ended up being the best location for my stay, but could be very good for others. It is about a 10 minute walk from the JR Shinjuku station. The room is very small, but it is Tokyo and I didn't really expect any more space. The room was clean, the water pressure for the shower was excellent, the wi-fi was free, and the bed was fine. The only negatives were that sometimes it took a while to catch an elevator and the small window made us feel like we were on a cruise ship.

If you are looking to be right in the thick of the action this place is for you! Walking into the hotel it has a very impressive foyer. The staff were friendly, and helpful and got our group checked in pretty quickly. Our room while functional is teeny tiny! There isn't much space for you bags but it's not really the kind of place where you will be going to hang out in your room. My husband is over 6ft 4 and he fit in the bed and the shower area which was the main thing I was worried about. There is no shortage of restaurants, entertainment, quick food stops, bars etc right at your doorstep. There was also a little fridge in the room which was a great help. If you are looking for a spacious room to relax in, this place may not be for you. If you are looking for somewhere to sleep that is close to everything it's a great option. Shinjuku metro/JR station is about 5 minutes walk away.

We are currently staying at this hotel on 13th floor, we leave on the 28/4/16. Rooms are extremely small no storage or place to put your luggage, room was not clean had hair in the shower and sink ect...Room smells really bad of smoke, 1 extremely thin pillow each. No safes in rooms. No water in room until day 2....We requested laundry to be done and it wasn't when I went to the counter the next day Saturday they said we couldn't have it done until Monday as Sunday the Laundry was closed no offer to help us out... We aren't allowed to use the baths as we have tattoos nothing mentioned at time of booking. Staff speak very little English, and not helpful. Wouldn't stay here again over priced for what you get... Would go to another hotel if I could get our money back..

- excellent location: next to Shinjuku station (trains+ subways), in a very lively district (not disturbing to sleep though)- pleasant essential oil smell within the hotel- very helpful and easy-going staff (we could have left our luggage 4 days in the hotel). Be patient though as there are trainees at the reception whose English is not that good.- bathroom and bedroom very well furnished (coffee set; soap-shampoo-body lotion-Q tip-hair tie-hairdryer...)- super extra clean and comfortable- free wi-fi- public bath on the top floor- the room is tiny and being organized is compulsory if you want to manage to "move" around

The hotel was everything we expected. Fantastic location, the staff were very helpful (having Google Translate available at times helped), the room is small - yes - but we knew that. But it was also well appointed, the bathroom very modern and pleasant, and the spa on the top level a bonus. For the money, we say you can't go past it.

As you'll read time and again, it's a narrow hotel with small rooms. However, that's the Japanese way. You'll see lots of tall narrow buildings there. Many many rooms, stores, businesses, home, etc, are small. The hotel felt authentic. My friend stayed at the Hilton Tokyo and we visited his hotel. You had no idea you're in Asia or Japan. If you want generic resort quality accommodations (expensive too), choose the Hilton Tokyo. The hilton lobby is full of non-Asian travellers. The Apa Kabukicho lobby is full of Asian tourists. The people and hotel and accommodations ensure you feel the vibe of the locals. The location can't be beat for a safe and decent hotel. The Shinjuku Kabuki-Cho area is purely entertainment. You can eat, drink, and party 24 hours there. Bars, games, karoke, arcades, clubs, massage parlors, hookah spots, etc--it's all represented in abundance here.
