Chicago, Illinois, United States

review_body: The hotel room is small, but comfortable enough to stay considering this is a budget hotel. Location was quite good, just a 10 mins walk to the Shinjuku station. Near Koreatown as well if you like Korean Food.

I was disappointed with this hotel....It is probably good for solo travellers and those making a quick stopover. The rooms are tiny and we could barely fit in our cases-had to rearrange the room. Ability to converse in English was very limited and frustrating many times...especially when there were frequent Internet issues. Checking in took ages...you lined up, are given a card and then have to go to a machine where you do it all yourself. The bathroom was miniature. There is no way you could use it-so we used the onsen each day. Not great also to find black hair sit there for days. Pillows were about a millimetre thick so not a comfortable sleep at all. Location was good although in the trashy part of Tokyo with stripper bars etc.

The only pro for the hotel was the location where you can find almost everything you need in the surrounding and it only take 10mins walk to the Shinjuku station which connected you to anywhere!The room was small. Though we know rooms in Japan used to be very small. However, rooms in this hotel is REALLY SMALL which. We can beastly opened 2 hand carry luggage in room.Most importantly, the service was rather disappointing. Those Japanese hotels that we came across with used to be very polite and read to help even they can not fully understand English. This APA hotel was totally another story for service. The night we arrived and found that the air-con only provided heat and we called to seek help. All they told us was 'You may tire off the air con. We have no ways to help'. It was not until I told them I can't breathe they put our room into air con mode. On the second night we came back we found they turned off our air con and put it in fan mode only without asking for our permission.

When we arrived it was before check in time, which was fine because we just wanted to leave our luggage and come back. Conveying this message however was tricky. The receptionist didn't speak much English but in her defence we didn't speak much Japanese. The issue came when she was trying to understand us and then left us at reception for at least 15 minutes, where she went I don't know. After half an hour we were finally able to leave our bags.When we came back to check in around 4.30pm, our room was still not ready. We had to wait another half hour till a room was available.The room itself was very clean and tidy. Quite small, but half the places we stayed in Japan were like that.The hotel was quite nice and in a convenient location for Shinjuku, just the customer service/check in procedure was disorganised and chaotic.

rooms are clean and comfortable but really small. not advisable if you need space or have big luggage. breakfast is quite expensive at 1,800 yen, but many of the restaurants in the area only open around 10am or 11am. nightlife in the area is good, but slightly dodgy. there is a family mart right across the hotel so easy to get snacks or drinks. seibu shibuya station is a really small station on a useless line though. more major stations are about a 10-15 minute walk away.

this hotel is in the hit-rate hotel in online hotel agent. as i need to search a hotel with carpark in tokyo Centre with reasonable price, it's a big difficult for me, just 2 weeks to go. so...i chose it! (with reasonable parking fee and good hotel location)location is perfect, located in the heart of Shinjuku! lot of restaurant and shopping malls nearby.this hotel should be a new building, furniture is new but room is small. well...it's a standard space of semi-double room in Japan, just fit for one 28" luggage.carpark arrangement is so bad because it is free to anyone to park, not exclusive for guest. so we have no space when we arrived at 16:00. we need to park our car in the next carpark with 2200 yen for 10 hours only. the hotel carpark is 1000 yen per day! well.....when we backed to hotel at 21:00, hotel carpark space is available but we still need to pay 1000 yen for the 1st day, no matter which time you park (hotel guest), you need to pay full charge per day.finally i spent total 4200 yen for 2 nights parking (2200 yen for public parking fee, 2000 yen for 2 nights hotel parking fee), original budget is 2000 yen for 2 nights!!!i think the carpark policy for hotel should be amended! hotel carpark should be exclusively for hotel guest only, especially this hotel have no wedding venue or conference venue. normally room guests only.

This hotel looks shiny, but it's not in a great part of town. You have to walk through drunks and avoid vomit on the ground at night and during the day hold your nose to avoid the smell of all the garbage from the late night partying. When I checked in, the hotel was aware that my luggage was being delivered the next morning. They asked me to pay the 3,000 yen delivery fee and I did. Today, I come back to the hotel to no luggage. Why? The hotel denied the luggage because they said I owed an extra 700 yen. That's about $6. They turned away my luggage for $6 instead of just accepting it and letting me know the mistake and asking me to pay the difference. My flight leaves early and I might have no luggage. This is not the level of service you normally see in Japan. Any hotel would have paid the extra $6, but this just goes to show you how cheap this hotel is. They boast an outdoor bath on the 28th floor. It's big enough for 2 people max and you don't even know you are outdoors except for the fact that you can feel the breeze. You can't even see through all the barriers to make it worth it. It's not at all as described. The rooms are business size in Japan. This means 2 people in a room will be tripping over each other so you better love your roommate. Next, my sheets were not changed. It says they will be if they are obviously dirty. I spilled my morning coffee all over myself and it got on the sheets. I cleaned as best I could but there are brown stains all over the sheets. I left the bed with the covers pulled back to show the obvious stain. Didn't matter. Same sheets. So now the smell of coffee will be with me as I sleep. Speaking of sleep. I had to go buy a pillow. The pillows are super thin and horribly uncomfortable. Although the bed and divert felt nice, I couldn't sleep. Thank goodness there is a Don Quixote nearby where I could get one. And luggage. You probably won't be able to fit or open a big suitcase without putting in on your bed. Also, if you have luggage that is unruly or large, it will not be easy to get it to the train station and to the hotel. The ground is pretty uneven and it's about an 11 minute walk. You'll probably need a taxi to drop you off. Because of the location, Inattentiveness of the staff, and the fact that they wouldn't pay $6 on my behalf, this hotel is a no go for me and I wouldn't even return of the room was free.

I and my brother stay at this hotel for 4 nights. 239/night avg. Not too bad due to cherry blossom season. We got the double room . Since the bed is fitted sideway against all the wall, my brother has to 'climb over' me to get off the bed. Which was a bit inconvenience. The size of the room was small. Just barely able to open 2 suitcases on the floor. On the positive side, the bed was very comfortable. The staff was friendly. Location wise, this hotel is in the red light district. It is safe to stay but there are touts in the area that approach your for 'female entertainment'. Actually they didn't use that exact phrase. They were much more direct. There is 7/11 and family mart 1/2 min away. Very convenient. They open 24 hrs.

APA Hotel Shinjuku is worth a stay in the expensive city of Shinjuku . Rooms are small but everything fits in there - All basic amenities are available. Wifi is good also. The service is upto expectation. The location is right in the city

We understand that this is a budget hotel but the room is just too small. We were two in the room and we could not even move around nor open our luggages.the location was good though but it seems like people who are on a budget or people who are in a quick business trip will be the only ones staying here.Check in was fast and staff were nice.

Seems like APA is a hotel chain that focuses on small rooms with comfort and amenities. The room is very small and there was no space for our suitcases. We kept our two bags zipped up and put them under the table. Everything is very compact and works very well. The amenities were replenished every day by the wonderful staff, and it includes everything we need. If you don't like the small bathroom, you can use the communal shower on the top floor. Lots to explore around the hotel. Definitely much better than a capsule hotel.

This hotel is well presented and located in the heart of Shinjuku where the action is. Checkin was pleasant and we were directed to our room on the 11th floor. Having seen the narrowness of the building facade from the outside, and recognising the typical sizing of accommodation in Tokyo, we were expecting a small hotel room. However, what we got was too small. The width of the room is the length of the bed. There is no cupboard in which to put/hide any gear and with 2 x bags the bulk of the floor space was used standing these up on their narrow ends! The bathroom facilities are suitable for people less that 2m in height (when drying yourself, watch out for the ceiling!). The TV in the room is nearly as wide as the bed (on the wall at the end of the bed) and offers some English channels also. There was just room to roll out the yoga mat from the door past the bathroom - entire floor space then used. Don't bring the cat - couldn't swing it here!

Very nice decor. The rooms are on the smaller size as is the bathroom but adequate. The beds are very comfy however the pillows are very hard. The central air conditioning cannot be adjusted so if you don't like your room hot you may be in trouble. We propt the door open to let the cool air in. The staff speak very little English so are no help in directing you to any sites. However the train station is only 5 minutes walk where you can get heaps of info. The spa on the top floor is a lovely relaxing way to finish your day.

This is a clean, comfortable hotel in a great location. Its proximity to Shinjuku station is a god-send when you have two suitcases. The area has a great vibe. Make sure you leave the station by the east exit. Yes, the room was small but we had no problems with 2 people and 3 suitcases. The single beds are huge and very comfortable. The pillows are another matter - very thin and hard! An extra one just made it feel harder. Only complaint would be that the room was too warm with no real way of cooling it. Tried to ask the desk staff but they speak little English and just pointed to the sign saying 'heating only today'. Ended up wedging the door open to allow cold air to get into the room - left it like that overnight (you can still put the lock-thingy on for security). The Japanese seem to like excessive heating (even our flight was too hot!). There are plenty of great restaurants nearby and also 7-11 or Family Mart to buy food for breakfast. We enjoyed our stay here and would recommend it. PS - the British Pub nearby has great Happy Hour specials until 7pm - G and T for 190 yen - bargain.

More a hour motel than a real hotel.Room was so small i could barely fit my luggage in it.Position is great and price is decent given the average price of tokyo, but it's more really a bad taste motelPlus, hotel sent me an email at 830 saying that if i hadnt shown up by 11 my reservation would have been cancelledBad bad place

Booked this hotel because of its proximity at the starting point of the 2016 Tokyo Marathon. Would've booked somewhere nearer but every hotel in Shinjuku was pretty pricey during the marathon week. This was the fairly cheaper hotel. Still expensive though at $80++ a night but what the heck. It's near Seibu Shinjuku station and three blocks away JR Shinjuku station. It's very near the Godzilla peeking building and at the end of Kabuki-cho. You know, the largest red light district in Japan. So if you like a hotel near "where the action is" this is the hotel for you. Did I mention its near shopping malls like isetan and awesome restaurants like the Robot restaurant? It's practically a bachelor's hotel. Good thing I've booked here. Room is very small but that's standard in Tokyo. Plus, there's a lot of convenience stores in the area. Staff were helpful as well, although they speak limited English. More or less I recommend this hotel when you're in the Shinjuku area.

I recommend this hotel. Small but functional room for 1 people, which was my selection this time.No sauna in this hotel. They had only what they call spa. It means two pools: one hot and other cold.Location of the hotel is great as all kind of activity are available just leaving the hotel door. Breakfast was complete and organized.

Stayed here for a couple nights, hotel was clean, the pillows were terrible like a pancake the bed was comfy but prepare for the room, it is very tiny but in a good spot and a good price. I Didnt really get a chance to see how the service was.

Right in the middle of all on offer, small compact clean rooms, yes unusual tinyfirm pillows and a great spa steam bath house on top floor!Good value in great location.Be at Isetans main front door at 10.27am to experience the daily openingritual,like none other anywhere!

Good surprise. This hotel network seems to be present in many places in Tokyo. Hotel is brand-new. Room was small but functional and clean. Breakfast great. Location even better. I missed only sauna and gym. Different was the check in and check-out on a standing machine.

My husband and I stayed at APA for 8 nights as the price was great! I was worried after reading reviews about this being a dangerous area/red light district but we had no issues. The hotel is in a good location and is only a short walk from the JR station. The rooms were reasonable and are the size expected for Japan. There are so many food options which was great and a family mart is across from the hotel.We did complain about the speed of the wifi as it was the worst we experienced while in Japan but the language barrier made it difficult for the reception staff the understand. This was the only issue we experience with the hotel. Overall it was a good stay, there is a free public bath available on the 28th floor which was awesome after a long day of walking. If you're after a busy environment, great places to drink and cheap food this is the place to stay.Tips Avoid going with anyone from the street offering good drinking deals or entertainment as these people are usually trying to scam you (and work for the yakuza). Just politely say "no thanks" and you will be fine! Go to places to eat that are Japanese only for the best prices. Avoids westerner places as these are generally more expensive. We went to a place that was don't a staircase (I didn't get the name) which looked scary at first but it was awesome (we had to wait a little to get in) drinks and food were all 300 yen each!!

Here with my husband for a short get away from Singapore had 3 nights here. Location is fantastic, near to lotsa convenient stores and restaurants. Tiny room, with small window. Breakfast has limited choice. The room next door left their rubbish outside our room and was not cleared for 2 days. (By the way you will have to clear your own bin within room and have it place outside your door for them to clear it off.) Called reception on day 3 to have them change the bed sheets was told that if we request to have the bed sheets changed they will not provide complimentary bottled water for that day, told reception no water was given since day 1 but receptionist just said "oh ok" thats it?! No efforts to even apologise or do anything. In the evening, room was not cleaned, called reception, language barrier again. Finally understood the part about why they did not change bedsheets reception replied oh ok again. Nothing done no apologies . Towel was left outside the door. Only 1 english new channel, will need to pay 1000 yen for movie . Overall will not recommend this hotel, will check out hotel gracery next time which is near this hotel.

It is not a hotel you would want to spend much time in your room because they are very small even by Japanese standard. I took a single room and I couldn't open my suitcase unless I put in on my bed. However, the hotel is centrally located in one of the busiest retail districts in Tokyo surrounded by restaurants, cafes, drug stores and nightlife. It is located in their redlight district but it didn't bother me as Japan is a very safe country for travellers. The hotel is 5 mins away from the Shinjuku JR station which is a major point to go anywhere. The area is a jungle of neon signs and nightspots. Reception is helpful and efficient.

ReviewI would first like to say that this hotel and the APA line are not bad they are in fact pretty good considering the price. However that said I would like to break it down into the pro's and con's.GOODStaff and Activitys:This hotel is in one of the best locations for shinjuku if your into the night life and tangoing with the much pronounced Yakuza presence and their adult entertainment abundance here if that is your thing its also good if your looking for the Robot Cafe and Samuri Museum which both where AWESOME by the way! the staff and amenaties are great the hotel even has its own public bath.BADWIFI:This is a pritty big one if your a travailing business man or even a family on holiday. The WIFI is NOT SO WIFI'ing its seriously the worst internet on the planet I'm pretty sure all the IP address are limited to only 300kb bandwidth or 0.3 MB speed if that makes more sense basically don't expect to be watching any type of youtube or researching much at all. loading the basic web page is just about all you can do on this so called free wifi. If you need to remote out of you laptop for work or various other reasons your better off finding a better hotel for wifi. BAD INTERNETLanguage:The staff while helpful do lack a little in english department depending on who you speak too.PS. You will have to ask for extra pillow's unless you like sleeping without any.

I and my family stayed in APA on 2/9 and 2/12-14. The first stay was pretty good. However the second visit made me feel like staying in a totally different hotel. Not only check-in and payment procedure became totally different (and complicated), but the room quality went down. There was a vomiting smell on the hallway. =__= Also the hotel counter staffs' English were really bad. I feel difficulty communicating with them. For example, I purchased some goods in Bic Camera Store and had them delivered to Apa.... but the hotel counter staff misplaced my goods with other guest's goods...and..it is so difficult to let the counter staff understand he gave me wrong parcels..... I won't chose Apa for my next visit to Tokyo.

If it's your first visit to Tokyo, you may consider choosing a hotel near Shinjuku station, which is perhaps the largest transportation hub, and you can go almost anywhere in the city conviniently using public transportation from this station. There are seveal APA hotels in Shinjuku area, the Kabuchicho Tower APA is 10 mins walk north of the east side of the Shinjuku station. We chose this one because it has a Japanese style public bath on the top floor, which opens till very late - ideal if you would like a hot bath after a little late night drink. What's not so good: the rooms are very small, It's a budget hotel after all. A bit of outside noise till midnight if you live on lower floors.

Stayed here end-Jan-start-Feb. Easy to find from Shinjuku station, just keep following the direction to Kabukicho and you'll exit at 3-chome, or pass through Subnade to exit at 1-chome (which is closer). Keep a lookout for Hotel Gracery and APA is just around the corner from it.You can deposit your luggage way in advance; and we did for ours a day ahead of our check-in date.Be prepared that the rooms will be small, as is the norm in major cities like Tokyo. It's good enough for rest/sleep since we were out most of the day. Our room was pretty high up so we had a nice view of the city, Godzilla's bust, and the trains coming in and out of Shinjuku station. Bathroom comes with a tub although we mostly used the public onsen on the top floor. There's no safe box though, so keep your passport with you when you're out. 2 dustbins were provided to separate our combustible/non-combustible trash, which is great for recycling.Not all staff speaks English/Mandarin so it's helpful if you know some Japanese phrases.There are 2 magnets for your door: Do not disturb, and Minimal cleaning. I thought the Minimal cleaning magnet was Please Clean My Room because the details were in Japanese so for the first 2 nights only the bathroom and dustbins were cleaned and our towels and slippers were changed. Don't stick anything on your door and they'll clean everything and refill your coffee/tea packs.There was only heated air in all rooms during our stay so it got quite warm and it was difficult to sleep. The cold air mode was disabled so we tried changing it to fan mode but didn't feel much of a difference. Reception advised to use the fan mode, so we told her it didn't work and she must have done something with their systems because it was cooler the next day onward.Artificial onsen on the top floor isn't huge, so if you need lots of personal space like I do, the indoor pool can feel crowded with more than 5/6 people. There's a smaller outdoor pool and a round tub (water feels hotter in the tub to me) and it's nice with the cold winter air. Remember to keep your voice down though, there was a group of 3 almost every time I went and they were super noisy. Shower before getting in only, and not again when leaving.Ask reception for limousine bus info to Haneda airport, but unlike what it says on the flyer, hotel staff aren't able to (or won't??) reserve seats for you. We walked to the ticket counter near the Shinjuku station west exit to get the tickets ourselves without making reservations.The hotel is situated in the red/neon-light district, which is good because lots of eateries close much later (there's a Family Mart opposite the hotel anyway so you can make late night snack runs). But if you look Chinese/Japanese and travel alone or with a partner of the same gender, you might get targeted by the guys standing around trying to pull guests into their host bars. If you're travelling with your other half, ALWAYS hold hands/arms and they won't bother you.There are lots of department stores nearby, plus there's Muji, BIC + Uniqlo, and Kinokuniya, so for 2 mornings we explored them, went back to deposit our shopping then went out again with lighter backpacks. Bring a tote bag to avoid getting lots of paper/plastic bags from cashiers.Drop your key card at the box outside the lift lobby if you didn't have additional charges. If you do, use the white machines adjacent to the reception counter.TIPS:1. Bring a towel from your room if you want to use the onsen as it's not provided there. Would be great if they could though. Wear the black slippers (you get 2 pairs, white and black) there and put them in the shelf at the entrance.2. Bring a cup from your room to the top floor to get ice, because the disposable ones at the ice dispenser isn't refilled regularly.3. Tap your keycard to enter the lift lobby (we saw lots of confused people there). Buttons corresponds to the lift it's next to, so it might be on the 1st floor but it won't open if you tapped your card at another lift. The lift next to the wheelchair-friendly lift is utilised the least because of this, so it's good for getting between your room and the onsen level if you feel weird about getting seen wearing only the robe provided.4. Bathtubs and basin en suite are on a "countdown" dial so you can turn it to the amount of water you need while you do something else and it'll stop automatically.

I've stayed in my fair share of Tokyo hotels and have a fairly good gauge of Japanese-sized hotel rooms. Small, I can deal with.This is by fair the tiniest business/tourist hotel roo. I've stayed in. (Short of capsule hotels, which I've not tried)So if you are a tourist with a normal amount of luggage, and are staying 2 people to a room, be prepared to feel claustrophobic. And bang into stuff.The good:Hotel is conveniently located near Shinjuku station. Plenty of eating places around. A combini (convenience store) is located directly opposite the hotel. For the price, the location is truly unbeatable. Check in was a breeze and the staff is very professional. There's a waiting area for those who need to repack their luggage. Hotel is clean and new.The bad:Size, size, size. From the tiny corridor that just about fits a luggage, to the tiny room itself.The width of the room is the length of the double bed. The bed is pushed right against the window. The wall mounted tv is at the foot of the bed.There's practically no room to open your luggage. Your best bet is to do it on the bed itself.There is no cupboard to hang clothes, save for a small wall pole with 6 hangers. In winter with large coats, it can be a nightmare.If you are 2 people, be prepared to be on top of each other. I was with my husband and we are relatively average sized Asians. For 2 Westerners, I can't imagine how they would move about. Or not.There's a tiny table and chair, but with the limited space, there's no way you can actually sit at the table.I know you are supposed to be out and about seeing the city and won't spend that much time in the hotel room. But having to return to this room after a long day out was... slightly depressing. I stayed at this hotel because I was in Tokyo during the new year and all other hotels were booked out. This was the only reasonably priced place left within walking distance to the station.To be fair, at this price it's hard to complain. But it really is small so I would like to caution other travellers. Either bring smaller or less luggage. And if you are a couple, book the room with 2 twin beds. I'm guessing it might be bigger.One last note - the pillows are flat as can be. You are better off sleeping on the mattress.Book only if you are travelling on a smaller budget, have little luggage and do not mind a tiny room.

Small which is expected in Tokyo, however very clean and tidy. I was not used to the thin pillow and hard bed but it wasn't uncomfortable. Found that we didn't need the heater on as the duvet kept us extremely warm. Very close to restaurants and not too far from the train. Overall good hotel.

This is a pretty standard business hotel, meaning the rooms are large enough for a bed and not much else. However it is modern and clean. The checking and checkout process is fast and the location is very close to the action in Shinjuku. Management should consider changing the pillows from the current 1 inch tall foam jobs to something more usable/comfortable. Staying here in winter I was baked like an udon in the room - the air conditioning only has heat settings and the bed had a single expedition-weight feather duvet which was overkill. Would stay again.

Nice hotel, new, great location! Take the breakfast, very tasty, and anyway no breakfast restaurants in the area. Room is very small, but comfortable, hard cushion, great Japanese style spa. All in all very nice. I will come again. Good wifi in the room

The location was excellent, the room was clean, and the public bath on the 28th floor was excellent. The only issue was that the room was pretty small. With 2 people and luggage, there was hardly any room to move around.

The location of the hotel is very nice, Shinjuku, that you can find good restaurant to eat. there is the public onsen on the top floor. it's very nice for relaxation. but the room the very small. I went with my friend, I can't even find the space to put our luggage. but overall is good to pay for.

We are a young couple visiting Tokyo as the first stop on our rtw trip. We've loved it! All the more for our stay at the APA Shinjuju Tower. After traveling over 22 hours we wanted a base that was clean, comfortable and well positioned. Just what we got. We wanted for nothing; helpful and friendly staff, efficient check in, heating and an air con/blower unit in the room, TV for watching surreal japanese cartoons and sumo wrestling as well as all the bathroom essentials you may have forgotten and extra for the onsen (of course the toilet has all the sprinkler bells and whistles!). The onsen! Immaculately clean with all the instructions a westerner could want to avoid offending anyone. Breakfast was also fab, a perfect mix of western and Japanese buffet which we stocked up on every morning, very tasty. The location is ideal for Shinjuku station and an interesting neighbourhood to walk round and eat out in. We're not into partying so couldn't say much about it but it looks great fun! Yes the rooms are compact but still cosy and so clean, the bed was extremely comfortable. We'll check out very happy this morning, on to Kyoto!

The main advantage of being in this hotel is the location. You are well located in Shinjuku with many restaurants & cafes nearby. The area is very lively whether day or night. The East exit out of Shinjuku station is the closest to the hotel, however the signs for this exit are very minimal. If you end up being lost in the busiest train station on the planet, I suggest using the South gateway exit, which is well marked. Service from the staff were good and will definitely stay again.

Air conditioning is standard in most terrible cut rate places. Not here. I can't open the window, so I have wedged it partly open with paper and opened our room door to let some air through. Yes, the room is small, but I expected that. Bathroom is fine, internet working well currently. However, the climate control issue is a money saving issue and nothing more. It is simply not good enough.I'd recommend this hotel to drunks sleeping it off or lizard people.

We booked and paid for a larger double room non smoking as my partner and I both can't stand smoking and have asthma. Get there and check in and it's a smoking room. Think to ourselves maybe we can deal with it if it's not too smelly. Go to the room and it's disgusting!! Could not even walk into the room, the smell was overpowering. Went back to reception and they tell us too bad. No other rooms available even tho I could go on to Agoda and there was clearly non smoking rooms still available. Girls behind the counter did not care and would not change us to a non smoking room. We had already paid for the room through Agoda and had to go and find another hotel and just hope we get a refund Bad customer service. Will never stay at an APA Hotel again.

The good things:- Location is nice. It`s located at the heart Shinjuku area- Many eatery food around the hotel- Price is reasonable, compare with similar hotel standard in the same areaThe bad things:- Room are pretty small (which as what I expected)- Hotel staff hardly speak EnglishOverall, I recommend to stay in this hotel.

The hotel is in good location. Next to metro-bus stations bars and restaurants. Rather than this the room is extremely small the people in reception doing their best to assist you but the language is big problem. In 2015 every hotel should have employees that speak english. An other issue was the pillow.. I do not know What they were thinking but this is the worst pillow I ever tried. Nothing special in general I will not stay again in this hotel.

New , clean and modern hotel smack in heart of exciting Shinjuku. Close to food, shopping, JR station (8 mins walk) and Odakyu line (4 mins). Familymart convenience store just across the hotel. Public bath at top floor great for those who enjoy onsen. Rooms are really compact and Westerners may find it too tight, especially the bathroom. Deep enough bath time for petite Asians which has water saving eco line. Bed is comfy with giant-sized TV right in front. Experience spoilt by super flat pillows. Travellers with huge or many luggage have almost no space to place in room. The few copies of Japan Times (English newspapers) provided at lobby run out real fast. Novel check in / check out - pay first and drop keys off at ATM-like machine.

Location is right in the centre of Kabukicho Not far from the Shinjuku JR E exit. For first time visitors ... Kabukicho is The adult entertainment area in Tokyo ... Restaurants, Bars, Karaoke, Host and Hostess Bars.... and its quickly downhill after that ...touts and hookers etc. So Not the Area is Not for Family Holidays although its slowly getting more mainstream . Rooms are small and the Hotel is New but the bed already seemed to have sunken area ! But its clean and comfy enough if you have to be in the area .

I really liked this hotel. It was a great deal. Nice, new rooms, clean, and pretty quiet. I would stay here again, but my only consideration would be the neighborhood... The area is kind of wild, and I'm not sure that's what I was looking for. For perspective, we stayed here four nights, and we had a double room on the 18th floor, facing north. GREAT THINGS:-This place was very clean and nice, given the price. Number one, this is a great value hotel! You really get your money's worth. -The bedding and bed were comfortable. -The hotel employees were very nice. The lady that helped us at check in we really great. One snag- a lot of people leave bags and picking them up later was a little time consuming. You may want to consider the lockers outside the hotel, just to the left. -Free WiFi that was really fast and useful. -The restaurant in the hotel is actually pretty great. There aren't a ton of breakfast options within a few blocks of the hotel, so this was handy, and reasonably priced.-The location is really great, if you're looking for the late night craziness of Shinjuku. It's right outside your doorstep, including the Robot Restaurant. -Transit from here is really great, tons of options. Most notably, the Narita Airport Express is at Shinjuku. You can take one train with all you bags and not transfer before you arrive/leave. I liked this, since the stations can be pretty crazy with all your bags (not unsafe, just hectic!). THINGS TO KNOW:-The pillows! I know everyone mentions it, and it's because they're weird. I slept great with them, but it took some getting used to. -The actual train station next to the hotel (Seibu Shinjuku) is a private-line train station that is rather useless. The walk to Shijuku station is several blocks, but that station provides so many transit options, its worth it. I could never figure it out, but it appears there is a way to almost get to the hotel underground from Shinjuku Station, but the station is so crazy, I just stuck with the route I knew to get out. -The hotel is clearly in a late night (aka red light) district. I always felt very safe, but I got hassled to buy massages and ladies several times at night. Its often by men standing in the middle of the street. It was annoying, but not dangerous. Even the people that were out drinking were so well behaved, it was almost funny. -The rooms are very small. I know this is always the case, and I didn't care, but if you're traveling with more than two suitcases, it could be a legitimate challenge to fit in the room, especially if you have large suitcases. We had two carry-on sized bags and backpacks; we were just fine.

This hotel located in the center of Kabukicho - a red light district in Tokyo, which could be fun to walk around with all the lights on at night, surrounded with pachinkos and restaurants which is also good point, and it is just few minutes walk to the seibu Shinjuku station. So I was absolutely love the location. Hotel staff are all friendly and helpful with limited English though. Room is newly renovated and don't forget to ask for high level floor so you can enjoy the Shinjuku view.However, note that size of room is quite small, we are having problems with just 2 luggages, we really need to take turn to be able to open our luggages. If you travel light then this hotel is perfect!There is a point that turn me down though, first day if check in I noticed the bed head was dusty and even though they did the cleaning , the bed head remain dusty which is quite disturbing.

Very bad services, the room is extremely small, it cannot put a luggage even.... And they do not have the room temperature adjustment, in the room, you only can turn on the warmer, it makes the room very very hot, we cannot sleep at nite .... When we complaint and reflect the option, the staff in hotel, just keep saying "no,no,no".. And not allow us to write the views on complaint form ( as they said no complaint/ options form for customers...:((((( ) besides the staff in the hotel, mostly not able to say English ..........I will not suggest anyone to choose this hotel though it is in a good location...

This hotel was right smack in the middle of the action at shinjuku / kabukicho area and was a short-ish walk away from shinjuku train station. Plenty of restaurants, nightlight, and action, great for seeing the sights and sounds of the crazy shinjuku area. The hotel was small but very comfortable, had everything we needed including BBC channel on the tv. Would recommend this hotel and would happily stay again.

The location is great if you want to explore the seedy side of Kabukicho – for host clubs, hostess clubs and the like. It's also super easy to get to Golden Gai's maze of tiny bars, Korea town, the JR train station, and the glitzier end of Shinjuku's shopping area. No shortage of restaurants either.The rooms are small, but not too tiny. Bed is a bit soft, and pillows a bit flat, but they do put you to sleep. The amenities are standard in Japanese business hotels, with a nice (small) rounded tub in the room (not so ideal if you're tall). Wifi is decent. Check out is as easy as dropping your keycard at the exit. Unlike many high-rise decently-priced hotel, it has more than one lift.The best part is the hotel's onsen (bathhouse) at the rooftop (27th floor) - there is an indoor bathing tub, as well as a smaller outdoor rotenburo from where you can peek at the city below. Nice and clean with rows of washing stalls, it opens throughout the night. Only down side is that the experience can be ruined by people who don't know onsen etiquette.All in all it's a good price for the amenities and the location.

review_body: This hotel was fine - it's a business hotel but had everything you need for a few nights. We were there for 3 and despite our initial trouble finding it, it was a good place to base ourselves. It's right in Shibuya surrounded by pachinko parlours and "massage parlours" (with various other things on offer, no doubt), so a bit seedy. Based on other reviews I'd read, I was expecting a tiny room. It was small, but hardly tiny by Japanese standards. Just small and compact, like pretty much every other hotel room here. Note that you can't use the onsen if you have tattoos. My husband was very disappointed!

I guess the whole tower (all 27 floors) is brand new. Sure looks like it. Rooms are quite small, but you get more than you pay for. The spa on the top floor (free for guests) is fantastic. An you cant beat the location. Would stay again. Beds are really really soft, so if you need a firm bed, dont go to APA. All APA hotels have soft beds FYI (I had to sleep on the floor, as I need an Asian ultra firm bed)...

The room is very small, which I understand in Tokyo is normal, but it is also lacking things. There is no in room safe, which I think is necessary, it's not sound proofed, so you can hear the trains pass by every few minutes, in room wifi is slow, and the pillow is this hard sponge thing.

Perfect and very attractive location in bustling Shinjuku, close to Shinjuku JR rail/subway station. Lots of stores and restaurants within walking distance. This property is very new, clean, modern and if it wasn't for the size of its rooms, even quite comfortable. The basic double room is definitely too small even for one single person, let alone two, especially when these are rather overweight. The bathroom is much more a mere cubicle, although very nice and clean. Quite difficult to handle if you are not really skinny.I enjoyed their breakfast, not too large but still sufficient. It provides both European and Japanese food, all excellent. Another nice feature ist the absence of the nerve-wracking check-out procedure: You pay in advance and when leaving, just drop the key-card into a box. If you have some extras to pay, there are machines. Japanese technology and efficiency at its best.Worth of trying out is also the thermal "onsen" spa on the 28th floor, providing a typical Japanese experience at no extra costs.

We stayed there 3 nights in November. It's pretty close to the train station. Our room on the 6th floor was fairly quiet. Never stayed in a smaller room. I thought it was kind of fun. I think my wife wasn't so enthused. I don't think most westerners will like this. For the price I was satisfied with it.

This is a great location in the middle of Shinjuku Kabukicho district. If you want to know more about the district, read my other view of another hotel in the district. To/from Narita and Haneda airport is very easy via the Airport Bus which stops at the Shinjuku station west exit and a no more than 10min walk to the hotel. The rooms are small. See photos of other people who stayed here. As I say, it is a typical "business" hotel in Japan. If you don't like small rooms (meaning not much space to put your luggage), small bathroom (meaning it only fit 1 person barely), then this is not for you. However, if you are looking for a new hotel, perfect location, and usually a good deal, then I don't see why this won't be in your list of hotels when visiting Tokyo. Mind you, when visiting Tokyo, I spend most of my time outside and not in the hotel so I just go back to bath and sleep. BUT the most important for me is location and cleanliness. Being a new hotel and smack in Shinjuku, it ticks all the boxes for me. Free wifi as for most business hotels in Japan.

The hotel is very central in Shinjuku. Close to all the lights, bars and restaurants. We were high up and it was very quiet with great views. The rooms are quite small for a couple but are brand new and modern. The hotel is very clean. The rooftop Onsen was great and included in the price. The vending machines sell beer if you want a cheeky beer after the Onsen.

Be prepared for the smallest rooms you have ever seen. We booked two doubles, don't even think about sharing a room even if you are a couple. They are a little bit bigger than in a capsule hotel, but not large enough for two people to move around or even for opening your suitcase without laying it on the bed!The hotel was new and had good standard, and very clean. Plus for the hot pool/spa on top floor which was very welcome after long, tiring days of walking around Tokyo.The service level of this hotel is horrible. They will not help you with anything, you have to check in on a machine, and they can't even provide an ironing board or basic amenities. Very no-frills experience. But if you just need a place to sleep, it works.Be aware that hotel is located in middle of a red-light district. Gets dodgy at night, and not good for small children. But it is fairly central, and we did not mind the strip clubs.

If you can overlook the fact that the hotelIs situated right in the heart of the red light district of Tokyo, then it was a pretty nice hotel. It was quite new when we stayed and very clean. It is very conveniently located. Opposite of Shinjuku JR station, easy access to metros or N'EX. Kabukicho area gets pretty trashed during the nighttime, lots of tourists, pimps, gangs. They are harmless, just looking for clients to visit their clubs. We didn't get approached though. Perhaps because we were a couple and looked like tourists. Wouldn't recommend it for families.

I checked out early as it simply does not meet my expectations or standards. If I had known before I would never have booked.Checkin process largely automated. Lobby overflowing with baggage making bad impression.Room the smallest I have ever been in, a step up from a capsule hotel but not even enough space to open a suitcase.Breakfast was feeding time at the zoo. Food not replenished and mostly empty. I walked out and didn't even try.No ironing facilities available meaning must wear wrinkled clothes which is embarrassing. Never have I seen a hotel with no iron even on request !!!Room very expensive for quality or lack thereof. Same price for Marriott Ginza!!!!Location close to station but mostly for young people having a party or going to a strip club it seems.

The smallest rooms we have ever seen, for a couple its better to take twin room. Poor WIFI in the rooms. The rooms are clean and location is great! close to a big metro and JR station (about 7 minutes walk). The price should be below the average.

The hotel is situated in a busy vibrant area .Checking is strange , start with a receptionist then end up with an automatic checkin and pay system. Could of been a lot quicker.  The cost of the hotel was great and it was very clean. Rooms were tiny typical of what you expect of Tokyo. The Tv was huge and took up the whole wall at the foot of the bed..wifi was wasn't that great, slow and kept kicking you off the connection.Paid extra for breakfast ....it was ok. If I had stayed more than one night I would of eaten elsewhere.
